TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment has been made by the Senate to the Corporations Legislation (Evidence) Amendment Bill 1992 to put in place a statutory scheme for a review of the main amendments that are made by the Bill, those amendments being made to narrow the scope of derivative use immunity in relation to civil proceedings or prosecutions for criminal offences. When this matter was before the House, the Opposition opposed those amendments. We do not consider that they are warranted, and we put that case fully and well. The Australian Democrats obviously had misgivings as well, as they have put forward a scheme for a statutory review. Because it reviews what we consider was a bad proposal in the first place, we will support the amendment. But I must say in passing that the scheme for the review looks clumsy and looks as though it will not necessarily achieve the best review of this particular provision.

PARA.TAB: It will be very difficult for somebody to go through the way in which the provisions have helped the enforcement of national scheme laws. One simply will not know whether it was this particular change that led to a charge in one particular case, a prosecution in one particular case or a conviction in one particular case that would not otherwise have transpired. One simply will not know whether this particular change led to an infringement of civil liberties in a particular case without perusing each and every case and each and every factual circumstance and interviewing every person who has been charged and bringing him in. It is going to be very difficult to review, and it is going to be very difficult to gather the evidence.

The way in which the report is to be made will not necessarily allay the qualms that we had in the first place and that led us to oppose the legislation. We still think it was bad legislation. Reviewing it after the event does nothing to allay those fears and qualms. But because it is a review of bad legislation, we will support the amendment that is now before the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House of Representatives is charged by the Constitution with the responsibility for raising revenue and introducing laws for that purpose. With that heavy first responsibility in mind, it gives me no satisfaction—and it cannot give the Government any satisfaction—to note that in this chamber we cannot seem to get right the Government's revenue raising legislation.

PARA.TAB: These amendments involve 17 major changes. I defy anyone to read through the paper which details them and make sense of them in a way that they could be sensibly debated in this place this morning. I have mixed feelings about the situation we find ourselves in because of the Government's legislative incompetence and the fact that it cannot get its legislation into proper form in the House of Representatives. As I have noted before, the House of Representatives has become less of a legislative chamber. We have given that responsibility more to our colleagues in the Senate. It is to the Senate's credit, particularly as evidenced by these amendments, that it is carrying out its true role as a House of review.

The Government does not get its legislation right here, and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) should lift his game. The present Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when Treasurer, made it quite clear that he had no interest in the mechanics of the various taxation Acts. He made no pretence of being interested. That seems to be the style of the present Treasurer, because he does not deign to seek carriage of his own legislation in this place.

Without inflicting unfair criticism on those people the Treasurer delegates to do the job in this place, in my experience, those delegates do not understand the legislation. When we first debate the measures in the House, the Minister representing the Treasurer in the debate merely parrots the views of tax officials in the advisers box, or ignores the criticisms and proposals of the Opposition. Our criticisms and proposals, as evidenced by these amendments, are meant to make the legislation work. They were not, when first discussed in this place and subsequently in the Senate, part of a political point-scoring game. We merely wanted the legislation to achieve what the Government said it wanted to achieve, yet it had to go to the Senate.

I appreciate the role that the Senate as a House of review performs. In this context it is entirely due to my colleague Senator John Watson that we have 17 amendments back here which are intended to, always were intended to, and will, make the legislation work. In other words, through the agency of Senator Watson we are making good legislation out of bad for the Government. That would be all right if we got credit for it. That opportunity should also be given here. Senator Watson is virtually a one man committee on taxation in the Senate. On this occasion, if not for the first time then certainly better than before, he appreciates the detailed responses he got to his detailed questions in connection with this legislation.

It is encouraging to see that the Australian Taxation Office is taking the concerns of the Opposition seriously, even if the Government and its Ministers are not. I join Senator Watson in expressing appreciation for the work of the Tax Office advisers who have assisted in getting this legislation into some sort of workable shape.

The other important thing to note is that, by having this legislation referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, the clarifications given by the Tax Office have some force which would otherwise not be the case. As far as they are recorded in the proceedings of those meetings, they become binding administratively on the Taxation Office in accordance with the provisions of the Acts Interpretation Act. That will add to the value of the work of Senator Watson as well as making the compliance with tax legislation by practising professionals in the tax field and businesses that much easier.

Part of this legislation and these amendments deal with depreciation. I just want to make the point that the depreciation measures covered in this legislation were first announced in the March 1991 industry statement. Here we are 12 months later discussing the legislation to put the Government's announced intentions into effect. Furthermore, on the provisional Notice Paper we had another taxation Bill to further amend depreciation allowances arising out of the `One Job' statement made earlier this year. Not only has the Government's intention stated in March last year not found legislative form, but we are already changing that before the relevant legislation goes through the Parliament. We are now in the stage of discussing further changes in depreciation. The Government's tinkering with that aspect of tax law does not bear dwelling on.

During the second reading debate and the committee stage, I personally canvassed very widely the serious concerns and telling criticisms of the legislation which came from the Taxation Institute of Australia. Some of that surrounded the latitude of discretion being conferred on the Commissioner of Taxation. I think that might be partially dealt with in these amendments, but the Government might have gone a good way further to simplify the Acts and the intentions of the provisions so that people might comply with them without running the risk of incurring the wrath or, more importantly, the penalties imposed by the Commissioner of Taxation for failure to comply 100 per cent.

I repeat that I derive great satisfaction from the fact that we are dealing with 17 amendments to the legislation, which could have been dealt with in this place, because my colleague Senator Watson, a member of the Liberal-National Party coalition, was the driving force behind them. Had he not acted as he did, I suspect—as we have seen in other cases—that the Government would have taken up to two or three years to pick up these amendments and, in the meantime, thrown tax professionals and others who have to comply with the Act into even greater confusion than has already been forced upon them.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I would indicate immediately that the Liberal and National parties have no objection to the amendments that are proposed in the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill is designed—may I put it this way—to render slightly less objectionable a fundamentally flawed piece of legislation which we opposed at the outset, namely, the training guarantee legislation. Because of that, it is logical that the Opposition not oppose the amending Bill that the Government is putting forward.

PARA.TAB: The Bill effectively widens the eligible practices under the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act to include work experience, expenditure in relation to people on work experience, and it also effects a number of administrative improvements to that legislation. In those circumstances there is obviously no intelligent reason why the Opposition should vote against the Bill.

This legislation relates to the broad issue of training and employment. I want to make some remarks about the training and employment situation in Australia at present, and the training and employment policies of the Government and the Opposition. Let me say at the outset that there is a good deal of agreement between the Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties on many issues related to training. There is no argument across this chamber about the need to have a competency based approach to training in this country.There is no argument about the need to fully equip our work force, or young men and women leaving school and seeking to enter tertiary institutions or the labour market, with greater training skills and training opportunities. Certainly nobody in the Liberal or National parties will be heard contesting the proposition that our society owes to all young people the opportunity to receive reasonable and adequate levels of training, that it also owes to our young people a system which recognises their varying skills and capacities and the fact that not all those who leave school are suitable for training at a university, and that we should offer to young Australians a wide variety of training opportunities. I welcome a number of initiatives over the last few years that have been directed towards more closely relating our training institutions and our training capacities to the needs and the practices of the labour market.

I also welcome the growing acceptance in the broad labour movement of the need to adopt something in the nature of a training or youth wage. Some years ago whenever anybody talked about the idea of a training wage or a youth wage—although for a long time there had been youth differentials in the various awards around Australia—there was an instinctive almost knee-jerk reaction to the effect that it was yet another attempt by some dark forces in our community to drive down the living standards of young people. The fact is that excessively high youth wages have driven young people out of work.

One of the reasons why over 30 per cent of our young people are out of work is that youth wages in this country are still far too high. One of the reasons why young people are denied jobs is that the basic award requirements in many areas represent impenetrable barriers of entry. When I saw the Carmichael report advancing the proposition that maybe in the future young people who were doing a training course should be paid only for the actual time that they spent on the job, I thought that represented an acceptance and very sensible recognition of an obvious fact by a man who had spent years in the labour movement and by the group of people in the committee that he led.

Whilst I do not subscribe to everything that was contained in the Carmichael report, I can at least say that I accepted that particular aspect of the report. I have also acknowledged on other occasions the need to examine the proposition that if, as a result of introducing something in the nature of what Mr Carmichael recommended on that subject, the pay accruing to young people was below the unemployment benefit, we ought to examine a proposition that would at least subsidise the pay up to the level of the unemployment benefit. It would be patently ridiculous to have a situation where there was a financial incentive for a young person in Australia to remain on the dole rather than to take advantage of a training opportunity.

I repeat that there are intelligent areas of bipartisanship so far as training is concerned. It ought to be, as far as possible, an area which is freed—I stress `as far as possible'—from partisanship because all of us are concerned about the daunting responsibility of providing job opportunities for young Australians, particularly against the background of a youth unemployment level which is now over 30 per cent.

One, of course, cannot glide over the training guarantee administration legislation without remarking that the financial and constitutional device which has been used to extract the levy on this occasion is exactly the same as the financial and constitutional device which is proposed to extract the levy in relation to superannuation. Basically, what the Government says in this legislation is the same as what it says in the superannuation guarantee legislation. It says that unless one makes the payment—or, in the case of the training guarantee legislation, unless one makes the training available—an additional tax will be charged.

Given the publicity which the superannuation guarantee legislation has received in recent days, it is instructive to remind the House again of the conclusions of the Federal Treasury which were submitted to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation inquiry on the superannuation legislation. Those conclusions were to the effect that, unless the levy replaced wage increases or other increases in emoluments, it could result in job losses of up to 100,000 people over a period of five years.

It is an extraordinary paradox, it is an extraordinary contradiction, it is a very strange irony indeed that, at a time when we have an unemployment level of over 10 1/2 per cent and a youth unemployment level of over 30 per cent, there is general agreement right across the political spectrum that the issue which most concerns Australians, most concerns Australian families, most worries Australian parents, is of course the issue of job security. It really is an extraordinary irony that the Government should be pressing ahead with a piece of legislation which is calculated, in the eye of its own major economic adviser, to add about 100,000 people to the dole queues over the next five years. It does display an extraordinary insensitivity to the major social and economic challenge that faces Australia at the present time. Of course, the reason why that legislation has been proceeded with—indeed, the reason why the training guarantee amendment legislation, or the original legislation, was proceeded with—is to discharge what can only be described as a broad ideological commitment to centralised direction in this area of the labour market.

We all believe in superannuation. We all believe in adequate training. The view of the Government is that we should extract it through the fiat of the industrial relations system using the taxation power when it comes to superannuation, and in relation to training we should extract it through a training guarantee approach which contains many fundamental errors. As was made plain in November of last year, when the Opposition's Fightback plan was produced, one of the seven taxes that will be abolished under the coalition government after the next election is, of course, the tax which is involved in the training guarantee administration legislation, along with the job destroying payroll tax, the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and the abolition of the Federal petroleum excise which collects about $6m.

I conclude my remarks by saying again that this particular proposal contains an improvement on a fundamentally flawed system. It is the view of the Opposition that there is no good, commonsense purpose achieved in voting against something which will make a piece of legislation, which is fundamentally flawed, slightly less objectionable. For that reason we will not be attempting to deny passage of the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members will be aware following the speech by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the training guarantee scheme is an important aspect of the Government's training proposals and is one which binds employers of large numbers of people into making proper provision for their training. I am sure the people of Australia are aware that training was not always carried out adequately across the board prior to the introduction of this legislation. That is not to say that many employers did not do a very good job of training, but unfortunately they were not always the employers who needed to do the training. As with many things in government and elsewhere, one finds that the people we are trying to educate are the ones who require the education. Therefore, steps need to be taken to lead them in the right direction. That is very much what the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act is all about. This amendment is to improve the application of the Act specifically in terms of the ability of people to undertake work experience and vocational practice, especially high school or post-compulsory students and teachers.

PARA.TAB: The training guarantee scheme came into effect on 1 July 1990, and it requires employers to spend a minimum amount on training. The levy was introduced as part of the Labor Government's ongoing policy of developing the environment necessary for Australian industry to become more competitive internationally by stimulating its commitment to training and thus increasing the skills in the work force. We have had a number of reports to this Parliament and elsewhere in Australia on the need, indeed the necessity, of having proper skills in our work force, even in an economic downturn, so that we can be ready for the time when the economy recovers. Of course, that is beginning to happen now.

Primarily, this Bill provides for changes to the training guarantee scheme in keeping with a recommendation of the Finn report of July 1991 on young people's participation in post-compulsory education and training. That report has been talked about quite a lot in this place. Other reports which have also informed the debate in this area of post-compulsory education and training include two reports by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, of which I and the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), who is in the House, are members.

The Committee's initial report, The Restless Years, which was dated October 1989, considered not only the position of post-compulsory students and their access to training, but also the relevance of the education that they received in years 10, 11 and 12. The other report of the Committee, Skills Training for the 21st Century, was brought down in December 1991.

These reports were, of course, followed in March 1992 by the report of the Employment and Skills Formation Council titled The Australian Vocational Certificate Training System, which is better known as the Carmichael report, to which the honourable member for Bennelong also referred in his remarks. This report made a number of recommendations related to providing multiple, flexible pathways to accommodate the needs and circumstances of most young people in Australia. That is a very important report. I think that the proposals in the Bill today lead us in that direction as well because they allow for a substantive change in the way that training occurs for people under the age of 21 in post-compulsory education.

Importantly, this Bill allows work experience and practice for students and teachers to be included in the eligible training program of an employer. As a consequence, it leads to closer links between industry and education, which is a benefit that I think we cannot understate. This change creates an incentive for employers to provide work experience and practice opportunities, both of which are key ingredients in education and training. Such opportunities prepare young people for entry into the work force and improve the ability of teachers to help their students meet industry needs.

Industry is often left out of the education process; it has been in the past. I do not think we would want to see a return to the point where industry's needs are the only factors that operate in terms of education, but I believe that it is important that the employability of people when they leave school is taken into account. To that degree, the closer the relationship between industry and education the better. We are seeing much more interest in this country now at the level of industry in contributing to schools and to other training institutions not just because of the training guarantee, but certainly partly as a consequence of it. I believe it has helped to a large degree in that regard.

The Bill targets full time students in year 10 or above who are under 21 years of age and undertaking full time courses in most schools and education-training institutions. Students must be full time in order to avoid inappropriate use of the provisions such as employers releasing their employees for part time study and being able to claim their employees' costs as eligible expenditure.

A similar provision is made, of course, for full time teachers in schools and institutions. It is recognised that, whilst part time teachers may have—not necessarily, but usually—the opportunity to improve their position and gain some work experience, that is not always the case for full time teachers who are obviously caught up in one way or another in their role in academia.

The Bill also specifies that there be an agreement between the teacher and the training institution, and the training institution and the provider of work experience, which includes the terms and conditions under which the teacher may undertake work experience. This is, of course, important in order to ensure that only genuine and formal work experience arrangements apply to full time teachers. It is consistent with the aim of encouraging teachers to acquire industry experience and knowledge so that they can then pass this knowledge on to students when they return to the teaching institution. The significance of that is that teachers can be involved in industry, gain work experience and then come back into the classroom and inform the students of their decisions and discussions.

I know some people feel that the same should apply to public servants. That is a matter which is currently under consideration by one of the committees of this Parliament. It is felt that we ought try to ensure that we provide not only a generalist education for our students, our teachers and our public servants, but also that they should have the opportunity, as often as is practicable and possible, to test their experience and their theories in the wider workplace, to inform themselves and to broaden their horizons by not remaining too closeted in any area of work.

As most honourable members would be aware, if an employer does not spend the requisite percentage of payroll on eligible training, he or she has two choices which bear repeating at this juncture. The employer can, using the shortfall statement, pay the shortfall to the Taxation Office—and I suspect that is something not many of them would want to do—or the employer can make a donation of the shortfall to another person or organisation. The training guarantee does not specify to whom the donation should be made, but the legislation does state that the employer must make the donation in order for the other person or organisation to carry out training activities.

In this context, I would encourage—and I hope that other people have already done so—employers to look at community groups such as Skillshare, with a view to providing them with that donation if they cannot think of anything better to do with it. Those groups have an obligation to get community sponsorship however they can, and employers are obviously the most desirable donors. These groups will then undertake training in the community, and I imagine that employers would also benefit from this.

When making the donation to the recipient, the employer must advise the recipient that he or she is making the donation solely for any of the following uses: determining the need for eligible training programs; and/or preparing and reviewing strategic and other plans in relation to eligible training programs; and/or developing, providing, evaluating and administering eligible training; and/or developing and administering accounting and information systems in relation to eligible training programs. One can see that these donations are designed to be used specifically for training, training mechanisms and administration.

As I have said, community groups such as Skillshare committees are suitable for such donations. Alternatively, employers may choose to send their money to a local senior high school which may be attempting to develop training programs. One of the schools in my electorate—which, in fact, borders on your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker—the Balga Senior High School, has been trying for some time to develop a school/industry mentor program or traineeship which, I think, some of the employers in the region may have an interest in.

Its proposal is designed to assist students undertaking post-compulsory education to participate in meaningful and relevant education combined with a significant proportion of vocational activity. That proposal differs from the proposals of this Bill, as the students, whilst allegedly being in full time education, would actually in the vocational sense be part time in the work force and part time in education. This would enable disadvantaged students or people from low social economic backgrounds to create a relevant environment within which to improve their learning.

That is a very good scheme. It is one that has not yet been funded, and I will certainly be attempting to seek assistance from any of the Ministers or members present to try to work out a way to get that scheme funded. There is some doubt as to whether it comes under youth at risk or whether it would fall into the normal sorts of DEET programs. I certainly hope that even at a pilot level a program of that nature could be funded because it very much links in with the proposals contained in the Bill today for the training guarantee.

It also links in very much with the Carmichael report and recognises, as did the Finn report and the other reports of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, that those people who are not currently participating effectively or actively in post-compulsory education are the people from working class or poor homes where perhaps there is financial pressure on them not to continue with education or where the education system, because they do not have a goal of university but have a more practical orientation, does not provide what they think they need. Some more emphasis on vocational training during their post-compulsory schooling period would certainly assist those students. That has been my experience from the committees in which I have been involved and the reports that have come down in this Parliament. I hope that we can do something about a program of this nature and importance.

The teachers at Balga Senior High School ought to be congratulated for having tried so hard over a 12-month period to negotiate this matter through with all the unions and the Government and having tried to make sure that the students themselves and the employers will have a decent outcome.

I am very pleased that the Government has persisted with the training guarantee. I am pleased, too, to see that it is rendering it more relevant through the provisions of this Bill and especially more relevant to those people who are undertaking post-compulsory education but who require more of a vocational orientation than has previously been the case and previously been allowed in terms of the training guarantee provisions. This will encourage employers to look to the younger people, and their teachers to improve the skills and aptitude of those younger people, so they can better participate in the community as continuing employees, and that will be better for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enjoyed listening to the comments of the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen). As the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) stated earlier in his remarks, it is to be expected in this place today that this will be largely a bipartisan debate. We largely agree on the absolute need to raise the level of skills in the work force and the general population of Australia. To some extent we agree on the mechanisms, but at the margin we may have some differences.

PARA.TAB: This Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill is not an obnoxious Bill. It is not a Bill that the Opposition would oppose. But I make the brief comment that the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act itself was opposed by the Opposition, and I will speak of some further opposition to continuing with the Act later in my remarks.

It is important that we recognise that over the past two years a number of significant reports have been brought down, discussed in this place and are currently still under discussion throughout the wider community. They relate to the broad issue of training, which is what we are really here to discuss today. The first significant report was the report by the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which was entitled The Restless Years. It looked at post-compulsory education for young people in terms of senior secondary schooling. It was an important report.

It was unfortunate that the Minister at the time did not respond to that report for, as I recall, some 18 months. The report had a great deal to offer, and if we today go back and examine it we will find that many of those recommendations hold as true today as they did when that Committee, which was not of this Parliament but of the Parliament before, brought down the report.

Following that report was the so-called Deveson report, which inquired into the training costs of award restructuring. That was really the first attempt to start a major look at TAFE, at our training systems and at what is perceived to be a major problem in terms of structure in the whole ambit of the education system in Australia. The Deveson report said that we could no longer simply rely on TAFE for all of our training needs and that, if we were going to be able to afford training for skills in Australia, we had to devolve some of the costs from the public purse down to the individual who would receive the training, to the State governments and to industry.

Following the Deveson report, the Employment and Skills Formation Council, under the direction of Charles Halton, brought down a report essentially into entry level training. It established a mechanism for discussing what sort of a system we should eventually evolve that will supply the training necessary for young people to enter the real world of work.

Following that report was the now very well-known Finn report, entitled Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training. The Finn report set targets for the first time for participation in skills training and in all manner of education by our young people. It is a very important document. The Finn report will remain current, I am certain, for a substantial period.

Following the Finn report, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training brought down a report entitled Skills Training for the 21st Century. We consider that this is a most important report because it follows on the work of Deveson, Halton and Finn and the earlier work of the Committee itself. It attempts to bring together information regarding all of the issues that we believe are pertinent to how we should go about restructuring the training side of the education bureaucracy, the education systems in Australia. So it is an important report.

I am personally disappointed that that report has not received the attention in the education circles, the bureaucracy or the press that one might have hoped it would generate. It took some 18 months while we travelled around Australia and discussed training issues not only with the bureaucracies in the various States and in Canberra, but also, more specifically, with industry, union representatives and employers and employees on work sites. We covered a great range of issues that are most important, some of which I will cover briefly in my remarks today.

Following our report is the Carmichael report, which inquires into the mechanisms that we will use to get young people actively into the work force and to change our basic entry level systems from our current apprenticeship and traineeship systems into something quite different.

Yesterday Mr Deveson brought down a second report, this time not a Federal report but a report of the State of Victoria. Mr Deveson is the Chairman of the Training Council of the State of Victoria. This second report attempts to pick up some of the recommendations that we have made and some of the recommendations of Finn in structure, in how we balance general academic education in our high schools and/or in TAFE, and how we physically accomplish that in terms of the VCE in Victoria.

All of these reports go to address our overall national problem of an insufficient level of training. We have all agreed that our young people have too few mechanisms to continue their vocational training. We agree that we have done a terrific job over the last decade of encouraging young people to continue in education, so that participation rates in secondary schools today are quite high compared with the 1970s and the beginning of the 1980s.

For a whole host of reasons Australia has decided that education is important. Those reasons include the fact that our economy has been opened up to a large extent to the world so that some of our previous attitudes, which were developed behind high tariff walls and behind an attitude of protectionism, have been blown away; the cobwebs have disappeared in the winds of change that have been swept up by our internationalisation. That is very positive. It has encouraged people to understand that without high levels of education and without good training skills we are unlikely to be so competitive in a very competitive world; that we are unlikely to be able to take our place in international debates and discussions without the same level of education as the people that we are discussing issues with.

These changes of attitude are important. They have helped our young people go to school. Part of the reason for the increase in participation is our severe recession today. Part of the increase is due to a bureaucratic or financial change in terms of providing Austudy for senior secondary students. It really comes together to mean that people have accepted the need for education and training. But what we have not done is provide the mechanisms nor the desire for that same level of participation in skill acquisition, in what we call training, as we have in general education, which leads young people to diplomas in secondary schools and entry into university for university degrees.All of these reports attempt to address that major structural problem because we do not compete with our OECD partners when it comes to skill acquisition.

The Training Guarantee Act was established by this Government for very positive reasons. I acknowledge that the Minister had in his heart the right desires when he brought down the Act. But it is my view that any act of compulsion is an act which, ultimately in a free society, must fail. For my own part, I would have us encourage employers to increase the training of their work force and I would have us educate employers to the need for training and the benefits of that training both in a social sense and, more particularly, in an economic sense, because certainly it has been proved time and time again that things such as quality, productivity and job interest are significantly enhanced with higher levels of skill acquisition.

One thing that has kept us behind in that respect has been our archaic, centralised industrial relations system. That system itself has tended to say that only an electrician can change a light bulb, and only a plumber can change a tap washer. We all agree that today in this world of competition we can no longer afford those kinds of attitudes and those sorts of inefficiencies. So we talk about training systems today that are broad-based in nature. We need to encourage employers to take up efforts to train their work force. But compelling them to train their work force will not necessarily achieve the objectives we desire.

I would point out to the House the fact that many groups of employers reported to our Committee that they have actually reduced the amount of real training they are doing with their personnel because of the extreme costs of record keeping associated with this Act. In particular, the retail trade, which is a huge business, as one would know, and which is a huge training market, has found that the cost of record keeping is so high that it has had to reduce the training of employees in order—in this time of recession—to keep its costs at a level to allow it to make even meagre profits.

There have been many reports in the press of rip-offs and rorts under the Training Guarantee Act with the use of mechanisms such as boat trips and conferences overseas for management which fulfil the taxation requirements of the Act but which do not fulfil the intent of the Act. This is, after all, a taxation measure. It is a measure which says that if companies do not fulfil what we say are their obligations for training then they will pay a tax; that tax is not tax deductible. From my own viewpoint, I would say that, while the Act has been to some extent successful in that it has tended to market the need for training, it has been unsuccessful in that much of the additional training has been developed in areas which will not serve our future needs, and always, as a philosophical matter, compulsion is doomed to fail.

The issue that all of these reports address is one that we should consider here today—senior secondary schools. In the last decade in many parts of Australia we had schools which attended themselves to vocational training; we called this streaming. Some proportion of the student population was directed into academic schools, where they studied a broad range of curricula and came out, theoretically, as well-rounded individuals with an ability to think and a further ability to learn. Some students, for whatever reason—it could be that they liked working with their hands or thought they would like to be a plumber, a carpenter or a bricklayer, or because they were not particularly good at academic pursuits—were directed into vocational or technical schools.

Ultimately, Australian society decried that streaming and said that it did not serve us well; that it really made out of the training market a second class education market for second class people producing second class results. So we got rid of our training schools and, in the process, we put ourselves at the bottom of the OECD in terms of skill acquisition and providing skills training for our young people.

One of the things that our Committee has found—and this latest Deveson report finds, and I am certain Carmichael and Finn both support—is the concept of senior secondary schools where we go back to a bit of streaming again; that is to say, students in a school are allowed to take a path towards general education or take a path towards vocational education with certification of their skills which they can use in industry when they leave what we call high school. This opportunity provides students with the chance to move back and forth between the two, so that a young person studying hairdressing in years 11 and 12 might also take a history course or a philosophy course or a course in journalism, and a student destined for Melbourne University or Sydney University to study law or medicine might take time out of their year's study and do a course in drafting or a course in carpentry, or they might take a small course in hairdressing. These combined schools which offer students a vocational path or an academic path would allow them to pick and choose between one and the other.

Our Committee visited two senior secondary colleges in Queensland, which apparently do an excellent job. The college at Hervey Bay in Queensland has outstanding results both in retention rates and in acceptance of its students in university or in the real world of work. Its students have a very high degree of success in getting jobs when they leave, if they wish jobs, or in going on to further education in university or further training in TAFE, if that is the direction in which they wish to go. These schools are based, as we hope all other training systems in Australia will be based in the not too distant future, on an attitude of competency rather than a strict requirement for time.

As we have pointed out, the apprenticeship system is a nonsense in that it is based on a master-slave relationship, which we gave away a long time ago. In terms of training, the apprenticeship system is based on time. Apprentices spend four or five years and, regardless of whether they learn anything or pass the course, they come out at the end as a plumber, carpenter, bricklayer or whatever it was that they intended to be. That system served us well in the past. Today is not the past and we do not have master-slave relationships.

Today, people on all sides of politics and throughout the bureaucracy agree that we must rapidly move to a system of competency-based training which allows young people particularly to advance through the training system at their own pace, in their own time, and to achieve real outcomes in the world of work at the earliest possible opportunity. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter the debate on the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill with some background in this area. The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) mentioned electricians once or twice in his contribution. I served an apprenticeship as an electrician and went on to teach in TAFE. Having that background, I am very encouraged by many of the things that are happening. I want to take issue with a few of the points the honourable member made, but in general terms I think most of what he said would find favour with many Government members.

PARA.TAB: In general terms, compelling people is not the best way to get them to do things. Good management is all about getting people to do things willingly. In an ideal world, that is what would happen. But when we are talking about changing attitudes, entrenched as they are in Australia and Australian management, sometimes we have to compel people to do things, such as with the training guarantee levy. The training guarantee levy would, with all factors taken into consideration, lead to those attitudes changing faster than they otherwise would.

After the introduction of the training guarantee levy, a headline in the Australian Financial Review on 29 April this year said, `Levy lifts training spending by $700m, but Australia still lags'. The fact that the levy led to an extra $700m being spent on training seems to indicate that without the training guarantee levy, the training effort would have been that much less. I do not know the veracity of those figures. Nobody put a name to the article. If we take the article at face value, even if the figure is out, the levy has lifted the training effort in Australia, and, from the Government's point of view, it certainly has been a success.

I agree that we need to encourage and educate employers, as the honourable member mentioned. I think that is happening now that we are competing with the world and we look at how other countries operate and how other management systems work. The honourable member made a point about record-keeping instead of training. I can imagine that people would say that. I can imagine that before any committee there would be employers saying that they did not like to keep records for the Australian Taxation Office. But we have to wonder about how they are running their businesses if they do not know where their money is going. It seems to me that they are comparing the way they run their businesses now with how they used to run them before.

In Australia many businesses fail because proper records are not kept and moneys are not accounted for. If the training guarantee levy has forced some firms to be more stringent in their bookkeeping than they otherwise would be, that is a good thing. Not only will they benefit from that in the long run; they might find their businesses improving as a result of that better bookkeeping.

As I said, I did an apprenticeship in the 1960s. I know all about apprenticeships: being indentured to a company, serving that company and coming out as a tradesman. In the past it has served us well, but I agree with the honourable member that there needs to be a broader approach. It is the old catch-22 situation: people do not get training unless they get a job, and it is very hard to get a job, especially in times when the economy is either recessed or in a slowdown. In general terms, the importance of education in Australia has never been taken as seriously as it should have been.

From my experience in TAFE, I know that TAFE was born out of the Kangan report in 1974, which was introduced during the term of the Whitlam Government by the then Minister for Education, Mr Beazley. I suppose that there is some sort of irony in the circumstance that today his son, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), is the Minister in charge of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill.

The Kangan report was the first report that looked at training, which I think was always considered the poor relation in vocational education. It never had a central focus. In the old days it was said that everybody knew what primary and secondary education were about and everybody knew what universities did, and all the functions not covered by those two umbrellas fell into what was then called `tech'. The Kangan report was the first report that looked at lifelong training. It was the first report that seriously looked at the way in which we should position ourselves in the world. It said that training should not be undertaken just once—for example, by doing an apprenticeship and then stopping; as technology moved on, education had to move with it. Back in those days the retention rates were very low—around 30 per cent.

When I was working as an electrician, most of the electricians that I worked with were not locally trained. Most of them came from overseas. It seems to me that back in the 1960s and 1970s migration was the way we skilled Australia. Rather than developing our own skills, we imported our skills. Comparisons with any other countries that are doing better than Australia point to the obvious fact that those countries skill their own people rather than rely on importing skills from overseas.

That system reflected the view of the governments of those days. The education system was a good barometer as to how the governments of the 1960s and 1970s viewed Australia. The industry of Australia was basically very small. We were content to dig up rocks and send them overseas in the form of unprocessed minerals and buy them back again as finished products. We did the same with agricultural products. I suppose the education system of the day matched the industry that existed at that time.

Since this Government has come to office, there has been a dramatic change in attitudes, an opening up of the Australian economy, and a priority given to education. Not only are the retention rates approaching 80 per cent, up from the 30 per cent I talked about before; there are also an extra 120,000 full time places in higher education. In relation to labour market programs, the Government has introduced four key reforms: the Skillshare program in 1989; the jobs, education and training package for sole parents in March 1989; the disability reform package in November 1991; and the Newstart program in July 1991.

These reforms have brought Australia's income support system and the labour market training systems together to increase the training efforts for those people. The total expenditure on labour market programs has been increased from $400m in 1990-91 to $683m this year, an increase of 70 per cent in one year. The initiatives announced in the One Nation statement will take expenditure to $870m in 1992-93. This will boost the number of Australians assisted to about 350,000.

In relation to TAFE the Government has already injected an extra $100m over and above its normal funding commitment for 1992. In February this year it was announced that a special package of $33m would be given to boost incentives for apprentices and trainees because of the recessed economy. We normally find that firms will take on apprentices when the economy is at its peak and will lay them off in the troughs. That is usually countercyclical to the actual demand. When we come out of a recession the demand for skilled tradesmen goes up. It is usually the time when firms that have not invested in apprentices during the recessed period of the economy find themselves short.

That $33m will go a long way to making sure that the apprenticeship system and the traineeship system continue to take in increasing numbers of young people so that hopefully their skills will be available when the economy comes out of recession. On top of these measures the One Nation statement defined the Government's commitment to the establishment of a new higher status, better resourced system of vocational education and training, and the Commonwealth will inject $720m over the 1993-95 triennium.

The Opposition, as two speakers have said, does not oppose this Bill. The one thing that is disappointing is that the Opposition has signalled that, should it become the government, it will get rid of the training guarantee levy. We find the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member Goldstein (Dr Kemp), saying that we must increase private investment in training but Fightback promises the immediate abolition of the training guarantee levy despite its acknowledged success in expanded private training effort. An article in the Australian Financial Review on 29 April this year, under the heading `Training market tipped to double', said:

SPEECH.PARA: The industry training market is expected to double in the next five years in Australia as a result of an increase in the training guarantee levy, coupled with moves by industry to increase productivity.

The training guarantee levy is working, the runs are on the board, and we now see that the private training effort looks like doubling in the next five years; yet the Opposition, should it become the Government, will put all that at risk by abolishing the training guarantee levy.

PARA.TAB: I think the honourable member who spoke prior to me talked about compulsion. The one thing we have noticed about the Opposition is that it always likes freedom of choice. That goes a long way to explaining its approach to many things, whether it be taxation, health insurance, superannuation or any number of things. Its approach has always been freedom to choose. Of course, freedom to choose assumes that everybody is equal, everybody can afford to choose, irrespective of the area, whether it be education or health. But people are not equal.

In many cases government intervention is necessary, as it has been in this case. If we abolished the training guarantee levy and said to employers, `It is up to you now; you have the freedom to train if you want to', we would find a significant number of employers—I will not say all—going back to the old ways. That was where they put in no training effort, but were happy to poach workers from other companies that did put in that effort, in many cases just by offering more money for the skills they needed. That is counterproductive in the end. The Government believes that the training effort should be spread across employers, and the training guarantee levy is committed to that.

I welcome the fact that the Opposition will not oppose this Bill. I would ask those opposite to review their position on the training guarantee levy. As time goes on we will find that the initial success of the levy that we are talking about today will become self-evident and, should it become the government, the Opposition should really look at retaining this program. Of course, I do not think we have much to fear about the Opposition gaining government, at least in the short term. Under this Government vocational training has come a long way. We have a long way to go, but I think the Government will be here to see it develop and prosper in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Training Guarantee (Administration) Bill makes a number of changes to the operation of the training guarantee scheme that the Government has inflicted on Australian business since 1 July 1990. The Bill will allow employers to include work experience for students and teachers in an eligible training program for the purpose of the training guarantee scheme. These amendments follow the recommendations of a report by the Australian Education Council Review Committee entitled Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training.

PARA.TAB: The amendments will provide employers with a greater incentive to provide work experience for students and teachers, thereby helping young people to obtain the skills necessary for a successful entry into the job market or, at least, what is left of the job market in the wake of the Government's very own recession, the recession we had to have, the worst recession in 60 years.

The Opposition does not oppose these amendments because they improve the operation of the training guarantee scheme, as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has mentioned. It does that while there are a number of technical amendments contained in this Bill which should serve to clarify the training guarantee law for employers. While the Opposition will not be opposing the amendments, we certainly do not support the training guarantee scheme as a whole. That is one thing the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) got right in his remarks.

The coalition opposed this legislation when it was first presented to the House in May 1990. In the coalition's Fightback package we have committed ourselves to the abolition of the training guarantee scheme as part of the overall tax relief to be provided to taxpayers under that package. Not only will we eliminate this compulsory tax, a tax on payrolls, but we will also eliminate the payroll tax per se, along with the wholesale sales tax and the petrol tax.

Regardless of what the coalition thinks of the training guarantee scheme, it should be pointed out that the whole edifice rests on some very shaky legal ground. Indeed, there are good reasons for believing that the entire scheme is unconstitutional and would be very vulnerable to a major legal challenge. At least one leading barrister, Mr Bryan Pape, has argued in an article in Taxation in Australia, the publication of the Taxation Institute of Australia, that the training guarantee scheme is unconstitutional. He cites three reasons for the unconstitutionality of the levy. First, the scheme does not fall within any of the enumerated heads of power contained in section 51 of the Constitution. Pape argues that the scheme is:

SPEECH.PARA: repugnant to the working of section 51 of the Constitution; it renders the other paragraphs of section 51 nugatory and would potentially convert the Federation into a unitary system of government.

The other two reasons for believing that the tax may be unconstitutional are that the legislation purports to regulate conduct, rather than to raise revenue, and that the so-called tax is, in truth, a penalty so as to compel or guarantee the observance of a law beyond the legislative power of the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The training guarantee scheme has resulted in a situation where the Government has sought to use its taxing powers to penalise what is otherwise entirely legitimate behaviour on the part of employers. It is not necessary to go into these legal arguments against the training guarantee scheme any further, except to note that in this, as in so many other matters, we would be substantially better off if the Commonwealth and the High Court had, over the years, remained true to the intentions of the founding fathers of the Federation in their interpretation of our Constitution.

The training guarantee scheme is an onerous burden on business in Australia, and yet it does little to improve the quality of training activity by Australian employers. The scheme does nothing to ensure that eligible training expenditures are in fact for the purposes of training particular categories of employees, rather than just for training the senior management people who have always been the major beneficiaries of the training expenditure of our larger corporations. Under the scheme, eligible training expenditure can equally take the form of sending a firm's managing director to expensive conferences overseas, rather than for the purposes of training rank and file employees in new skills.

It is interesting that, for the purposes of the scheme, eligible training expenditure can take place anywhere in the world, not just in Australia, making substantiation of the true nature of the relevant training expenditure very difficult indeed. It is hardly surprising to find, therefore, that many Australian businesses and their employees view the training scheme as a rort to be exploited, rather than as an incentive to maximise the extent and the value of their training expenditures.

At the same time, however, the training guarantee legislation represents a minefield for employers in meeting their obligation to spend the equivalent of one per cent of their payrolls on so-called structured training—thereby the accusation which we fairly level that this is simply another payroll tax on top of the existing payroll tax levied by the States. The training guarantee levy is to rise again to 1.5 per cent in the near future.

There is enormous uncertainty as to what qualifies as eligible training expenditure for the purposes of the scheme. This has resulted in many employers resorting to spending their scarce funds on known eligible training expenditure that may not be entirely relevant to their needs, rather than taking risks with more relevant training expenditure that may not qualify as a result of a subsequent audit by the Australian Taxation Office. In other words, eligibility considerations override commonsense and relevant training requirements.

This is part of a wider problem with the training guarantee scheme, which is that it takes no account of the needs of individual firms, much like our archaic system of industrial awards and centralised wage-fixing system. The Government presumes that it knows better than the many firms that are affected by the scheme as to how they should best spend their training funds. It should be obvious that for many firms the expenditure of the equivalent of one per cent of their payroll on structured training may be totally inappropriate to their identifiable needs.

Businesses may have urgent priorities in other areas of potential investment that they will now be unable to meet because they will be required to spend their limited funds on structured training. Thus, important investment opportunities may be missed due to the need to fulfil obligations under the training guarantee levy. The scheme also ignores the fact that many firms do not, or would not, choose to allocate their training expenditure on an annualised basis. For many firms it would be most profitable to spend heavily on training in one year, but with little or no expenditure on training in subsequent years while the firm benefits from its initial concentrated investment in workplace skills.

Under the training guarantee scheme, however, such a firm is required to spend the minimum amount each year or incur a penalty. So the firm is forced into suboptimal training expenditure, detrimental to its overall profitability. The training guarantee scheme also completely ignores the fact that formal structured training may be completely irrelevant to the needs of some businesses. Many businesses are far better served by the many possibilities for informal training that may exist in the workplace. Instead, these firms are now forced to spend money on forms of training that may be totally inappropriate to their needs, reducing workplace and overall productivity.

Many firms, rather than attempting to restructure their training activities to meet the requirements of the Act, have purchased expensive training packages totally superfluous to their requirements, such that the additional expenditure on training coerced from businesses under the Act is in many cases simply wasted. Consequently, the opportunity cost of the expenditures misallocated as a result of the training guarantee scheme may be the greatest cost of all imposed on Australian businesses, and the Australian economy, as a result of the training guarantee levy.

That this sort of distortion should ever have been introduced into the Australian economy is bad enough, but in the present economic climate and the worst recession in 60 years, it is nothing short of outrageous. These costs are totally unquantifiable, which is probably just as well, since they are likely to be extremely large in the context of training expenditure in Australia. Not only does the training guarantee scheme detract from the quality of training expenditure in Australia; it also imposes an enormous compliance burden upon Australian business.

It is interesting that under the training guarantee scheme any expenditure incurred in keeping the records necessary to substantiate eligible training expenditure under the Act actually counts towards that very same eligible training expenditure. This means that an employer's training guarantee liability can, in large part, be met simply by developing accounting systems to keep track of the remaining expenditure. Thus, the scheme has generated a compliance bureaucracy that in many cases returns little in terms of increased training. There could be no better illustration of the futile nature of the legislation than that, I suggest.

This compliance burden falls on all firms above the payroll threshold for the scheme, even if those firms have for many years been spending well above the required minimum amount on eligible training. The $200,000 payroll threshold means that 15 per cent of all employers in Australia are affected by the scheme. Of these employers, some 42 per cent, who employ nearly 75 per cent of the work force, already spend an average of 2.2 per cent of their payrolls on training, thereby meeting their obligations under the scheme. But this means that the employers of nearly 75 per cent of the work force must meet the full range of compliance responsibilities under the training guarantee scheme without a single extra dollar being spent on training as a result.

We have generated a vast compliance burden for Australian businesses for the purposes of substantiating eligible training expenditure that was already taking place well before the imposition of the training guarantee levy. The relevant records need to be kept for five years, during which time the Tax Office may require the employer to substantiate all eligible training expenditure as a result of a random audit. The cost involved in meeting these compliance responsibilities alone probably far exceeds the increase in training expenditure that has been brought about as a result of the training guarantee scheme. The training guarantee levy is thus totally counterproductive in bringing about an increase in the quality and quantity of training expenditure in Australia, which is the scheme's stated objective.

It is a scheme that would be more at home in one of the world's few remaining command economies, rather than in a supposedly capitalist country such as Australia. It is regulation run riot. The training guarantee scheme is not only totally ineffective in achieving its stated objectives, it is also conceptually flawed. It assumes that there is some serious shortfall in the amount of training expenditure taking place in Australia at present, or at least that took place prior to the scheme's introduction.

The scheme has its origins in the Government's 1988 discussion paper entitled Industry Training in Australia: The Need for Change, which drew some unfavourable comparisons between Australia and some overseas countries in the amount we spend on training. It is this concentration on spending which so often drives legislation under Labor. But the overall figures tell us very little about the adequacy or otherwise of training expenditure in Australia. They fail to take account of the particular characteristics of the education and industrial relations systems of the various countries with which we can be compared, and that can result in all sorts of anomalies arising in broad aggregates such as those the Government has used to justify the training guarantee levy.There can be no doubt that these broad aggregate figures led the Government to adopt a blanket solution by coercing a minimum level of training expenditure from all Australian businesses, regardless of the relevance of the expenditure to their particular needs.

In order to argue that there is some general shortfall in the amount of money that Australian businesses allocate to training expenditure, it is necessary to postulate some general market value whereby Australian business fails to recognise its interest in spending an appropriate amount on training. As has already been indicated, there is no way of knowing what the appropriate level of training expenditure for Australia really is, even in comparison with other countries. But, more to the point, there is no evidence to support the proposition that Australian business is or was lacking an awareness of the value of training in its productive development and, consequently, the future economic development of Australia. It may lack some of the necessary incentives to undertake training expenditure, but that is an argument for removing those disincentives rather than seeking to coerce the deemed levels of expenditure out of business in spite of those disincentives.
As Mr Barry Maley, one of the leading critics of the training guarantee scheme has noted, the scheme ignores:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the importance, and priority, of establishing competition between enterprises and within the labour market to create the essential incentives for employers and employees to undertake appropriate training commitments. This deficiency is compounded by the centralised award system and minimum wage obligations that inhibit innovative contracts between employers, employees and school-leavers that could act as incentives to skills acquisition.
Does that sound familiar? It is the very reasoning behind the coalition's industrial relations policy and some of the other elements of our Fightback package.

PARA.TAB: If there is a problem with the level of training expenditure in Australia, it is more likely to reside in our antiquated industrial relations system rather than in any lack of foresight on the part of Australian businesses. The training guarantee scheme is yet another example from this Government of the attitude that `government knows best'—an attitude that has been proved so disastrously wrong time and time again and was so aptly described by the late F.A. Hayek as `the fatal conceit'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1992 and to support the notion of the training guarantee levy. It is most interesting to hear Opposition speakers oppose the levy and the training which emanates from that, given their own desire to impose a goods and services tax on small businesses in Australia and in fact force an enormous amount of compliance on them in that regard. However, industry in Australia has failed miserably in its attempt to create a skilled work force which would meet the demands of the twenty-first century.

PARA.TAB: Australia and Australian industry is second last in the OECD countries in terms of training, the quality of training and the level of training which operates within its work force. Indeed, only Greece trains its workers less than Australia. In a country as rich as Australia, this surely is a crime. The area in which industry is involved in training—that is, the TAFE system—has also been proven to be the cinderella segment of our whole education system.

During the last few years the States have continued to ensure that even less money has been spent within the TAFE sector than previously and have provided for even fewer people to train in real vocational and industry based training than has been necessary. The training guarantee levy is a response to that and is a mechanism to stimulate industry's commitment to training. Why do we have it? Why is it necessary? Who is being trained?

We heard all sorts of stories from the other side of the House as to why and what can happen. Indeed, we heard the same kinds of stories when we saw the end of fringe benefits for industry. Most of those people in industry claimed then that the lunches which they had and the kinds of things which were claimed under fringe benefits were in fact training. One of the Opposition members now claims that the training guarantee levy is viewed as a rort, hence in some part the Government is responsible for that. I would say that if industry views the levy as a rort, that is an indication of its own inability to respond to the training needs of our community.

Many of the earlier speakers have taken us through the whole issue of training and the kinds of reports which have been brought out, including the Finn report and our own House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training report entitled Skills Training for the 21st Century: A Report on Skills Training: Apprenticeships and Traineeships.There is no question and no doubt that government, industry and unions alike all deplore the level of training in the Australian work force. It is the responsibility of all of us. It is the failure of industry, in the first part, to take the initiative itself that has driven the Government into pursuing the training guarantee levy. I might point out that many of our large companies spend considerably more than one per cent on training, but a group of companies which employ more than half our work force have failed to spend any money at all on training.

What the training guarantee levy does is provide for training courses that are structured and have no significant object other than training. If we are talking about a training guarantee levy, I am sure that not only industry but also those people on whom the money is being spent need a guarantee that what they are doing is meaningful and worth while. If industry itself cannot decide what it needs and how it must train its work force, it is in a more sorry state than any of us imagined.

What the training guarantee levy allows for is that industries can buy training from some of our very large institutions. It also means that, for the first time in many years, institutions have a marriage with industry. I am forced to cite an example of this from my own electorate, where Toyota has a very large truck factory at which, rather than by a line process, it makes trucks in a stable manner—that is, it has a team of workers who together create and build one truck. Toyota has a very large training component; it employs a large number of apprentices and so on. But what is more important is that Toyota has those facilities there. It seems extraordinary that private industry providing facilities at that level should not find some support for that, perhaps in the public sector, and provide a sharing of ideas and a sharing of worth and so on through both the TAFE system and others.

It seems to me that, as well, institutions such as the Queensland University of Technology have found a way in which to expand many of their courses and to meet the demands of industry through the training guarantee levy. Industries have found that for one per cent they can have the provision of facilities that are indeed very rarely going to be available to them as individuals because they simply could not finance them but, by participating in the training guarantee levy and participating in schemes run by the Queensland University of Technology, they have access to facilities that are first class, to teaching that is first class and to courses that are actually moulded to meet the needs of their particular industry. The House of Representatives Committee was delighted, as are many honourable members in this House, that literacy is one of the courses that can be covered by the training guarantee levy. If honourable members had read the report Words at Work, they would know that one of the great difficulties that have come about in the changing work force has been the impact of the illiteracy of many of our workers.

As we move to skill our work force and move to multiskill and to restructure industry, one of the factors that have made for great difficulties is that many of our workers have not had the functional ability to read and write sufficiently in English to be able to work to the demands of new and changing technology and new and changing structures. I have visited a number of factories where this was recognised. They, of their own volition, have instituted literacy courses for their workers. In any instance, one can see that this is industry responding to its own demands in its own way with its own structured courses. This is what the training guarantee levy offers; not the kind of constraints which we heard elaborated by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher).

Indeed, the kinds of constraints which the previous speakers pointed out are simply not true. The training guarantee levy offers an opportunity for each particular industry—each particular site, in fact—to look at its training needs, to assess its training needs and then to work through those. If they find themselves not in a position to provide such courses and such facilities, then they are in a position to spend some money on them, and perhaps other institutions and other groups within the community who have skills and expertise can do some of the training for them and create a cooperative spirit. So, what the training guarantee levy offers for the first time in our community is a real marriage between industry and government in this training process.

I noted with interest one of the points which was made last night in the Lateline program about the Australian components group, where one of the people on the shop floor noted the various changes in management style which had been brought about, and with it a rise in productivity and, of course, a fall in industrial disputation. There is no doubt—and all the research would show—that a more highly skilled work force, a work force that participates and understands the production and the activities of the company for whom and with whom it is working, brings about considerably higher productivity levels, as well as lowering industrial disputation. Indeed, the last thing that industry wants or needs is a return to the kinds of days, certainly through the 1970s and the early 1980s, when we had an enormous amount of disputation and a huge number of working days lost. In the House the other day the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) pointed out that this year Australia has seen the lowest levels of disputation in industry in 30 years. Surely, at last we have seen industry working in cooperation; industry working with employer and employee working together to create a more viable and more profitable environment.

The training guarantee levy is, of course, one of the mechanisms to enable that to happen. I am sometimes dismayed at the fact that members of the Opposition suggest that we should not keep children at school any longer; it is simply a way of stopping them from becoming unemployed—this is simply not true. The demands of society and of our life now mean that all of us need to be much better trained and much more highly skilled. Since industry itself has failed to recognise this and failed to respond to it, it becomes the role of government. It is not simply a question of government knowing best; it is simply that there is nobody else to do such work or to provide the stimulus to industry to force industry along those lines.

One of the other interesting aspects of this Bill is the provision for work experience for teachers. This certainly arose out of Deveson and Finn, and out of our own House of Representatives Committee report Skills Training for the 21st Century, which pointed out that one of the great difficulties which was occurring within our training sector was that many of our teachers had gone through school and college and then back into the classroom themselves, without having any real knowledge of industry. They were preparing people for a world of work which had changed quite dramatically in the last 10 or 15 years.

This is borne out more dramatically when one recognises that the average age of primary school teachers in Australia is somewhere between 45 and 50. One would have to say that the kinds of experiences which they have had in terms of school and schooling, and a notion of work and the work place, are somewhat different from those which occur now in 1992. Indeed, the children they are teaching will be in the work force after the year 2000. It is stated, and research shows, that over 70 per cent of the jobs that will be available in the year 2010 have yet to be discovered; so an ageing work force in our school system is simply unable to meet those kinds of changing needs.

This Bill also provides an opportunity for teachers to go into the work force. I for one am very pleased to see that—as someone who has also spent 20 years in the classroom. I think it is particularly important that teachers understand very clearly the kind of work force and the kinds of demands that are currently being made on their young charges, and that they have an opportunity to experience the full range and the full sets of experiences, because, let us face it, one of the few things about which we can now be certain in terms of the work force is change.
