The days of people simply having one job, doing the same task year in and year out, day in and day out for 50 years are gone forever. I think many of us would welcome that change.

Many of us, of course, also welcome the up-skilling of our work force. Indeed, members of the Opposition have disclaimed the use of the training guarantee levy for people pursuing qualifications overseas, or some kind of training and training courses overseas. While I for one certainly think that our first responsibility must always be Australia and Australians, there are many factors in the overseas experience from which we can learn. The Scandinavian countries and Germany have shown us that, in terms of educating their work force and creating a system and an environment in which the work force in fact accepts that it must be skilled, it must continue to be skilled and must also participate and should participate in the life of the company in which it works, and that is a very important facet for all of us to understand. One would have thought that the motives for a profit would drive industry to demand a better and more skilled and productive work force. If they are the kinds of values which can be explored and gathered, garnished from overseas, then that is something that the training guarantee levy could and should be applied to.

Might I also say that I think the Small Business Association, certainly in Queensland and throughout Australia, has seen training methods, business methods and processes as one of the reasons for the enormous demise of small business in Australia. Indeed, right in the boom times of the 1980s in Queensland, six out of seven small businesses were folding within six to seven months. That had nothing to do with the economic downturn; that was in fact in boom times. Those small businesses were unable to operate in a booming economy. One would have to ask why. We know why: because their work force was unskilled. They were unskilled, as either managers or people who were able to work in any sort of operation which enabled them to operate in what was a booming economy.

We have to look at that; we have to address that. As I said, the issue has been addressed by a whole range of people, and the training guarantee levy is the answer. Its flexibility and its ability to be used in a whole range of ways means that it is an opportunity for industry to up-skill its work force in a way which it finds most suitable. If that means buying in trainers, if it means participating in a range of group schemes, if it means buying and developing some of its own facilities, this is the way it should go.

If what is happening is, as one of the members of the Opposition suggests, that people are running out and simply spending their money willy-nilly on a whole range of packages which are inappropriate to them as an industry, that says considerably more about the managers of industry than about the training guarantee levy. I am appalled, horrified and totally dismayed that managers and people who purport to be leaders in our community could simply go out and fling money around in some sort of revengeful and spiteful act against the training guarantee levy rather than look at it as a real opportunity to develop skills within their work force, which will bring them profits. One has to wonder about the kind of motivation and the kind of nonsense that is being expounded by some members of the Opposition as to the kind of apparent behaviour within industry because of the training guarantee levy.

Let me say that I have seen some very superb examples of the way in which people have creatively used the training guarantee levy. I have seen examples right through from providing very small appropriate courses on the shop floor to developing literacy skills for people for the first time in their lives. I have seen the development of team approaches so that the ways in which people can become multi-skilled are developed and worked upon. I have also seen the top end of the scale, at which a number of companies have built their own community college to develop a range of skills across their whole industry. So, indeed, industry does, will and can respond to the demands of the twentieth century.

Unfortunately, most of industry seemed unwilling or unable to move down the training path. So the Government needed to introduce the training guarantee levy to provide a stimulus for training and to recognise and establish on the agenda once and for all that training must be, will be and has to be a central issue for government, industry and unions if we are going to take Australia and the Australian work force into the twenty-first century and, by doing so, ensure a healthy growth in profits. Of course, with a healthy growth in profits comes an expansion in jobs. The training guarantee levy is central to that issue. It is absolutely integral that industry see it as such, seize the opportunity and develop a skilled Australia that will take us all into the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill 1992, I must refer to some of the comments that the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) has made. The boom in small business during the 1980s came about because people were out there desperately trying to employ people. But what happened was that, under the Hawke Government of that time, small business was told that interest rates would be coming down in 1984 and again, in 1987, Mr Hawke said before the election campaign that interest rates would be coming down. Of course, this was wrecking small businesses on a daily basis. The Government never gave an opportunity to many small businesses to get off the ground and keep going up. They were kept on the ground because the Government kept on upping the ante on interest rates until they reached the level of 18 1/2 per cent and then up to 24 1/2 per cent in the end for those that were struggling. The harder they struggled, the higher the interest rates went.

PARA.TAB: The Government did create a change; it had got a change off the ground. But the outcome of the change is that some 900,000 people are now out of work. In 1973, there were some 3,000 people who were long term unemployed. Only recently we saw a headline that says that we now have 311,000 people who are long term unemployed. So I say to the honourable member for Forde that, yes, there has been a change. We now have the lowest inflation, which was caused by the recession that we `had to have'; we have the lowest number of days lost at work in January, caused by the recession we `had to have'; we have the deepest recession for 60 years; and we still have high interest rates compared with those of our international competitors.

This Bill does not recognise, and will never recognise, the talents of the individual. The broad brush approach, which is effected by this Bill—I will come to the changes in a few moments—has never recognised the talents of the individual for particular training. That cannot be recognised under this Bill. The Government has a blanket approach to it, from which the outcome will always be failure. It will not be a win. As was mentioned by the honourable member for—

TALK.START.PARA: —Curtin.

—No, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) was very good, and I listened very closely to him. It was the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) who pointed out that in the retail sector there are now companies that have had to reduce the amount of training to cover the costs incurred by this Bill. That was put to a committee, but I notice that the Government has not taken up or addressed that issue in this Bill. It should have been addressed by the Parliamentary Secretaries at the table, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Price).

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) said that this legislation is another heavy hand of government that is entering into the business places. It is exactly the same as the superannuation levy. It is the Government's whole approach of entering into the administration of businesses right across Australia. What the Government is saying is, `We want the opportunity to have a share of your profit to direct it to wherever we want it to go'. It is not satisfied with high taxation rates; it actually wants to enter in. The Government is going to find problems all the way through this, and further amendments will be necessary.

One provision will allow an employer to include work experience for students and teachers in eligible training programs, and others make some less important technical amendments and clarifications. In regard to teachers moving out, there have been some very successful exercises of teachers moving out of their workplace, as was explained by the honourable member for Forde, because they had been to primary, secondary and tertiary education and then moved back into the education industry, if I can call it that. Did the honourable member for Forde say they had no worthwhile experience or did she say they had no real experience of life and, therefore, were inadequately equipped to train the students of Australia for the workplace environment that they are heading into? I think they were her exact words, but I could be corrected. She said, `We have a work force in our teaching community in Australia that is inadequately equipped to train the young people of today who have to go in to face this workplace where some 40 per cent of them are unemployed'. Through this no answers are given as to how that might be corrected.

There have been some teachers who have actually moved into industry and been very successful in the education programs that they have introduced into companies, and then have applied for leave of absence for one year and actually not gone back into the education industry. They found out that there was another world out there; there was a world for them to tap. In my opinion, we have actually let our teachers down to a great degree in Australia over the last 10 years. On a popularity rating, I think they come somewhere down near politicians—which is very unfair on them, I am sure.

Having some experience with people who have come to my business for work experience, I believe that what the Labor Government has missed in this Bill is that people have been training young people for a long time in businesses throughout Australia. It is not the way the Government would like them trained. There are people who—I talk about individual application to work—come from school into businesses for a two-week period or even a week and get a bit of vision about where they might like to be when they enter the work force. Some come into our retail establishments and may decide that they are not particularly keen on being in the retail industry. Therefore, that gives them an impetus and a vision to go on to either higher education or other things. It gives them a little snippet of what the world is like when they have to actually pay for something out of the profits and they have to make a contribution on a daily basis to the operation of that business.

The Opposition does not support this Bill because it is a further impost on business. The training and the administration that is tied up with it make it like the superannuation levy legislation which the Government has introduced. It is very similar to the WorkCare program in Victoria, which is another impost on business; and it is very similar to the payroll tax we pay, which is a tax on people who want to work and a tax on people who want to increase the size of their work force. But they do not increase their work force, and there are a number of reasons why they do not do that. Land tax is another impost on business which is affecting Victoria particularly badly at the moment. There is also the bank accounts debit tax and the high tax on employees, which reduces the ability of businesses to reinvest.

But I think the comments of the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) today were the pits. She said, `If you can't spend this money in your own business, then give it away'. I come from the small business sector, and I cannot remember a time, in any of my businesses, when there was extra money to fling around. If there was extra money to fling around, people actually tried to employ somebody from their community; they took the opportunity to employ somebody else and build up the business or reinvest or expand into new lines. The honourable member for Cowan said that, if people cannot spend the money, under the Government's program detailed in this Bill they have the opportunity to turn around and give it to somebody else.

The honourable member for Forde said that businesses should give the money to teaching institutions. The honourable member for Cowan said that there must be some set-up which could be fitted into the Act whereby people could give their profits away. What a great idea! That is terrific. The Government comes in and tells a business how it will spend its money. This must mean that every business will be guaranteed a certain profit each year. Will businesses be guaranteed certain profits each year because of all of these levies and imposts? I do not think the Government has thought about that for one tiny moment; but this is its view.
The Bill affects not only businesses, which I am fully aware of, but also other institutions—such as hospitals—in my electorate. The Bill covers such institutions as hospitals—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are untrained, are they?

—I am not saying they are untrained. In fact, the local Westernport Memorial Hospital at Kooweerup was doing considerable training before this levy was introduced. It is still doing that training, but now a bevy of literature comes to it seeking dollars from the health industry. The Government has created a whole new training industry. People are thinking up ways of how they might get hold of training dollars. If that is the way the Government wants to create new businesses, that is fine; but let us see what the outcomes are. I know that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, who is at the table, knows all about outcomes. If there is an outcome here, it is that we have created a bevy of businesses which are trying desperately to get their hands on dollars from the health community. That has been forced upon them by this levy.

PARA.TAB: The administration of the levy in hospitals was described to me as `challenging'. Honourable members should remember that hospitals have administrative areas and they have reporting procedures in many areas. But this levy was described as `challenging'. The chief executive officer to whom I spoke was being very careful with his words because he knew I would come into this House and quote what he had said. So he used the word `challenging'. But it sounded tongue in cheek when he said `challenging'. In other words, it is a huge effort for that hospital to report on the training it gives its staff.

That is reflected through all of the hospitals in my electorate and, I dare say, those in the electorate of the Parliamentary Secretary at the table. I suggest that the Parliamentary Secretary ring the hospitals in his electorate and ask them how they are affected by this Bill. He will then find that, perhaps because of the imposition of the training guarantee, they have actually reduced the amount of training they are doing as well. There are hospitals which have not been doing any training to this time, and they are now having great difficulty conforming.

Worst of all, in Victoria businesses can say, `Well, this will come out of the profits, so we will make 1 1/2 per cent less profit this year'. The Government is decreeing that that money will come out of businesses' profits. We should remember that businesses have to make some dough before they can pay all of these things; they have to make some dough in the first place or they are out the back door.

The Kirner State Government in Victoria said to the hospitals, `Look, you are going to have to take this money for training out of existing resources because, even though we agree with what the Federal Government is doing, we are not prepared to pay for it'. So it gets the chance to say,`There is the institution', but it is the institution and the local people who raise extra funds to keep these institutions going—such as the Westernport Hospital and the Kooweerup Potato Festival Committee, which had a great year this year and will raise another $30,000 for the hospital—who will actually pay the impost of 1 1/2 per cent. That is very unfair. The Victorian Government has stepped away from the obligation to fund it, as the employer in a business is obliged to do.

I cannot respond to the Bill without getting down to the crux of the matter. I have to mention my electorate of Corinella when it comes to this Bill. The great disgrace of what has happened—I think I have mentioned it before, but I want to refer to it again today—is that when I was elected in March 1990 some 2,288 people were unable to find work in my area. In March 1992, 10,961 people are unable to find work in my area.

TALK.START.PARA: —An increase of 8,000.
—Yes, an increase of 8,000. That is 361 persons each month.
—All because of the Bill?

—It is part of it. The Government fails to understand that it is its continued imposts time after time which contribute to this situation. The Government has been given a plan that we have called Fightback which could begin to address these matters. I do not know why the Government has not had the strength and the intestinal fortitude to actually look at the Fightback package prepared by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and fully implement the guts of it. At least it returns the opportunities for jobs. In 24 months, a staggering 8,673 people in my electorate of Corinella have lost their jobs. Those people have names like John, Robin, Peter and Bill. There are dads who do not have jobs and there are children who do not have jobs.

PARA.TAB: This brings me to my next point. This week in the newspaper Geoffrey Barker talked about the difficulties that have been faced by the Los Angeles community recently and the absolute tragedy that has occurred. He went on to talk about Australia in a similar context. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The black and hispanic mobs who went on a four-day spree of killing, beating, burning and looting provided a chilling glimpse of the fury and the destructive power of deprived and alienated underclasses in prosperous liberal societies.

PARA.TAB: Groups who feel marginalised, deprived of justice, employment, education and opportunity are about as stable as nitro-glycerine. Their notions of personal and social discipline and morality are diminished and, when provoked, they quickly turn feral and mindlessly violent.

SPEECH.PARA: He continued:

PARA.TAB: I am concerned that the persistence of high levels of long-term unemployment—especially among young people—is creating a deprived, alienated and potentially destructive underclass in Australia. I am also concerned at how little serious political attention this problem receives from either Government—

SPEECH.PARA: then, to be honest, he continued—
or Opposition parties.
He went on:

Australia may not have the witches' brew of racial and social unrest that forced President Bush to send the US army to restore order to Los Angeles last week, but there is evidence of increasing personal despair and declining social cohesion as job prospects continue to be bleak and uncertain.
That is the trend line in the Dandenong area. We have not hit the bottom. I report to the Parliament that the increase continues. He continued:

PARA.TAB: Part of the evidence is the increasing incidence of serious assault and theft charges against young people. The causal connection between unemployment and crime is not clear, but there seems little doubt in the minds of criminologists and youth workers that there has been a sharp increase in the number of unemployed young people who feel marginalised and who are in furious . . . despair about their future.

Whether or not Australia is creating a lost generation of the 1990s remains to be seen, but a sub-culture of young, unqualified and unemployed Australians is increasingly visible and voluble, especially in Australia's hard-hit, old industrial regions.

SPEECH.PARA: Dandenong is an example—
Social workers describe them as frequent alcohol and drug abusers, destructive, potentially violent and without hope.

PARA.TAB: Less visible, but no less desperate, are the vast numbers of qualified young people who are also locked out of the employment that would give them the experience and confidence on which to build the careers for which they trained. They are entitled to feel deeply disillusioned.
The facts are that the youth unemployment rate is close to 40 per cent . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Is that the unemployment rate we had to have, I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, who is at the table? Is 40 per cent, four out of 10, of our young people the unemployment rate we have to have in Australia? Is that our future? In the One Nation statement from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), did it not say that continued unemployment is expected through to the year 2000 at current levels? Does that mean that he is not going to address the problem that we face as a nation? I remember back a short time ago when there was a riot of young people in the city of Frankston one Saturday night. It was some years ago. The article continued:

PARA.TAB: Ten years ago the Labor Party, just back in office, was acutely sensitive to the personal and social costs of the unemployment generated by Fraser Government policies. Writing in the 1983 edition of `Labor Essays', Ralph Willis, now Minister for Finance, and John Langmore, MP, observed: ". . . unemployment is an important contributing factor to symptoms of social disruption, such as increasing crime, vandalism, mental and physical illness, wife- and child-bashing, marital breakdown, drug addiction, homelessness, prostitution and suicide.

. . . The rest of society is affected too through the increased costs of law enforcement, public health and related social services, and much more seriously through an increasing sense of insecurity, fear, isolation and helplessness.
Today, when its own policies have generated the worst unemployment for 60 years, Labor spokesmen speak in muted terms about the social implications and costs of long-term unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the Parliamentary Secretary: if this is this Government's form of social justice, it is a crime. We have given the Government an opportunity under Fightback to implement changes that can put a halt to the decline in employment in Australia. Previous Prime Minister Hawke, before those opposite exited him recently, said that he created 1.6 million jobs with all the imposts that were on this Government at the time. The time has now come to implement the Fightback package, which would actually create the two million jobs that we say we can create. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr PRICE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise to support the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill. I note that the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent) invited me to comment on some of his contributions. I mention my local hospital, Mount Druitt Hospital. I was chairman of the committee that pushed locally for some years to get the hospital. I was pleased to serve with Bishop Pat Murphy, with him as chairman and me as deputy chairman, for some years on the board. A lack of religious qualifications precluded me from aspiring to be chairman.

PARA.TAB: If the honourable member wants to know what the real problem is at Mount Druitt Hospital, frankly it is that the State Government has closed so many beds. We are down to 160 operating beds, which is the lowest level that we have had for some time.

We are being made to choose between having an orthopaedic service and a gynaecological service at the hospital. It is an awful choice for a community to be forced to make by a government determined to render the hospital capable of not optimising its services to the community. As someone who has always vigorously and publicly supported the hospital, I am concerned about the issue of care and personal attention that staff members provide to casualty and to patients. In my view, it has dropped. I think that is all the more regrettable.

One of the things that Oppositions always do, as this Opposition does with the training levy Bill, is to say, firstly, that Fightback solves everything for small business. Of course, the Opposition does not tell small business that it will not be eligible to benefit from payroll tax abolition under Fightback—that is an exclusive preserve of medium and large business. Small business will have extra administrative costs and, at the end of the day, will be paying a higher company tax rate. In fact, if anyone is the loser out of Fightback, it is small business. I would have thought that the Opposition, at least in terms of `Flexiback', as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is calling it, would be trying to ease the burden that small business will so obviously bear.

The honourable member for Corinella invited me to comment on youth unemployment. In my electorate, I have a particular problem. For statistical reasons, the Australian Bureau of Statistics aggregates the Blacktown local government area with Baulkham Hills. The youth unemployment rate provided by the Bureau—which I am happy to concede is unacceptably high—is about 28.8 per cent. I am concerned about that, but the difficulty for me is that Baulkham Hills and Blacktown are aggregated for statistical purposes. The general unemployment rate for Blacktown, which we are able to disaggregate, is about 11 per cent; for Baulkham Hills, it is 2.5 per cent. Unfortunately, I think the clear implication from that is that the 28.8 per cent figure is very badly understated.

The honourable member for Corinella said that, in his electorate, he had 40 per cent youth unemployment. In no way do I wish to say that is an acceptable figure, but I think he needs to explain how that figure was derived. It was not derived from the percentage of all young people in his electorate; that is, if there were 1,000 young people in his electorate, 400 of them were unemployed. The figure excludes those who are at school, at TAFE, or at university. The net figure that is used includes those people who are either in the work force or unemployed. That is why that figure is much higher. If it were taken over the whole youth population, the figure would be much lower. Having said that, I wish in no way to condone the existing level of youth unemployment. Indeed, it is a real concern of mine.

I thought that, in this area of industrial relations cum training cum vocational training, we could arrive at some bipartisan approach. In fact, I think that it is dramatically important that we do. But I am unable to observe that that will be the case. I think that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is wrong in suggesting that we will reach agreement on these issues. In fact, I think that it will be a flashpoint for the election.

Industrial relations is clearly an area where we have some very fundamental differences. The Opposition seemed to argue the point of golden dialogue, that is, that the only valid form of dialogue is that which can exist between the employer and the employee. Any other form of dialogue is inappropriate, not wanted and should be disdained. It does not address the issue. The Opposition wants to smash the unions, but it says, `Well, look, we are not against unions. It will be on a voluntary basis and they will have to offer services'. It knows full well that its policies will fragment the trade union movement and will render them less able to demonstrate the very point that it says they should.

Another point is that the Opposition really sees economic success in Australia as being through coolie wages. It believes that if wages can be lowered enough, we will have a booming economy. That is so unrealistic. It is not the way to go. This Government is saying that we have profound confidence in the ability of Australian men and women in the work force and those about to join the work force to provide the skill base to trade our way out of our current situation. In fact, we are doing it. That has to be contrasted with the approach of the Opposition, whose only retort is golden dialogue and coolie wages. I think that it is fundamentally flawed.

Another thing that I would like to raise, because it is analogous with the training levy, is superannuation. The Opposition does not talk about its record when it was in government. Maybe it is unfair, so many years later, to keep raising that, but the reality is that the people who had superannuation coverage under the Opposition were public servants and the highest level people in private enterprise—middle management and above—and no-one else.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. M.J.R. MacKellar)—Order! The Parliamentary Secretary! This has been a wide-ranging debate, but I suggest that he get very quickly back to the Bill under discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am responding to the comments of the honourable member for Bennelong, so I wanted to make that point. I think that, genuinely, there ought to be a legitimate debate about national savings which ties in here. Let me point to what happens in Singapore on the issue of superannuation and savings. It has a scheme where the employer contributes—this is in its original form—25 per cent and the employee contributes 25 per cent. This is a massive amount, which has fuelled Singapore's economy. Here we are trying to say that it is all right for all sections of the community to aspire to a degree of security in their old age and, incidentally, help the national economy, yet this is opposed bitterly by those opposite.

PARA.TAB: I do not think that to date the important place that award restructuring takes has been mentioned in the debate on vocational training. If there was one catalyst for change in thinking, it was award restructuring. In the metal trades industry the number of separate awards was reduced from about 300 to 10 and a whole new classification system was devised with the cooperation of the trade union movement and the employers, who sat down and worked through it; there are now about 10 different classifications. If we want to point to a catalyst in the change of thinking, let us put up front award restructuring; let us congratulate the employers and associations involved in it, and let us congratulate the trade unions for doing it.

On the issue of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill, once again we have this approach by the Opposition. Incidentally, I was amused when the honourable member for Corinella referred to the contribution of the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen), who said, `Well, if they can't spend it, they ought to get out'. His point was that he would try to employ someone else. It is interesting that the Opposition never runs the argument that the training provided in all forms of business enterprises, from small to large, is already exceeding OECD averages or it excludes some other acceptable figure or it says that we ought to be complacent and move on.

That is what distinguishes us, I suppose. The Opposition sees it as an intrusion into business. We see it in terms of economic restructuring with employees being perhaps the most valuable ingredients and we see their level of skill, whether it is in a service industry providing service like retailing or in a very highly technical industry, as being absolutely critical. We will move as we have in the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill to say to business that this is not acceptable and that it should get levels of expenditure on training up.

I hope that I am still in the Parliament when we come to the day when we say that Australian business and employees have really grabbed the nub of this issue; that they have moved on so far that they are not only convinced of the benefits of it but also practising it; and that there is no need for this legislation. But, unfortunately, there is. Just as there was need for the superannuation legislation, there is a need for this legislation.

The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) made a very interesting contribution in the area of vocational training. I wanted to spend a little time, by and large, agreeing with him. In my own electorate, I believe that our education system fails students. If I have been associated with two things in this Parliament in relation to education they have been the campaign for the University of Western Sydney and the issue of senior high schools. It is an absolute tragedy that New South Wales is the only State with one senior high school.

A senior high school is of benefit because we have low retention, notwithstanding the increased goals that are articulated about retention—and we have movement there—but it is unacceptably below the national average. Senior high schools allow us to aggregate the number of students in year 11 and 12, and to offer a wider choice in terms of curriculum. Most important of all, we are able to treat these young adults as young adults. I cannot emphasise how important that is.

This has been bitterly opposed by conservative elements in the community, the most notable probably being the Australian Teachers Federation. But there are many examples Australia-wide. Whether we go to Tasmania—it is established as a point of failure for the system, which in reality it is not—the ACT, the Northern Territory, Western Australia, Victoria or Queensland, senior high schools exist. By and large, the senior high schools tend to be orphans within the administration under which they are placed, but they succeed and perform well. Students like going to them and, apparently, that is the biggest sin that the schools have.

The Carmichael report is the first public report. Whilst Finn acknowledged the role of senior high schools, Carmichael is unequivocally in support of them. So they are an important feature in his program of reform. But this program of reform that Carmichael is advocating for us—it touches on this Bill because of the earlier Finn report—is this, and it is very simple: a majority of Australian young people do not aspire to go on to university or tertiary education at that stage in their lives. Yet education Ministers, departments and commissions throughout Australia have this absurd proposition that in years 11 and 12 these students should be locked into a curriculum which is frankly not meeting their needs and aspirations.

Lest anyone suggest that we are going to develop a less rigorous curriculum or testing regime for those majority of young Australians who seek to enter the world of work at the earliest opportunity, that is not the case. But we have to bite the bullet in what we offer them. We just cannot look at one issue in isolation. For my part, I cannot just look at senior high schools as the answer. We cannot just look at the issue of curriculums in years 11 and 12 and open up the opportunities to go on to TAFE.

For the trade union movement and the Labor Party, I acknowledge a most difficult issue; that is, youth wages. Unpopular as it may be, I advance the thought that I do not believe that we have come to grips with it. But we have the potential to come to grips with it on the advice of the recent reports, in particular the Carmichael report, which suggests that we need to merge traineeships and apprenticeships. It also suggests that we need to look further than the concept whereby we go to school and when we leave it we go to work and a little training is involved. The issue of entry level training is just that; one goes into further training where there is work involved. It is a revolution in thinking. It is contrary to our British way of looking at things, but it is quite comfortable with Europeans.

If there is any report that has the potential to alter the outcomes for young people in my electorate and, I would say, in Western Sydney, it is the Carmichael report. I believe that all honourable members ought to be vigilant in terms of this vocational and educational revolution to ensure that there is full support for it.

It is not going to be cheap to implement. Something like $1.2 billion of additional Commonwealth expenditure will be required up until 1998. I say to State Ministers for education that for once in our lives let us not argue about territory and administration but let us focus on who will benefit and whom we are seeking to serve, and let us come to an agreement about issues such as the Commonwealth offer in relation to TAFE. Let us get behind the Carmichael report and look at a brave new world in 1993.

If we do not meet the challenges presented in trying to cater for the needs of the majority of young Australians, we are going to permanently condemn whole rafts of them. Young Australians will not just be three-year long term unemployed but generationally unemployed. We will have no hope whatsoever of breaking poverty cycles, of providing hope and opportunity—career and educational—for so many young Australians.

I reiterate that I support the Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill and its openings in relation to some of the recommendations of the Finn committee. Employers can get benefits by allowing a wider range of participation, whether it be work experience or participation by teachers in the work environment. I strongly endorse that. I also strongly endorse the idea that where industries fail to live up to our expectation, whether they are big or small or middle, there is a legitimate role for the Government to say that we want every Australian in the work force skilled, trained up, performing better, and more productive. I do not see it as an intrusion into business.

As I say, I wait for the day when I can come into the House and say how magnificent the performance has been, and that this bit of legislation is no longer necessary because all businesses recognise the worth of their employees and are spending far above what is expected in terms of training. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Training Guarantee (Administration) Amendment Bill adds to a substantial piece of legislation previously supported in this House but opposed by the Opposition at that time. In terms of the overall legislation, we still oppose it. But we propose to support this particular amendment simply because, in the context of something that we do not like, it at least makes some sense.

PARA.TAB: It is very hard to speak to the very narrow aspects of this Bill without expressing views on the whole concept of this legislation. I am reasonably grateful to the previous speaker, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Price), because he touched on a couple of issues that I already have written down, including youth wages.

The issue concerns the mechanisms by which we achieve vocational training within Australia. The simple fact is that the Opposition has the view that this sort of levy is not the appropriate means of achieving vocational training. I think the evidence that that is so is now legion. It always comes back to one simple situation: the total lack of understanding of how people achieve vocational skills.

I am reminded that the father of the present honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) once said at about the time of his retirement from parliament that when he entered the Labor Party it consisted of the cream of the working class and, by the time he left it, it had the dregs of the middle class. Of course, in many cases that happens to be the dregs of academia—those who aspired to be engineers but ended up union officials in the engineering union, not being smart enough to pass their exams. There is the case of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). He is a good indication of that fact, having taken nine years to get an economics degree and having to be shunted into a trade union between parliamentary appointments.

The simple fact is that these people have not had the experience of operating a business as the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent) and I have. Therefore, they come to this Parliament with the idea that as long as someone sits down behind a desk, that person will learn vocational skills. For the information of the Parliament, I have to say that, to his credit, the previous speaker touched on this. But the simple fact is that I do not care what sort of academic achievements people have; they start to learn vocational skills when they go to work. They can have the most wonderful degrees, such as a masters degree or a PhD, but when they get out in the workplace it suddenly comes as a dreadful shock to find how they will have to operate and what they need to understand. Certainly, that background of academic training will be of assistance, but they will learn their vocational skills in the work force.

As the Parliamentary Secretary indicated, if high levels of academic training are necessary for people to achieve in their chosen workplace—and they certainly are if people aspire to a science vocation or many other vocations—certainly they have to go as high as possible with academic training. But in so many cases the way people earn their living does not require that level of academic training and, in fact, in terms of their achieving the skills they need, it is a downright problem; it is a roadblock.

One of the best accepted rules of learning is that the older one gets, the harder it is to learn. A child learns a language in two or three years; but try learning a second language at 45, or anything else for that matter. Why do we say to young people that they cannot be allowed to learn to do a day's work when they are 12 or 13 and that they have to continue to be trained academically—often in subjects that are totally useless and do not even extend their mental capacity? I think that is what the previous speaker was touching on in his remarks.

I have been an advocate of this all my life. Today I completed a letter to a school in my electorate where the fishing industry is dominant. I asked whether that school would consider teaching skills that are necessary in the fishing industry, just as a couple of other schools in Western Australia are teaching kids air-training skills and to fly aeroplanes, as well as covering a lot of the academic aspects of that, whilst they are 12 and 13 years old. Why are schools not doing that for the fishing industry? I am concerned that I will receive a reply, `The local TAFE does it already'. In my letter I asked: why does someone have to wait to turn 17 or 18 to be taught how to get a job?

I give a practical example of that. I was in that fishing area just after Easter. I had the fortune to go out on a crayfishing boat. Because it was school holidays there was an 11-year-old boy on board. He came from a relative's family and he was just there for a holiday, but he did not have any previous experience. He was given the opportunity to steer the boat. It happened to be a jet boat. Those boats are harder to steer than those with a rudder and a keel.

The kid was having some difficulty and was told to follow the compass. He had no idea of how to use the compass, and at one stage we did a full circle. The fisherman then took control of him and explained what he had to do to follow the compass, and within five minutes that kid could keep that boat straight. He had learnt a fundamental principle of the vocation of fishing in five minutes. How long would he have taken to learn it back at school? He would have still driven the boat in a circle when he first got in. He would have said that the compass does this and does that.

The simple fact is that the Government has got it wrong. How does it measure this expenditure? Basically it has to be external. Business has been training staff for decades, for centuries. It just has not kept records of that independent expenditure. In certain areas—and I have experience in trucking and earth moving—a lot of it was in wrecked equipment as people learnt. There is the guy who joined the local authority, got the opportunity to drive the front-end loader and over time progressed to driving a grader, which was considered the top of that particular tree. The simple fact is that that happened; it happened in local government, it happened everywhere. Suddenly someone says, `We will send them to school and teach them all about that'. I bet we do not.

Let me tell the House something else that is going on and how this expenditure is being justified. I have been a guest speaker on approved programs. With due respect, what does the Government think I taught young people about vocational skills? I was no doubt highly entertaining after lunch. I took note of some the other speakers, some of whom were telling them how to organise their tax affairs to pay less money. Is that what the Government believes is the idea behind this training? It is creating junkets in certain sectors. It is a joke. So what is the Government achieving? Nothing! People were better off before.

The Parliamentary Secretary referred to youth wages. In my electorate I had somewhere between 20 and 50 young apprentices out of work; I cannot be certain of the number. A group of them contacted me and said, `We are out of work because we were apprenticed to small building industry businesses. We want to go back and complete the last year of our indentures so we can become tradesmen and then we will take our chances in the world. We want to do that for nothing. We know our bosses cannot afford to pay us, but let us please complete our indentures'. What did the protectors of those young men, those union bureaucrats, say? `No, you cannot do it'. In response, to some degree the State Government of Western Australia is now picking some of those kids up and paying them at the taxpayers' expense so that they can qualify before their time runs out. Remember that under an apprenticeship they cannot go back when they are ready. What sort of training is that? Why is it that we prevent young people from employment by overpricing them in the market?

From my recollection, there was a time in the hotel industry when we could not apprentice a chef and we were constantly stuck with drunks and no-hopers, particularly in rural areas, because we could not get people who had made a vocation of it. I was desperate for the day I could train some young people in my district to become chefs. Apprenticeships were formally introduced. I think the matter was overlooked by the union at the time, and the first year's wage was $18 a week. I said to my wife, `We do not need an apprentice to help us work, but we should employ one'. We had the qualified chefs in our business to teach them, and teach them well. We took one on and the next year we took another one on. Suddenly the union woke up, made an application to the industrial commission and got those first-year wages lifted to $50 or $60 a week. Of course, it progressed until in the final year I was paying some hundreds of dollars for people whom I did not need to run my business but whom I was prepared to train. We never employed another one. We could not afford it.

We had more growth in the Australian economy in the 1980s than there is total GDP in New Zealand. The place was a wipe-out for nearly a decade. It is now showing some signs of lifting. So what! After eight or 10 years, it is about time. Just simple human pity would require us all to hope that the economy lifts over there. But the notion that it is lifting on the basis of industrial contracts legislation introduced six months ago is the greatest distortion that we have ever heard. Yet this is the place where the Leader of the Opposition denounces Australia's bad attitudes, as he calls them, and where he is disloyal to Australia abroad.

In New Zealand, we had a social experiment by people who believed in micro-economic reform and who placed it before macro-economic reform without taking the two in tandem. They gave us the micro-economic nirvana over there—if you could get through the desert to get to it. The desert was actually negative growth for a long part of the decade.

The Leader of the Opposition has the same proposals here and Australian business is slowly starting to understand what he is on about. Basically, he is about wrecking the place. He has blown in from a merchant bank, where he had been no closer to an industrial negotiation than reading about it in some business magazine. He found himself in here on the front bench of the Opposition and—because of a paucity of personnel on the Opposition front bench—then Leader of the Opposition. Now, as Leader of the Opposition, he and the honourable member for Bennelong—who is one of the guilty people in the Australian industrial relations and inflation equation—want to revisit the scene of the crime. They want to try to do it twice—only this time they want to wreck the whole award system and the legal basis for six million employees.

A few minutes ago we had a question from the Leader of the Opposition about real wages. How do you think he could unashamedly put that question when he has a policy of denuding the legal standing of the conditions and rates of pay of six million people? That is his policy. It has been confirmed today by his spokesperson, the honourable member for Bennelong.

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously don't understand.

—I understand well what you are about. You are about social division and social upheaval, and you are about pitting employer against employee and the consensual approach which we have seen. No amount of bunting will protect you, my friend. Whether it be the flag or the streamers of a car yard, it will not protect you.

PARA.TAB: This man wants to wreck our inflation record. He wants to wreck the national inflation achievement and put asunder, desperately and vilely, the industrial peace which has come by way of the accord. Yet these ideologues opposite—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Corinella!

—sit and say, `Well, look they're up there running the show'. We will see how they will run the show as business starts to get onto what they are really on about and as employees understand what sort of terminal battle they are about to unleash—if they ever have the opportunity.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that on 9 March 1992 the South Australian Government told the Senate Standing Committee on Superannuation that South Australia could not afford the super levy? Is it also a fact that the South Australian Premier, Mr Bannon, has lobbied the Federal Government for an exemption from the levy because the South Australian Government cannot deliver the wage cuts necessary to offset the levy and avert job losses? Perhaps the Prime Minister can explain to the House why the Premier of South Australia is wrong and how South Australia will achieve the wage cuts necessary in order to avoid those job losses.

—The Premier of South Australia has an employer's obligation to meet national wage commitments. It is as simple as that, and I have told him as simply as that. All States wish to diminish costs, and wages constitute 80 per cent of States' outlays. This Government has given the States the lowest wage cost structure in living memory. Yet instead of saying, `Yes, it is all part of one package', the States will always, upon the advice of their Under Treasurers and the rest, say, `Let's slide out of this on the basis that we are a government and we are not obliged to be part of the national wage'.
—So Bannon's wrong?
—On this, he is dead wrong; absolutely wrong.
—Vilely wrong?
—Order!

—There is no way he or any other government will be allowed to get away with this. They have a responsibility to face, along with all employers, and they will face it. The coalition should understand this simple point: only the movement towards occupational superannuation and the building of a pool of savings for self-provision in retirement can possibly give Australians a reasonable standard of living when the retired-age population doubles in about 2015—only this sort of policy. If you want to go along blackguarding it—or, worse, trying to obstruct it or pull it down—you should try to put something else in its place. You have never had the wit to do it in the past, and you would not be able to do it now.

PARA.TAB: You left the tax treatment of superannuation massively tax preferred and, as I said earlier, only there for the wealthy and those in the white-collar areas. You seem to just want to deny ordinary people a decent go. I do not know what is in the psyche of your Party—why you are so crooked on ordinary Australians. I just cannot understand why you are so down on them, why you want to rip away at their award entitlements—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—why you want to rip away at their three or four weeks annual leave pay, why you want to rip away at their superannuation. I can understand you, Ian; if someone walked on your place, you would put the dogs on them. That is the sort of approach you have. That is about the extent of the generosity of the human spirit we would get from you, as we have always had from all of the blue bloods around this country. They have no regard for the ordinary workers of this country and never have had. You have always seen them as cannon fodder in factories. You have never done a thing for them. We have—and it will take more than you to wreck it.

We will tell you later when we come to government'. I do not believe it is likely to come to government because, like a whole range of other communities within Australia—

The other thing that local government should be increasingly concerned about is that the Opposition suggests that under the proposal it will hack back the financial assistance grants to the order of 5 per cent. As I said in allowing the matter of public importance yesterday, I do not think that the relevant standing order should be used to stifle wide-ranging debate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The business sector is really concerned about the effect that the new superannuation guarantee levy will have on it. The small-business sector today is already reeling under the worst recession this country has experienced in 60 years—a recession, I might add, brought on by this Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he was Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: Bankruptcies have increased by 50 per cent over the past 12 months and yet this Government wants to increase that figure further by putting this impost onto small business. Over the period from July 1989, 31,000 small businesses have gone bankrupt. In fact, during the term of this Government a staggering 79,345 small businesses have gone to the wall because of its policies. That does not take account of the number of small businesses that close their doors and just walk away because they cannot make a quid. The Government does not seem to entertain these facts.It reminds me of a joke I heard about 12 months ago. The joke went something like this: how do you get a small business? The answer in those days was: get a larger one and wait. Today that is stark reality. Not only are large and medium sized businesses scaling down, not only are they losing market share, not only are they not making profit, but also they are going broke.

This superannuation guarantee levy will be an increase in costs. There are three things that might happen: either the cost of the levy will have to be paid for out of wages; it will flow on to prices; or it will result in the loss of jobs. We need to look at what industry is saying about this, because the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) is not listening. I think the first important thing we should look at is what the Minister's own Small Business Coalition said. In a submission to the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), Senator Button, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and him, his own Small Business Coalition went on:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is no doubt aware of the concerns of all business that the superannuation levy guarantee is regarded as a massive deterrent to employment and will, we believe, have the effect of causing significant job losses. . . Any review should consider such possibilities as trading off benefits such as penalty rates and holiday leave loadings for increased across the board superannuation coverage to which ideally both employers and wage-earners would contribute.
The Executive Director of VECCI said:

The superannuation tax will increase labour costs by up to five per cent with an estimated 60,000 jobs to be lost in the first year of the tax. . . Jobs will go, companies will go to the wall, taxes will rise. . . and companies will hold off from creating new employment to avoid the threshold where additional superannuation commitments have to be met.
Mr Edwards added:

There will be little or no gains from these economic casualties. . . the tax will simply channel funds which would be available for reinvestment in small-to-medium size businesses. . . The upshot will be reduced investment in business and restrictions on job growth.

This Government has probably introduced this at the worst possible time. The Government is totally out of touch with what the economy is doing and totally out of touch with what this country is doing. I noticed an article about the Australian economy, but more importantly about this Government's handling of the economy, in the Singapore Straits Times of 14 January this year. It stated:
Crisis-hit Australia faces some tough economic decisions.
It went on:

Australia has reached a crossroads in its battle to repair. . . self-confidence and restore some international prestige to what was, only 20 years ago, a credible middle-ranking economic power. The country's decisions over the next few years will determine the economic well-being of Australians to come.
So true that is! Why does the Minister not heed the warning? It went on:

After thrashing around for quick-fix solutions for nearly 10 years, Australians have found themselves back at square one—in a recession. . . The 1980s will undoubtedly go down amongst the most wasteful years in Australia's history.

Look at our proposal to scrap $5.8 billion worth of payroll tax. Australian manufacturers have estimated that that will create 175,000 jobs. Do not take my word for it; take its word on what has been happening as a result of the massive reforms. And they are some of the reforms, I might add, that we are proposing. SPEECH.PARA: Basic labour productivity had improved spectacularly. The number of man-hours required to produce 1 tonne of aluminium dropped 31 per cent and was still declining.

PARA.TAB: The crude cost of labour had declined 17 per cent per tonne for aluminium produced.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is about costing jobs in this country. He is about adding labour costs. We on this side of the House are prepared to get out and argue the benefits of Fightback for this country, for our youth and for our nation. The letter from David Jones, dated 28 April this year, reads:

David Jones employs approximately 10,000 staff throughout Australia and, should we incur an additional 2% payroll cost, we will have no alternative but to instruct there be a 2% reduction in employee numbers . . .

SPEECH.PARA: More jobs lost at a time when we cannot afford it. It goes on:

PARA.TAB: The current recession—

SPEECH.PARA: the recession that the Prime Minister said we had to have, and he said that because he did not have the policies; he did not have the vision; and he did not have the determination to set the economic climate in this country so that our industries and our businesses could be competitive—

has had a significant impact on all retailers throughout Australia and to compound our cost of employment by an additional Superannuation Guarantee Levy is not, in my view, in the interest of creating additional employment opportunities and providing a path of recovery from the recession.

Obviously the Minister and his Government are not listening. The National Australia Bank Quarterly Business Survey surveyed a huge range of business on the impact of the additional 2 per cent superannuation levy. On the question of profitability, the huge majority of respondents in fact responded by saying that they expect profitability to be very poor or poor over the coming months. The huge majority of respondents thought that overheads would fall. They never thought that the Government would increase their overheads by 2 per cent and that that would flow through to the small business sector.

PARA.TAB: The size for small business is 50 to 99 employees. As the Minister may know, that covers the manufacturing small business sector, and he had better read his own report if he does not know what it means. Of the businesses surveyed 52 per cent expect profitability to fall and more than that expect further shedding of labour. In the latest quarter, again another 50 per cent expect that both labour and profitability will continue to fall.

I think we should go on and see what all industry people think. Not only does the Minister not listen to his own Small Business Coalition but it also concerns us on this side of the House that he does not listen to the business sector. He does not listen to all of those people who are out there trying to make it and trying to employ Australians. The Confederation of Australian Industry states:
The Superannuation Guarantee is like a National Wage Increase basically a Guarantee of Increased Unemployment . . .

SPEECH.PARA: What does the Minister think this increase in labour costs will do to the CPI? Again, it is just one more nail in the coffin of our manufacturers that are struggling to become competitive under the Government's so-called labour reform that has not happened. The Taxation Institute of Australia states that this levy `could result in tens of thousands of Australians having their wages cut'. The Institute reckons that people will have wage cuts as a result of this. It further states:
. . . it would result in unwelcome paper work particularly for small businesses . . .
It predicted that many employers, because of the current poor economic trading climate, would in fact shed labour. A media release from the Chamber of Commerce in New South Wales states:

PARA.TAB: "The levy is a direct cost on employment and acts as a massive disincentive just like any other levy such as Payroll Tax. The superannuation levy will cost small businesses nearly $22 billion over the next 9 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat: the superannuation levy will cost small business $22 billion over the next nine years—at a time when it is trying to recover from the worst recession in 60 years. It goes on:

In calling for the super levy moratorium, Mr Taylor said that employers are already buckling under the weight of the Training Levy, Payroll Tax and current award superannuation payments and this is not conducive to job growth.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce said that the message coming from Treasury really is that the Federal Government is hell-bent on rushing this superannuation levy through at the expense of jobs.

PARA.TAB: The problem we have in this country is that the Minister does not understand what is happening. He does not even take the advice given during the Senate Estimates committee hearing. The Deputy Secretary to the Treasury admitted that there was no evidence to indicate that the superannuation levy will in any way arrest the rising cost of pensions. He also admitted that there was very little evidence to suggest that the superannuation levy will result in any significant increase in national savings.

The Minister's whole argument has been blown out of the water; his whole premise has been blown out of the water. By taking costs off businesses—by scrapping the payroll tax, by scrapping $6.6 billion worth of fuel excise, by scrapping $9.4 billion worth of wholesale sales tax, by taking $1.7 billion worth of wholesale sales tax off our exports and by reforming the labour market—we can make our business sector and our service sector truly competitive both domestically and internationally. That will flow through to job growth; that will flow through to stability in employment; that will take this additional labour on-cost away. When negotiating their agreements with their employers and business, employees can then, of course, arrange for a sensible cover of superannuation.

I have received letters from shearers in my electorate. They work for four months of the year, have superannuation taken out of their pay under the award system, then they get a letter saying, `Look, I am sorry, because you have not made any extra contributions, all the money has gone, chum; too bad'. The Government has not even worked out that its threshold in regard to the 18-year-olds would be very detrimental to youth. What does the Minister think is going to happen when they turn 18? If the Government sets a clear path across the board it can in fact create a healthy climate.

We are proposing to encourage people to take out their own superannuation, to give them reward for hard work, to give them a challenge and a chance to save both short and long term. But, more importantly, we are about creating a climate in this country where we do not want to put additional costs on our businesses; we do not want to create any more down sides to employment. We want those one million Australians who cannot get a job under this Government's policies to have a job. Under our policies they will have a job—the youth of this country will have work—and this country and our businesses will become competitive, both domestically and internationally, unlike under this Government's policies.
