SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEDDALL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I enter into this debate on the superannuation guarantee levy. I had to re-read the letter that was given to Mr Speaker about the matter of public importance, because the shadow Minister for small business, housing and Customs, the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), during his tirade, was talking about everything else except the superannuation guarantee levy. I must say, it was interesting. The shadow Minister spoke during the cognate debate on the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill and the Superannuation Guarantee (Consequential Amendments) Bill when they were debated last night in the House of Representatives. We agree on one thing in particular, that is, that we all need to encourage Australians to provide adequate retirement benefits for our ageing population. We disagree because the very reason the Government is introducing this superannuation guarantee levy is to make sure that the six million Australians who do not have access to superannuation will have access.

PARA.TAB: Before I proceed to rebut what the shadow Minister was talking about, perhaps I should mention a bit of history about the superannuation guarantee levy. This levy came about in 1987 when part of an award agreement was made that 3 per cent of superannuation was to be contributed on behalf of employees in lieu of a wage rise. That is, instead of the employer paying the employee cash, 3 per cent went into superannuation. That was a saving to employers because the 3 per cent superannuation levy did not carry the ongoing on-cost that applied to all wage rises. We have to understand that many businesses in the small-business community complied with that, but many did not. As it was only an award of superannuation, many did not have that impost and had the saving of that 3 per cent.

The Opposition uses alarmist tactics. I note that the shadow Minister, in his contribution to this debate, referred to Singapore. He might like to explain how Singapore achieved its high level of success when it has a compulsory 22 per cent rate of contribution to pensions, which is nowhere near what the Government is providing for in this country. The alarmist tactics, in particular, were exposed by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in Question Time today. The Opposition has been referring to a Treasury minute saying that it shows that 100,000 jobs would be lost over the five-year period if the superannuation guarantee levy were introduced. Of course, what the Opposition failed to say, which is the very crux of this matter, was that it was not allowing for any trade-off between wages and superannuation. The Government has consistently said that we will trade off wage rises for the contribution to superannuation so that we do not get an increase in unit labour cost.

This issue has been of minor concern for some time to small business. It is interesting to note that, if the shadow Minister had actually talked to small business, he would have found out that it has consistently said that it does not disagree with a uniform superannuation scheme; it disagrees with the timing. When the business organisations met with the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), as referred to by the shadow Minister, they said, `As we come out of the recession, it is going to be too much of an impost'. So what the Government did, in compiling information for the One Nation statement, was listen to the small business community and take into account what it said. Now it has deferred the introduction of the levy for over 80 per cent of small business until 1993-94, allowing small business to get the benefit of the recovery before the levy is imposed. We should always remember that that 3 per cent is not employers' money; it is employees' forgone wages.

We had to then look at the other issues that were asked for by the small-business community leading up to the One Nation statement. This was one issue. There were other small business high priorities. There was capital gains tax relief, the provision of PDFs—

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to roll-over?

—What happened to roll-over? In particular, the small-business community put two options forward. Its preferred option was an enhancement of the goodwill provisions of capital gains tax. The Opposition does not talk to it. It was actually Stephen Shepherd from VECCI, whom you quoted, who put forward that proposition on behalf of the small-business community.
—It was not Shepherd; it was David Edwards.

—VECCI is the organisation. There is more than one person in an organisation. Apart from that, there was enhanced export access and, more importantly, some provisions for debt write-off with the banks which was, I think, one of most innovative ways in helping small incorporated businesses. In the past, when banks have had to write off partial bad debt, they have had only one option—that is, to totally liquidate the company. Now they can partially write it off or do a debt for equity swap. That part of the small-business debt that is non-performing can be written off, the bank can claim the benefit and the business can continue to trade. There is also additional sales tax relief for the small-business community.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition does not really ever consider the small-business priorities. There is nothing in Fightback for small business, except a new tax. The shadow Minister is always talking about the benefit to small business of the abolition of payroll tax for small business. Of course, it is an absolute nonsense. Eighty-five per cent of small business does not pay payroll tax. As I pointed out in the House not long ago, the Opposition is taking a competitive advantage away from small business by giving the abolition of payroll tax to big business. That is, if one is running a shoe store in a shopping centre competing with Coles Myer where one does not pay payroll tax, the only person in that shopping centre who is going to benefit is Coles Myer because it can then reduce its prices as it is not going to pay the payroll tax.

It is interesting that, even though this MPI is purported to be about small business, the only business the shadow Minister actually quoted was David Jones. I think it has been some time since David Jones has been a small business.

The Opposition's whole miscalculation is that it really does not understand the role and the dynamics of small business. The Opposition thinks that if it has a bunch of policies and it tells small business that it is good for it, then small business will accept that. But that is not the case. This particular proposition, which passed through the House last night and which will go to the Senate for its concurrence, is, I think, one of the great reforms of the 1990s.

We are now an ageing population. No-one denies that. All of us sitting here are part of the baby boom generation. There are currently five taxpayers for every pensioner. By the year 2020, there will be three taxpayers for every pensioner. There will not be enough taxpayers to provide adequate pension facilities. We really have to provide a national superannuation scheme. The Government thinks that the most appropriate way to do this is to ensure that all Australians, not just those who are wealthy enough, are able to prepare for their retirement. If we do not do that we will have a greatly disadvantaged society as we move into the twenty-first century. It is important.

The Opposition has had universal criticism of its superannuation policy. From listening to what people are saying, I understand that the Opposition will have to go back and re-draw it because nobody really believes that it has a superannuation policy. It has been shown consistently throughout Australia's history that, when it is left to people's own devices, the overriding needs of day-to-day living mean that people put off making decisions about their retirement. This is particularly true of young people. We want to get young people into this particular scheme so that by the time they get through the whole of their working life, they will be in the position of having prepared adequately for their retirement.

Young people tend not to think about retiring. When they start work they tend to think that turning 30 is a limitation they will never reach. By providing occupational superannuation and award superannuation, we will have a vast number of people coming into the network and providing a continuing benefit. There will also be spin-off benefits for the small business community which will come from providing such a large pool of funds.

That has been the experience in Singapore. By having a large base of funds available for investment, there is an opportunity to develop the economy. It is clear that the large superannuation pool that has been built up in the Singapore economy has been of enormous benefit to the business community in that country. From my understanding, in Singapore one can either borrow against one's superannuation entitlement for one's home purchase or for starting a small business. That has freed up more money and enabled the banking sector in Singapore to invest in productive investment. I am sure that this will happen here.

In the One Nation statement there is a provision to create pool development funds, which I think is a very innovative way of trying to fill the market gap between debt and equity that exists in this country. The pool development funds would obviously be a very attractive proposition which people could invest in from the superannuation funds.

The Opposition continually says that the Government does not listen to the small-business community. I could not think of anything further from the truth. The Opposition's problem is that it does not even have a policy for small business. The shadow Minister for small business was running around quoting newspaper article after newspaper article. Perhaps I should quote one for him from the May 1992 edition—the current volume—of the Australian Small Business and Investing magazine. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the coalition's Small Business Minister, Geoff Prosser, promised COSBOA to deliver the Liberal's small business policy within three months of our first meeting—
which was on 8 November 1990. The article then goes on to say that this has yet to see the light of day. Nothing condemns the small business shadow Minister more than that particular statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did they say about Fightback?
—They said they do not like Fightback.
—Rubbish!
—How would the honourable member for Barker know what small business thinks?
—Because he told me on the same day.

—Ask what it thinks of the shadow Minister. It is there in print in this month's edition. The Opposition has no policy for small business. It lectures people and does not listen. This Government has a consistent record of listening to the concerns of the small-business community and acting upon them to get an agenda; rather than the broad-brush approach which presumes that what is good for everybody can be encapsulated in this broad-brush policy approach.

PARA.TAB: What is needed are specific policies. That is what this Government has done for small business; it has specific policies. We have listened to and reacted to the concerns of small businesses about the superannuation guarantee levy. They said that they were concerned about the timing, so we have postponed the timing for small businesses. We have consistently said that we will listen to people.

What the Prime Minister has said, what the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has said and what the Treasurer has said is that this is not about adding on to wage costs; it is about making sure that there is a trade-off between wages and superannuation. It is not about what the shadow Minister was saying, about additional costs. Therefore the whole proposition that he put forward is flawed; it is deceptive. He knows and Senator Alston knows that the statement given by the Treasury officials to the Senate committee had a qualification. It said, `These would be the outcomes if they were added on to wage costs'. The Government has consistently said that it would not allow this to flow into wage costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, how is it going to be paid for?

—It will be paid for by a trade-off, by talking between employers, employees and government, by having a dialogue with people—not by just telling people that we think we know what is good for them. That does not work. That is why those opposite are slipping further and further behind. Their whole package is now being discredited because they have a fixation that they know what is best for everyone. We do not get anywhere in this country by telling people that we know what is best for them. We have to listen to and to work with people. That is what we have been doing consistently, particularly in the small business area. There are many examples—probably too numerous to cite here—of that.

PARA.TAB: The shadow Minister kindly refers to the Small Business Coalition as my coalition. It would be nice if it were but it is not. The Small Business Coalition is made up of the Confederation of Australian Industry, The Chamber of Commerce, the Chamber of Manufactures, professional accountants and professional lawyers—hardly a normal support base for the Australian Labor Party. But what it has always done and continues to do is to work with the government of the day. It has continually made offers available to the shadow Minister, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), to meet and talk with it about those issues that are of concern to it. But those opposite do not want to listen. They continually try to put into place an attitude that they know what is best. The honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) said, `We do not listen to lobby groups; we know what is best for them'. That attitude is of no use in developing a cooperative culture in Australia.

I am pleased to be able to contribute to this debate. I fully support the Government's move to superannuation. I know that there is broad support for it in the small business community. It was concerned about the timing, and the Government has responded to that concern.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Before I call the honourable member for Bradfield, I note the presence in the Gallery of the Hon. Frank Crean, a former Minister in this national Parliament. I am sure colleagues welcome him to the proceedings.
Honourable members—Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One has to ask a fundamental question: what is this matter of public importance all about? Principally, it is about the whole issue of whether or not we should have a compulsory superannuation scheme affecting all Australian workers, and specifically what the effect of the current Government's policy will be on small business in Australia. We have just been hearing some interesting views from the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) in which he claimed, for example, that small businesses in Australia basically support the proposal. I have before me the Australian Small Business Association submission to the current Senate Select Committee on Superannuation.
—He is laughing at ASBA.

—He may think it is an amusing matter, but the fact is that this is the voice of a large proportion of Australian small businesses and the issues which it raises are particularly important. I quote one paragraph in particular which states:

SPEECH.PARA: There is absolutely no encouragement under the present system for employees to invest in tax deductible superannuation if they are on a marginal tax rate of 30% or less as their tax saving is offset by losing 15% of their contribution in the fund and being taxed at 15% on investment in the fund. The tax deduction only favours high marginal rate taxpayers who tend to have access to superannuation rather than lower paid employees.

This is precisely one of the fundamental distinctions between the Fightback policy of the Opposition and the current ramshackle shambles of a policy put forward by the Government in the legislation introduced into this House yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The fundamental fact which the Government refuses to admit is a statistical one, and it is this: the current taxation arrangements give the top end of town about 32c in the dollar tax support on every superannuation dollar, whereas the average person at lower levels of income gets as little as 6c in the dollar. The fact of the matter is that the workers in small business are precisely the sort of people who get nothing at all out of the current Government policy, and regrettably they will not in future.

The Minister told us earlier in his usual platitudinous tones that the Government is really about helping everybody in retirement, that we have an ageing population and have to be conscious of that, and that all of us should contribute to superannuation so that we will have a higher living standard in retirement. Amen to most of that. But let us look at the facts as distinct from the mirage which the Minister has been putting to us. The reality is simply this: the average lump sum pay-out at the present time is approximately $50,000. Anybody who bothers to look up the assets and income test for access to the age pension will have no difficulty in finding that people on that level of lump sum pay-out will be beneficiaries of the full pension.

Let us go another step further. Let us raise the grounds of this argument. Even at levels of $100,000—for the benefit of the Minister that is 100 per cent more—the fact of the matter is that people will also qualify at least in terms of the assets test for access to the part pension. The point I am trying to make is simply this: the Minister can play around with the superannuation system until the cows come home; he can force everybody to come into his system for as long as he likes. But the sad reality is that, if the basic principle of his policy is that those people should be free of the welfare system in their retirement, he will have to rip apart the existing welfare system. Perhaps that is part of the hidden agenda of the Labor Party if it wins the next election. I can assure the Minister that there is no way he can square this circle, because the simple mathematics of the exercise do not add up.

My colleague has already pointed out that in terms of small business the capacity to stay alive economically is vital. It is fundamental at the very time when bankruptcies have increased by over 50 per cent and when over 31,000 small businesses are no longer in existence because they have been declared bankrupt. A total of 79,345 small businesses have failed—and that is the ones we know about. God knows how many we do not know about.

It has been said in this House on many occasions that, if every small business were able to employ one additional worker, effectively we could control, if not overcome, a large measure of the unemployment brought upon the Australian people as a result of the gross economic failures of the Hawke and Keating governments. It is this group of people in our community who are prepared to get out and have a go which will ultimately determine the economic strength of our economy.

We had discussions earlier about the whole question of the Treasury estimates. The simple fact is—if the Minister wishes to read the document, I have it here; I am happy to give it to him—Treasury puts forward essentially two scenarios. Under both of those scenarios there is a loss of jobs. The principal point that we have been trying to make about this whole proposal is that it is flawed. It demonstrates a fact that we know so well: this Government is more interested in making a deal with the ACTU which will give it absolute and ultimate control over the last segment of the private sector over which the ACTU has very little control at the moment, namely, small business. The Government is prepared to do that at the cost of potentially hundreds of thousands of jobs in this country.

People employed by small business have a choice: they can either accept superannuation increases over five years and perhaps keep their jobs or run the very real risk of seeing no increase in their wages whatsoever. In terms of the Government's policy, in terms of this Treasury document—and that is all we are quoting—the Government has to say to people, `Don't worry, you're doing your bit for Australia. You'll be independent in your retirement, and God be with you'. The sad fact is that those people will not be independent in their retirement on the basis of the Government's policy because it is mathematically impossible to achieve that outcome.

Small businesses, those which employ less than 100 employees, make up 96 per cent of Australian enterprises. The Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, in evidence given before the Committee, stated that the cost to the Australian small business sector of providing superannuation already amounts to $1.14 billion a year, representing 60,000 jobs to workers on an average weekly wage.

The Morgan gallup poll has told every member in this House that 74 per cent of the Australian people consider unemployment to be one of the three most important political issues facing this country. It is absolutely beyond description how a government under current circumstances can come in here at this stage with a policy package which effectively means that people will lose jobs, not gain them. At the very same time, the Treasurer has gone on record as saying that before the end of this session, and certainly before the Budget, there will be a White Paper on superannuation policy. Perhaps somebody will produce one, but he certainly will not. He had the opportunity last night to explain to the House precisely what the Government's policy was, and he flunked it. He did not even come into the House except to vote, and then he scuttled out again as fast as he could. It is a disgrace to the Minister and a disgrace to this Parliament to be treated in that manner.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I should say to the honourable member for Bradfield that it is not within his capacity in relation to the MPI to reflect upon a previous vote of the House. I just want to ensure that he stays within those requirements of the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am not reflecting on a previous vote, just on the obvious facts. But it is standard practice in this House for Ministers to answer questions on legislation, and the Minister failed to do so.

PARA.TAB: The Government must create new job opportunities, particularly fostering industries, small business and farming communities. That is what it has to do if it is going to make any serious impact on unemployment. We have evidence before us. We have received many letters. The letter from Tonkin's Currency Creek Wines is a good example, and I will quote it for the benefit of the House. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: This firm currently employs three people and has an annual payroll of under $500,000. On our calculations, the cost of the government's proposals to this organisation will be as follows:

By 1993-94, one or two positions will be lost and the business will be forced to cut back on many trade avenues, making it less viable again. The current Super burden is heavy for this small company which is working on very fine margins already.

As profits cannot be pruned further, and efficiency levels are already very high, raising prices is the only alternative. However this would make us non-competitive, and in the medium term, may cause closure of the business.

We therefore urge you to withdraw the Superannuation Guarantee Levy (S.G.L.) proposals to help this business survive. If we go under, at least three extra workers will join the ranks of the unemployed.

This matter was covered in the debate last night. It is a critical matter for small business that it stay alive. This is not the time to be increasing the costs of economic viability, and it is grossly irresponsible for this Government and this Minister to support such a flawed policy at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time when we have the lowest level of inflation that we have witnessed in 20 years, and today the lowest level of interest rates that we have witnessed in 20 years, to have the Opposition come in and indulge in the sort of cant and humbug that we have witnessed today in this matter of public importance says nothing about small business or about the Opposition's broader policies.

PARA.TAB: In the area of superannuation, the motivation behind our superannuation policy has been to ensure a comprehensive retirement incomes policy for all Australians into the next century. Surely that is an area which we should, as a nation, be prepared to take up with some degree of seriousness and urgency. Yet what do we get? We get the Opposition pretending that it is concerned about small business and using the superannuation guarantee levy proposals as a means to further its own political motives.

This MPI gives us the opportunity to highlight some of the positive things that have occurred in relation to the Government's approach to small business and the visionary aspects of our superannuation policies. I want to touch on a few of the matters that are significant as far as small business needs are concerned and to use that to work into the superannuation issue.

The first thing that needs to be said is that throughout the development of our policies we have recognised the special needs of small business. Going back to the One Nation statement, we recognise the special concerns small business had at that time to ensure the deferral of the super guarantee levy for firms under the $500,000 threshold. The Government agreed to that, and so there is a deferral for firms under that threshold. Their arrangement for bringing in the full contribution of superannuation has been deferred for that year, and they have a more graduated scale than larger firms.

At the same time, in the recent changes to the wholesale sales tax area, we recognise that small business should be relieved of much of the burden of wholesale sales tax. Of course, the changes that were announced in that area ensure that the vast majority of small businesses are not affected by those wholesale sales tax areas. The Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) has already referred to other initiatives in the One Nation statement to give more access to funds to small businesses seeking export opportunities and to small businesses seeking additional arrangements through the goodwill transition arrangements on the capital gains tax. All of those things have been done because we recognise the important place that small business has in our economy and the special role it will have to have in economic recovery.

At the same time as we have been doing that, the Opposition has pretended to show concern for small business. Yet, what would it propose as the alternative strategy for assisting small business? It proposes a 15 per cent goods and services tax. I do not know how many documents I have seen in recent times about the experience of the goods and services tax on small business in Canada and New Zealand, but one of the things that come through loud and clear in all of it is just what an administrative nightmare it is for small business having to complete the returns for the comparable goods and services tax arrangements in those countries; that is not what small business wants.

I recall from the report from the Minister when he was Chairman of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology that small business complained at that time and made submissions about the need to ensure that its costs and its overheads because of government requirements were minimised. The very thing one would do if one was trying to ensure the maximisation of the administrative complexity facing small business would be to introduce a goods and services tax in the way the Opposition proposes. It will have a devastating effect on small business. It will be a real disincentive to employment in this country. That has to be compared, as I said, with our approach, which has at all times tried to assist and to encourage small business to streamline, to be more efficient and to make a more active contribution to the community as a whole.

Then we come to the superannuation guarantee levy and we start getting international comparisons as to what effect this will have on Australia and how it will make us less competitive. There are a few things that need to be said. Firstly, over the last two days we have seen the most gross misrepresentation of what the Treasury actually put to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. We have had this reinforced in today's MPI by the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) and the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). They have selectively quoted, as the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) did yesterday, what the Treasury had said. But the fundamental point they decided not to quote was that Treasury went on:

SPEECH.PARA: However, this assumption is not regarded as reasonable. It is expected that the cost of the SGL will be largely, if not fully, offset by lower growth in other forms of remuneration, especially wages. In this regard the Government indicated in the One Nation statement that the scope for wages growth from other sources than the SGL will necessarily be lower than otherwise so as to ensure that enhanced superannuation does not impact adversely on cost structures and inflation.

The Government has recognised all the way through the need to ensure the maintenance of an eye on the inflation result, which has been a great achievement of the Government. Maintaining a keen eye on that is built into all our strategies. That has been one of the fundamental focuses of the arrangement between the Government and the ACTU. It is something on which we know the Opposition can never deliver.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition can never grasp the fact that we have to run a wages policy that involves consultation and agreement with the trade union movement. Of course, small business benefits from the fact that wages growth, the real unit labour costs, is not as great. Part of the offset for that has been superannuation for the work force. That is a pretty fundamental policy difference between us, because, basically, the Opposition's policy, when it is narrowed down, represents the most wholesale attack on the work force of this country and a belief that workers of this country are not entitled to share in the benefits of an adequate retirement incomes policy. It is all right for the upper echelons of society to have that, but clearly the workers of this country, according to the Opposition, are not entitled to have access to that form of retirement income assistance.

What is the result of that? We see the result in what the Liberals did when they were last in office. First of all, they had double digit inflation and interest rates. They had a policy that did not guarantee the security and certainty of wages. When we talk to businesses, one of the things they definitely say about this Government is that they recognise the Government's strength in the accord process and what that has meant in terms of stability, certainty and wages outcomes for them, together with the partnership approach between government and the trade union movement, which gives employers a certainty that they never had in the unpredictable days of the wages explosions of the late seventies and early eighties.

Part of that agreement between the Government and the trade union movement has been built around having the superannuation arrangements put in place. It is a responsible thing on the part of the Government; it is a responsible thing on the part of the trade union movement. We are trying to recognise that we need to have some vision, some foresight, to plan for the ageing of the population that is occurring in the community. We are still going to be short of what is done in many other countries in terms of the employer contribution to employees' retirement, but at the same time we have recognised that it is essential that we build and make a start so that we are not leaving people in retirement in the next century relying on the age pension, which, if the Opposition ever gets into government, will just diminish as a real retirement income in the way it did under the Fraser Government. Of course, it would haemorrhage at a much greater rate because the number of people in the retired category would be so great that the Opposition would not give any commitment to maintain it.

This MPI gives us a chance to highlight, as the Minister has done, what we have achieved in recognising the relationship that we need to have with small business and also what we need to do in terms of providing properly for people's retirement. If the Parliament is not prepared to do that today, in 10 years time it will be too late, and the policies of the Opposition at that time will not enable us to provide adequately for retirement for the great bulk of the population. SPEECH.PARA: The A.C.T. Supreme Court (Transfer) Bill will enhance the protection of the independence of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court, which is to be transferred to the Australian Capital Territory on 1 July 1992. At present, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 merely provides that from 1 July 1992 the ACT Legislative Assembly has legislative power in relation to the establishment and administration of courts. Without something more, none of the traditional safeguards of an independent judiciary are entrenched in Territory law.

PARA.TAB: In the Australian Capital Territory, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act takes the place of a constitution. It is, therefore, appropriate that the self-government Act should contain provisions entrenching the position of an independent judiciary, in a similar manner to Chapter III of the Constitution in relation to the Federal judiciary.

On 8 April 1992 the ACT Legislative Assembly formally requested that the Commonwealth Parliament amend the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act so as to provide a new part of the Act dealing with the judiciary. Specifically, the following provisions were requested by the ACT Legislative Assembly:

SPEECH.PARA: .a provision for the existence of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory, which is to have all the original and appellate jurisdiction that is necessary to administer justice in the Territory;

.provisions for the removal from office of a judge, a magistrate or another judicial officer, only after a request to the ACT Executive by the ACT Legislative Assembly made in accordance with a report of a judicial commission, which has found that the behaviour or capacity of a person could amount to misbehaviour warranting that person's removal from office;
.provisions for the determination of judicial remuneration, which guarantee the non-diminution of that remuneration; and
.provisions to protect the position of the judges who will continue as judges of the Court after 1 July 1992.

Under the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, the ACT Legislative Assembly is excluded from making laws in relation to the establishment of courts, subject to provisions of the Act providing for the transfer of legislative power. The ACT Magistrates Court was transferred to the ACT Government on 1 July 1990, when the ACT was given legislative power in relation to the establishment of magistrates' courts and coroners' courts. The Supreme Court will, under the existing provisions of the Act, be transferred on 1 July 1992 when the ACT obtains legislative power in relation to all courts, completing the process of transfer of ACT courts to the Australian Capital Territory.

PARA.TAB: The Bill largely implements the recommendations of a working party comprising representatives of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, the ACT Government Law Office and the ACT Supreme Court. The ACT Law Society and the ACT Bar Association were also consulted.

The Bill provides for the amendment of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988, both Commonwealth Acts, and the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933, a Commonwealth Act which will become a Territory enactment on 1 July 1992. There are also some minor, consequential amendments of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, the Judges (Long Leave Payments) Act 1979 and the Judges' Pensions Act 1968. The amendments of the Self-Government Act include provisions for the:

SPEECH.PARA: .jurisdiction and powers of the Supreme Court;
.establishment of a judicial commission to investigate allegations or complaints about the conduct or physical or mental capacity of a judicial officer;
.removal of a judicial officer from office; and,
.remuneration and allowances of judicial officers.
The amendments of the ACT Supreme Court Act include provisions:
.concerning the seniority of the judges of the Court;
.for the exercise by the Supreme Court of jurisdiction under subsections 46(4) and 48(2) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1989 of the Territory;
.for approval for the holding of other judicial offices by judges of the Supreme Court;
.in respect of the jurisdiction and powers of the Court;
.for an oath or affirmation of office to be taken by the registrar of the court; and
.in respect of the appointment of officers to assist the sheriff.

The principal provisions of this Bill are those that entrench in Commonwealth legislation the traditional protections of judicial independence. Because the provisions are to be in Commonwealth legislation, the ACT judiciary will not be subject to the possibility of an attack on the independence of the ACT judicial system from the ACT Executive or legislature.

PARA.TAB: Appointment of judges in Australia is traditionally a matter for the Executive. While the ACT Supreme Court has been a court created by the Commonwealth, judges have been appointed by the Governor-General in Council. The Bill provides for all future judges and other officers of the Supreme Court to be appointed by the ACT Executive.

The amendments of the Self-Government Act provide for the removal of a judge or other judicial officer or a member of a tribunal by the ACT Executive following a resolution of the ACT Legislative Assembly acting in accordance with a report of a judicial commission, in which the commission has concluded that the behaviour or physical or mental capacity of the judicial officer or member of the tribunal concerned could amount to proved misbehaviour or incapacity such as to warrant removal from office. This standard for the operation of a judicial commission is the standard recommended by the Advisory Committee of the Constitutional Commission in its 1988 report, paragraph 5.55. A judicial officer may only be removed from office by the Executive in writing.

The judicial commission will be constituted by judges who have been, but are no longer, justices of the High Court, or who are or have been judges of a superior court of record of a State or Territory—other than sitting resident judges of the ACT Supreme Court—and will be appointed by the ACT Government. The commission may be a standing commission or established ad hoc.

The retiring ages of the present judges and the master are protected by the provisions of this Bill. After 1 July 1992, the ACT Legislative Assembly will have power to make a law that establishes a retiring age for judges or the master that is different from that which now applies. New section 48B provides that such a law is to have no effect in relation to a judge or the master who was appointed before the commencement of the Act, unless the judge or the master consents, in writing, to the different law applying to him or her. It will therefore be possible for the ACT Legislative Assembly to increase or decrease the retiring age of members of the ACT judiciary, but the retiring age of the current members of the Supreme Court can only be changed with their consent.

As a further safeguard to judicial independence, the amended Self-Government Act and the amended ACT Supreme Court Act will provide that the remuneration and allowances of a judicial officer cannot be diminished while the officer holds office, and the amended self-government Act provides that the remuneration and allowances of the chief justice, the judges, the master, the chief magistrate and a magistrate of the Australian Capital Territory are to be determined by the Commonwealth Remuneration Tribunal.

The current chief justice and judges of the Court, except the additional judges, will continue to hold office on terms no less favourable than those of judges of the Federal Court of Australia. The additional judges are, of course, all judges of the Federal Court of Australia.

Some provisions of the Bill have been included to ensure that there is no doubt as to the fact that the ACT Supreme Court will continue to operate as the same entity after 1 July 1992. The translation of the Supreme Court Act 1933 from an Act of the Commonwealth Parliament to an ACT enactment in no way creates a break in the existence of the ACT Supreme Court.

Amendments of the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Act 1988 will ensure the continuity of office of the judges and the master of the Court. New section 29A of the Consequential Provisions Act provides that the chief justice, the other judges (including the additional judges) and the master as at 1 July 1992, continue to hold their office after 1 July 1992, notwithstanding the fact that from 1 July 1992 the ACT Supreme Court Act is an ACT enactment.

New section 29B provides that all proceedings pending in the Supreme Court on or before 1 July 1992, and any judgment or order entered or made before 1 July 1992, are to be continued on and after that date as if they were proceedings instituted in the Court referred to in the ACT enactment.

The Bill is expected to have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. The running costs of the Supreme Court were agreed with the ACT Government in 1988 and that amount will be included in the general revenue grant of the ACT from 1 July 1992. I table the explanatory memorandum for the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is an omnibus Bill containing minor administrative amendments to the following legislation administered within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio: the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977; the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991; the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991; the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989; the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991; and the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Australian Meat and Live-Stock Corporation Act 1977

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Act to correct a deficiency in the Act in relation to the giving of evidence of analysts in court proceedings by way of a certificate. The AMLC Act currently provides that a certificate of analysis—for example, analysis of product for residues—is prima facie evidence of the information it contains. The deficiency arises, however, in that the certificate fails to establish that the substances which have been analysed were those found in the possession of the accused, seized and passed onto the analyst for analysis. The Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions believes that this deficiency requires the analyst to attend court to give evidence in support of other continuity witnesses.

The amendment proposed in this Bill will allow the certificate of the analyst to contain information as to the date of receipt of the substance, the name of the person from whom it was received and a description of the substance. This will directly link the substances analysed with those found in the possession of the accused and overcome the gap in the chain of evidence, obviating the need for the analyst to attend court to give evidence, unless called by the defendant.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991
Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989

PARA.TAB: The major part of this Bill is to provide for amendments to legislation for the wool industry. The amendments relate specifically to the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991 and the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989.

In addition, as part of the overall package of changes to the wool industry legislation, proposed amendments to the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964, and to the Wool Tax Acts (Nos 1-5) 1964, will be introduced separately.

The primary purpose of the package of amendments to the wool legislation is to provide mechanisms for distributing surplus Australian Wool Realisation Commission funds to woolgrowers and to introduce more flexibility into the current debt reduction arrangements. Both of these initiatives were recently announced in the One Nation statement. The package will also provide for other relatively minor amendments to the wool industry legislation, most of which are at the request of those involved in aspects of its administration.

The wool industry represents yet another case which clearly demonstrates this Government's capacity to work with industry to develop sound public policy. The Government's position has always been clear: we will accept advice from a variety of sources, we will consult with the industry and jointly develop a policy base that will take those industries forward. What we have also made clear is that we will not be driven by ideological approaches that fail to recognise the concerns and requirements of industry.

Honourable members will be aware of the radical changes to the statutory industry framework and marketing arrangements for wool which came into effect in July last year. The new statutory authorities—the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, the new Australian Wool Corporation and the Wool R&D Corporation—have taken up their respective roles with enthusiasm and commitment. The AWRC, in particular, has a significant challenge in selling the stockpile and discharging the industry debt. At the same time it must have regard for the overall impact of its activities on the market. While ever there is a large stockpile, there is a potential for that stockpile to overhang the market in such a way as to create uncertainty and affect demand.

Twelve months ago the stockpile stood at 4.7 million bales and the debt was around $2.7 billion. At the time we expected that the AWRC would only be able to pay off a small amount of the debt in 1991-92, and the debt schedule therefore set the repayment target for the year at $20 million. Since July the AWRC has been affected by a range of factors combining to enable it to achieve a higher income from sales from its stockpile of wool than was anticipated at the start of the season. The reasons for this include lower levels of wool production, the quality of the wool in the stockpile being different to recent drought affected production, increased demand for stocks to replenish the wool processing pipeline, and higher prices than expected. As a result, the AWRC is now well ahead of its required debt repayment target for this year.

To build on that better than expected outcome for the AWRC, the Government decided it was appropriate to change the AWRC debt reduction schedule from an annual to a cumulative basis, as announced in the One Nation statement. This provision will give the AWRC more flexibility in adjusting its operations to market conditions. In the event of a market downturn, the flexibility to pay off more debt in some years will give it the capacity to pay off less if returns are lower in others. It will, however, need to ensure that the maximum debt balances at the end of each year do not exceed the limits set within the cumulative debt schedule.

It is possible in some years that funds might be generated by the AWRC which are not prudently required for the debt repayment program. Therefore, recognising that most growers are currently receiving low incomes, the Government believes that a way is needed to distribute to growers any such surplus funds generated by the AWRC. In the One Nation statement it was indicated that any surplus funds not prudently required by the AWRC may be used as a rebate to growers in the form of a cash payment.

The Government also gave a commitment to consult with the wool industry on the distribution of such funds to growers. Following constructive discussions involving myself, and with the agreement of the Wool Council, I announced in April that I propose to use any surplus funds generated by the AWRC during the current year as a rebate against the wool tax in 1992-93. My intention is that this will enable a reduction in the effective rate of the tax for the next season, while maintaining the prescribed rate of the tax at the existing 12 per cent. The Wool Council supports this position.

The amendments proposed in the Bill will provide the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy with the flexibility to distribute surplus AWRC funds as a rebate of wool tax, as a cash payment to wool tax payers, or to determine that the surplus should remain in the stockpile fund to pay off more debt. A determination would be made after the Minister had been advised by the AWRC if it holds surplus funds which are not required for the prudent management of the debt repayment program and the operation of the stockpile fund. Before making a decision, the Minister will be required to consult with the Wool Council of Australia about the distribution of the surplus.

I am optimistic about the future for wool. However, it is still very difficult to accurately predict what the market might do in the years ahead and therefore whether the AWRC will generate a surplus in future years. I am particularly mindful to also ensure that the objective to prudently manage the debt and stockpile sales must remain clear and uncompromised. To this end I will continue to strongly resist calls for a reduction in the overall prescribed wool tax rate.

The Government does not believe that, on the basis of one year's performance, it would be prudent to lower the prescribed rate of tax at this time. To do that might result in having to put the tax rate up again in a later year if the market suffers a downturn. The Wool Council of Australia endorses this position. The level of the tax rebate to apply in 1992-93 will be decided in June this year, and I will be considering the advice I receive from the AWRC on the size of the surplus when making that decision. I will also be consulting with the Wool Council on the matter.

As I mentioned earlier, this Bill contains a number of other amendments which have been made at the request of the Australian Wool Corporation, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wool Industry Council in the light of experience with the legislation so far. Generally these amendments are intended to finetune some of the administrative provisions. Three of them warrant some explanatory comment.

The AWC has requested modifications to the way in which the register of wool tax payers entitled to vote at general meetings is maintained. The proposed amendments will provide for grower registration and voting entitlements to be specified in a three-year rolling register. Growers will be able to update their details each year if they wish, but if they consider that the details previously provided are still relevant, then their entry on the register would be maintained for three years. In making these changes, the administration of the register will be simplified, and growers will be relieved of the annual requirement to make a formal application to be registered.

As well, an addition is proposed to the types of motions which can be put and voted on at an AWC annual general meeting. Under the current legislation, woolgrowers are unable to put forward motions on general business matters within the Corporation's responsibilities. The proposed amendment will mean greater accountability between woolgrowers and the Corporation by allowing a wider range of motions to be debated and voted upon.

Amendments to ensure that the AWRC has the appropriate and well-defined powers to deal in hedging have been requested by it following discussions with financial institutions and in the light of legal advice. The changes will ensure that the Commission has the commercial flexibility which is consistent with its functions. The proposed changes are similar to recently made provisions for other statutory authorities and, in essence, ensure that the AWRC has the power to use hedging contracts to manage risks of variations in the cost of borrowings as well as risks of adverse variations in foreign currency transactions. In addition, the AWRC will be able to use hedging to manage returns on investments. Similar amendments have also been made to the AWC legislation at the request of the AWC.

At the request of the AWIC, the Wool Industry Council, an amendment has been made to the Australian Wool Corporation Act to provide additional flexibility in the registration authority of wool sampling sites, testing laboratories and show floors. Currently the National Association of Testing Authorities (NATA) is the sole registration authority. The proposed amendment will provide for the possibility that an alternative registration authority to NATA may be prescribed at some time in the future.

Some minor amendments have also been made to the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, the PIERD Act. These amendments are required as a consequence of amendments made to the AWC Act regarding the establishment and maintenance of a register of woolgrowers for the purposes of voting at an annual general meeting. All of the proposed amendments which make up the package of changes to the wool legislation are responsible decisions. They finetune the statutory arrangements and show that the Government is sensitive to ensuring that there is an appropriate and flexible framework for the industry.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendments to this Act are to rectify minor anomalies concerning the allowing of minimum quantity or minimum monetary levels for small producers. In most levy or export charge schemes about 85 per cent of levy income is paid by only 15 per cent of the levy payer population, whereas 40 to 50 per cent of the population would pay less than the limits proposed. The intention is to allow small producers a threshold before having to pay a levy. Once the threshold is reached, the levy would become payable on the total quantity or amount. The basis for setting the threshold is not linked to the actual levy rates but is related to the estimated collection cost per levy return. These provisions will permit different thresholds to be prescribed for future levy years according to changing economic circumstances.

With full cost recovery for levy collections operating since 1988-89 there has been increasing pressure from participating industries for more economical collection techniques to be adopted by the Department. These measures have the support of participating industries. As there are no changes proposed to the operative rates of levy or export charges in this Bill, there will be no net revenue effect.

The amendment to this Act 1949 increases the ministerial contract approval level from $0.5m to $2m. It empowers the Authority to enter into contracts valued under $2m without the requirement to obtain prior ministerial approval for each contract up to this level. SPEECH.PARA: The Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1992 and the accompanying Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill will set the framework for the Commonwealth's dairy marketing arrangements until the year 2000, and will have a substantial influence on the future direction of the Australian dairy industry.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this Bill is to set the rate of assistance for manufactured dairy exports each year up until 30 June 2000, to provide for the termination of Commonwealth underwriting for dairy exports from 30 June 1992 and to provide more flexibility in the way promotion and other industry funds can be expended.

The Australian dairy industry is one of our great traditional primary industries. Over the years it has experienced good times but there have also been bad times. The past few years in particular have been difficult, especially for the export sector, but as always the industry has shown great resilience and is adjusting well to meet the new marketing challenges. The package of measures that I will announce today will better equip the industry to handle those challenges. It is the Government's response to the Industry Commission's September 1991 report on the Australian dairy industry.

The details of the announcements go to both assistance and market development. It is proposed that there be a moratorium for a further 12 months on any reduction in market support. This is particularly to assist the situation in Victoria and Tasmania, where farmers have been hard hit. There will be a phase-down in market support to the year 2000 in equal instalments, taking the market support equivalent protection from 22 per cent above export parity to 10 per cent above export parity. I should point out that this 10 per cent above export parity is the equivalent of and is consistent with the tariff target of 5 per cent for manufacturing industry set by this Government. Importantly, it is a figure that has been achieved with the agreement of the industry. It is not a figure that was advocated by the Industry Commission, which the Opposition, I might note, was locked into.

PARA.TAB: First, let us have a closer look at the dairy industry. There are just under 15,000 registered dairy farms in Australia producing about 6,400 million litres of milk per annum worth about $1.7 billion. The industry is labour-intensive, directly employing some 50,000 people and indirectly employing a further 50,000.

Victoria is the key dairy State, producing about 60 per cent of national milk output. The wholesale value of processed dairy foods is around $4.5 billion—and manufacturers and processors add nearly $3 billion of extra value. Around 30 per cent of milk production is exported as dairy products worth around $700m. East Asia accounts for 67 per cent of Australia's dairy exports. Japan is the largest market, closely followed by the Philippines. Taiwan, Malaysia, Singapore and Thailand sales opportunities are increasing as a result of continuing income growth in South East Asia.

In 1986, my colleague the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Hon. John Kerin, introduced what became known in the industry as the `Kerin plan'. The aim was to wean the industry from its reliance on government assistance and to make it more commercially based and more responsive to market opportunities. There would be few in the industry who would disagree that the `Kerin plan' has been a great success. The industry is now neither backward nor is it stagnant. It is adopting state of the art technology and adjustment has been taking place on a continuing basis. Farmers have, for example, been leaving the industry at a rate of around 3 per cent per year. Nevertheless, national production has tended to increase. There has been continuous amalgamation of and investment in manufacturing facilities and a shift in emphasis from commodities to the marketing of profitable value added products. Nominal assistance to the export sector has reduced from around 45 per cent in 1986 to the current 22 per cent.

The `Kerin plan' assistance terminates on 30 June this year. The challenge has been to develop a new set of arrangements that would be consistent with the Government's broader industry objectives, maintaining the momentum created under the current arrangements and yet recognising that the industry is currently feeling the effects of low world prices.

I believe the package I will now detail will achieve all of these objectives. It is the outcome of productive consultations with the industry's leadership and I believe it has a large measure of support within the industry itself. In its development I have sought a strategy that capitalises on the technical and marketing achievements resulting from the six years of the `Kerin plan' and provides the framework that will enable a more productive, internationally competitive and export focused sector to develop. I believe that the process of interaction that I have gone through with industry has enabled the laying of a sound foundation for the industry's position up to and beyond the turn of the century.

Let me say that the important thing about this outcome is that it does reflect the active consultation with the industry. That is the important difference between our approach and the Opposition's in terms of addressing industry development.

I want to also give praise to the industry with whom I have negotiated this package of reforms. The Australian Dairy Industry Council represents both producers as well as processors and therefore is an important body because it involves more than just the grower end of the market. It had to negotiate this in difficult circumstances. Not only did the Council have an IC report which it could not live with—and members of the coalition could because they were committed to introducing it—but also it had to cope with the disciplines associated with our position in the GATT and a constituency that was arguing for the retention of the status quo. But against that background, I challenged it to come forward with a strategy for the future, one that would secure the industry and make it grow. The Council has responded. I sat down with it and we negotiated.

At this point I want to make particular mention of the contribution of Mr Pat Rowley, the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Industry Council. The success of the `Kerin plan' is in no small measure due to Mr Rowley's determination to see the Australian dairy industry adjust and prosper in the face of difficult market conditions. He was a very forceful advocate on behalf of the industry in the recent negotiations.

Assistance to the export sector will remain at the 1991-92 level of 22 per cent of average export prices throughout 1992-93. This is in recognition of the difficult circumstances currently facing many dairy farmers and will provide some time for the industry to re-group. Thereafter, the rate of assistance will be reduced in equal steps each year to 10 per cent in 1999-2000. This 10 per cent market support rate is consistent with the 5 per cent tariff target for manufacturing industry because of the manner in which dairy market support applies and reasonably reflects the Government's industry objectives as announced in recent policy statements. The new arrangements will `sunset' on 30 June 2000. The industry's leadership accepts that the dairy industry should expect no further legislative support beyond the year 2000 and that it will be treated the same as other industries at that time.

In keeping with current Government policy, government underwriting of dairy export returns will terminate on 30 June 1992. Underwriting has been of limited assistance to the dairy industry as it was not triggered until 1990-91, when SMP and casein received $22m in support.

The cheese tariff quota will be renewed from 1 July 1992. My colleague the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) will be introducing shortly the necessary alteration to the Customs Tariff Act 1987 by way of a customs tariff proposal.

The new arrangements will have no direct impact on the State market milk schemes. These are a State responsibility and continue to provide the major portion of the measured assistance to the dairy industry. Most States have in place, or are planning, significant deregulation post the farm gate. This is a commendable objective which may lead to significant changes. I welcome the current moves for a more uniform national approach to UHT milk pricing. The possible inclusion of enhanced farm gate pricing regulation, the so-called section 38 type provisions, will remain a controversial issue and my only comment on this aspect is that States may find it prudent not to be locked into any new farm gate pricing regulation which does not offer scope for flexibility to deal with changing market conditions. I propose to keep developments in State market milk arrangements under review in the Agricultural Council of Australia and New Zealand.

As an added discipline on the States, the Government has decided to terminate the so-called comfort clause from 30 June 1992. This provision has provided a connection between the Commonwealth arrangements and the State schemes. This enabled any State to seek suspension of the all milk levy and so discourage interstate milk trade.

The Kerin plan was aimed primarily at raising the farm gate return for manufacturing milk. It also involved the removal of the longstanding practice of equalising domestic and export product returns. The changes exposed dairy manufacturers more directly to market forces. Consequently, a more efficient manufacturing sector has evolved through technology transfer and infrastructure rationalisation. Nevertheless, dairy manufacturers are still some way from achieving their potential in both a well-developed marketing ethos and operating practices. The Government has therefore decided to add a second element to the new marketing arrangements to encourage further development in these areas.

The impetus for change will come from a redirection of the operation of the Australian Dairy Corporation and, to a lesser extent, the Dairy Research and Development Corporation to further enhance the industry's export marketing and market development, particularly for profitable higher value products. I will be working closely with the Australian Dairy Industry Council and with the corporations in the coming months to put in place specific activity that will assist dairy manufacturers in the general area of market development. This Bill makes provision for more flexibility in the use of industry promotion funds and the Dairy Industry Fund in market development activity to provide additional funds to support and reinforce the industry's marketing efforts.

The Council has a legislated role under the current arrangements in respect of a range of policy issues. This is an unusual status for an industry based body and is different from the current representational model based on statutory industry councils. Nevertheless, the Council has operated responsibly in its administration of the Kerin plan, and the Government has decided to continue that role in relation to the new arrangements. On the other hand, the Council is industry based and cannot avoid an agri-political role. This Bill provides for ministerial scrutiny of the funding of the Council to ensure that funds available for its policy role are not used for other purposes. This process will ensure that the contribution of the Council to industry policy development remains under review.

Cooperatives have historically been a feature of this industry, and a large part of the industry's rationalisation in recent years has been through co-operative mergers. Co-operatives are regulated by State legislation. I believe their effectiveness could be improved by consistent and uniform legislation throughout Australia. Progress to this end through Commonwealth and State ministerial councils has been slow. I am seeking to hasten change so that the cooperative sector of this and other industries can pursue commercial goals and benefits that are presently hindered due to inconsistent legislation between States.

The package I have just detailed will provide an industry arrangement that is transparent, predictable and progressive. It highlights the benefits of consulting with industry and it underscores the fact that this outcome for the industry could not have been achieved by the coalition, because of its blind locking into the Fightback package, which proposes the elimination of tariffs and the adoption of IC recommendations. There is no flexibility in the Opposition's position at all, and that is why the National Party, in particular, has found itself in such great difficulties within its own constituency. On the other hand, this Government has taken a reasonable approach given the industry's current situation and the desirability of further assistance reductions. It will take the industry to the end of the decade and leave it in good shape to face the future thereafter. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bills.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
