TALK.START.PARA: —The Remuneration and Allowances Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 has three principal purposes. Firstly, it sets a new salary structure for the Industrial Relations Commission; secondly, it varies the Remuneration Tribunal decision on the salaries of vice-chancellors and; thirdly, it broadens the range of persons eligible to chair the Remuneration Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: This particular Bill invites the House to discuss the future of the Industrial Relations Commission—in particular, its role within the contemporary industrial relations system. It also asks us to look at the status of Industrial Relations commissioners and their appropriate salary levels. Given the recent controversy which has surrounded the resignation of Commissioner Turbet from the Commission, I think it also invites us to examine the proper relationship between the Commission and the government of the day. Finally, it invites us to discuss the Remuneration Tribunal and its role in setting salaries for the Commission and for others.

In commencing this debate, I would like to take issue with the remarks of the previous speaker, the shadow Minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who addressed the House on Monday night. He made what I could describe as an enlivened speech, although it was not a particularly new one. I think it was essentially the same speech that he delivered in the discussion of a matter of public importance the previous week.

The shadow Minister based his case upon an examination of the resignation letter advanced by former Commissioner Turbet. The shadow Minister read a great deal into that. He said the letter demonstrated that the Government had no proper respect for the Commission, that the Commission was being stacked with appointments from the union movement and, really, that the whole authority of the Commission would now be so greatly damaged that confidence in it could never be restored.

While I did take great interest in what the shadow Minister had to say, I could not particularly agree with many of the conclusions that he reached. Firstly, while the resignation of Commissioner Turbet is obviously a matter of some embarrassment to the Government—I would not try to pretend otherwise—to say that his resignation and the reasons he advanced in his resignation sound the death knell of the Industrial Relations Commission as we know it and mean that the Commission has no future role in the industrial scene of Australia is, I think, a gross exaggeration and is not borne out by the facts.

The main point Commissioner Turbet took great issue with was the failure of the Government to follow through on the decision of the Remuneration Tribunal, which had recommended a substantial increase in the salaries of commissioners. This whole matter has some sort of history. It stems from an original decision of the Tribunal—of, I think, about 18 months ago—when a 14 per cent increase was recommended. This increase came against a background when the Government and the Commission were asking Australian wage and salary earners to exercise considerable constraint for economic outcomes. I imagine that it was a bit hard for ordinary workers to accept that they were being asked to limit their wage demands at that time to an overall level of 6 per cent, when the very people who were setting their wage rates were asking for an increase—and it was recommended that they receive an increase considerably above that.

The Government, as is its express right, did not agree with the decision of the Tribunal, and a subsequent decision was made to grant a 6 per cent rise with a second rise to follow after a review of the functions of the Commission. This review was carried out by a committee headed by Mr Gleeson, who was the former head of the Premier's Department in New South Wales. It was a very sound review and its recommendations about restructuring the Commission have been accepted by the Government and, indeed, have now been enacted into law by this Parliament. I believe the new structure was, at that time, supported by the Opposition.

The matter then went back to the Tribunal in order for it to determine what the new wage structure within the Commission should be. Quite simply, the Tribunal failed to resolve the matter. It set no salaries for the new structures and, against that quite extraordinary decision of the Tribunal, the Government decided to proceed with this particular course and bring this particular Bill to the Parliament.

Commissioner Turbet has taken great exception to that, and he cites it as his principal reason for resigning from the Commission. That resignation is a matter of regret and certainly the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has said that quite openly and publicly. But to conclude from the disappointment of Commissioner Turbet that the Industrial Relations Commission is about to fall over, that it has no future role, or that its authority has been greatly diminished is to overstate the case completely.

The Commission and its forebear, the Arbitration Commission, have been part of the industrial landscape of Australia since Federation. Indeed, there have been many times throughout its long and colourful history when the government of the day, particular commissioners, and the Commission as a whole have not always seen eye to eye. The Commission has lived long past the particular whims of those governments.

Interestingly enough, in the letter of resignation submitted by Commissioner Turbet, he recounted the experience of the Bruce conservative Government in 1929 which, at that time, tried to eliminate the Arbitration Commission from the industrial landscape. That particular Government fell on the floor of the House and was subsequently soundly defeated at the general election.

I think there might be a lesson in that for my colleagues opposite who now also go to the Australian people with essentially the same policy as the conservative Government of Mr Bruce of 60-odd years ago. Mr Bruce's Government was soundly defeated. I think the Opposition—which thinks that the Australian people do not have a deep respect for the Industrial Relations Commission, the role it has played, and the future that it has in our new industrial system—may also bring about the wrath of the Australian people when it proposes policies which essentially eliminate a future role for the Commission.

I do not think that the role of the Commission has been greatly diminished. As I have said, there have been disputes with it before in the 1950s. Certainly the labour movement as a whole did not support the wage fixing principles and attitudes adopted by the Commission at that time and yet the Commission went on from strength to strength from those disputes of the 1950s. Certainly, the Fraser Government did not achieve everything it wanted in terms of its submissions to the Commission and yet the Commission continued to play a role.

Although this Government did not agree with the April 1991 wage fixing decision, with the refusal of the Commission at that time to endorse the move towards enterprise bargaining, to take from that the long bow that the honourable member for Bennelong did and to say, `Well, that is it; the game is up for the Commission; its authority has been destroyed or diminished' is to ignore the lessons of history. I would be a little more circumspect than was the honourable member for Bennelong in suggesting that the game is up; I do not think it is.

The honourable member for Bennelong then went on to attack the accord process and the Government's approach to industrial relations. I took great interest in this because I have been listening to the honourable member, certainly for the five years that I have been a member of this House, and maybe for a few years prior to that. During the life of this Government the accord has been a bit of a hobbyhorse for the Opposition. The Opposition has seen great fault in it throughout its entire history.

The honourable member for Bennelong built himself up to a bit of a crescendo and said that the accord process had failed the most important test. I waited with bated breath to find out what this test was going to be. I remembered that a few years ago the test that the accord always failed, according to the Opposition, was the inflation test. It was always argued by those opposite that under the accord process inflation was built into the system; that the accord guaranteed a wage increase to Australian workers which built in inflation because prices would rise and so on. We now have a situation where the latest inflation result in Australia was a zero rate, with an annual inflation rate of 1.7 per cent and an underlying inflation rate of 3 per cent.

Interestingly enough, the honourable member for Bennelong has moved the goalposts a bit in terms of this important test for the accord process. No longer is inflation the real evil of the accord. The real and the most important test now, according to the honourable member for Bennelong, is productivity. The Opposition says that the accord has failed because there have not been sufficient increases in productivity in Australia. I accept that Australia has not had a great productivity performance, probably going over many decades. But I was a bit bemused to hear the honourable member for Bennelong put this as the great test.

If the honourable member believes that the Government is failing in increasing productivity levels in Australia and that the accord is failing to deliver better productivity, one would assume that the Opposition's own Fightback proposals, its blueprint for Australia, would project better productivity outcomes than are occurring under the accord, which is failing the test.

If we go to page 16 of the Fightback! document, we see the figures by which the Government is supposedly damned by the Opposition. Page 16 tells us that on the OECD figures the rate of Australian productivity increase per annum from 1983 to 1990 was 0.9 per cent. The Opposition says that is a pretty dismal result, that it is fairly poor and that we have to do a lot better in Australia.

In the same document we will look at the three scenarios which the Opposition says are possible outcomes from the implementation of its Fightback proposals. Scenario 1, which is the low result, if you like, predicts a productivity outcome for Australia of 0.4 per cent. That is less than one-half of what the Opposition says was a dismal record flowing from the accord. Anyway, that is the low road. Obviously those opposite do not expect that to happen; they expect much better outcomes than 0.4 per cent.

We go now to the middle road, the middle of the range estimates of what would be the productivity outcome under the Fightback proposals. Lo and behold, the productivity outcome in that scenario is 4.3 per cent—just marginally above what the low road outcome would be. Anyway, those opposite are eternal optimists and no doubt will go to the Australian people and say, `Well, we will not get the low road proposal; we will not get the middle road proposal; our policy will deliver the best possible outcome, the highest possible outcome, according to our projections'. So let us look at what the best possible outcome, the high road outcome, would be for productivity under the Opposition's proposal. Lo and behold, it would be an 0.8 per cent increase in productivity.

Of course, the Government has been attacked for producing a result on OECD figures of 0.9 per cent—but it is higher than the Opposition's best possible case. So this is the important test that the shadow Minister says the Government has failed, the accord has failed—the test of productivity.

The Opposition's policies completely reject the accord and would scrap the whole process. It sees next to no role for the Industrial Relations Commission. Yet the best scenario under its policies has a productivity performance for Australia which is actually less than that which it is criticising the Government for producing under the accord process.

I am not surprised that the goalposts have been moved concerning the accord and the Government's industrial approach. The Opposition would hardly make the important test one relating to industrial disputes. Industrial disputes are never mentioned by our friends opposite because they know that the industrial dispute record under the accord has been absolutely streets ahead of anything that they achieved in their period of government or would be likely to achieve through the so-called new big bang approach to industrial relations—the old `troops on the wharves if it is necessary' line that the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong now promote.

Those opposite do not talk about the important test being industrial disputation because their record was dismal and the accord has cut it by about 60 per cent. In fact, the most recent figures for January 1992 show that days lost through industrial disputation in Australia are at a 30-year low. I do not know whether that is too bad a test for the accord to be judged against or for the Opposition's policies to be judged against.

As I have already outlined, the other test for the accord used to be inflation. Under the accord, we have managed to control the rate of inflation through the very strong boom of the mid- and late 1980s. At that stage unions and employees in many sectors of the economy could have gone out and grabbed much larger wage increases than they did. But through the accord process, through the concept of a social wage, a social contract, we were able to restrain wage demands, which enabled us to come through the boom and into this period of recession—not with double-digit inflation which was the hallmark of the last recession presided over by the Opposition parties, but with a declining inflation rate and one which is now considerably below the OECD average and below those of our major trading partners.

I would have thought that that is also a fairly important test of what the accord has delivered and a fairly important test against which the industrial and other policies of the Opposition should be judged. We know what would happen to inflation under the policies of those opposite. With the introduction of a tax on food and clothing, there must be an inbuilt increase in inflation; the debate would be only about how much inflation would go up. There is no doubt that inflation would go up.

On the third test of productivity, the productivity outcome under the accord process has been higher than would be the case under the three scenarios in the Opposition's proposals. So, if productivity is no longer the great test for the accord to pass, I wonder what the next test will be.

The Industrial Relations Commission does have a role in an enterprise bargaining situation. The Opposition cannot see how it can. It sees it as a vehicle of a central system and that the whole essence of industrial enterprise bargaining is to move to the coalface, the workplace, negotiations between employers and employees. Those opposite argue that in that system there is no role for a central umpire. The Government rejects that for a very important reason: unlike the Opposition we do not see the cost of labour simply as a cost that can be reduced. We do not see labour in there simply with raw materials and the whole rest of it and an attempt being made to minimise the costs, to get them down to the lowest possible total cost. The cost of labour equates with human beings—their wages, salaries, quality of life and ability to lead a decent life on a decent wage.

There may well be many examples of industrial parties equal enough in power for there to be fair enterprise bargaining and fair collective bargaining. That may well be the case in many industries across Australia. But it is not the case in all industries, and I do not believe it is the case in the majority.

The vast majority of the Australian work force works in medium and small businesses. In fact, the vast majority of these particular businesses are not covered by unions. The industrial relations system and the Industrial Relations Commission provide a safety net. They provide a test of public interest so that we know when we test our enterprise bargaining and our agreements that they maintain basic conditions which all Australians, regardless of where they work or what their occupations are, should be entitled to enjoy. That is why there is a role for the Industrial Relations Commission. It is an institution which I have great affection for. I have no doubt that it has a future and that its future will be assured under a Labor government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed in the contribution of the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch). Only one Government representative was scheduled to discuss this important Government initiative and he spent his 20 minutes attacking, first, the shadow Minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard); second, Commissioner Turbet, of the Industrial Relations Commission; and, third, the Opposition's Fightback proposal to rejuvenate this sick nation.

PARA.TAB: He talked at some length in the latter part of his speech about the accord and how it has brought us to a low level of inflation and industrial disputes. That, of course, is not the point of this Bill. Let me point out to the honourable member for Fisher that this country has a staggering unemployment level and that we have been at record levels for a record period of time. If there ain't no jobs, there ain't no pay increases and there ain't no reason for disputes.

This Bill is about changes to the structure and salary mechanisms of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, brought down by the Remuneration Tribunal. This Bill is all about destroying the independence and, therefore, the integrity of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

I think perhaps it might be useful for us today if we had a bit of a history lesson with respect to this Bill. In May 1990, the Remuneration Tribunal brought down a finding recommending a 14 per cent pay increase for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The Government then countered through Senator Cook with a proposal for a 6 per cent increase on 1 July 1990 and a 6 per cent increase in January 1991. The Government then changed its mind and dumped the 1 January 1991 proposal, so essentially the Remuneration Tribunal recommendation of 14 per cent was revised by the Government to 6 per cent.

In November 1990, following `robust' discussions, Senator Cook set up the Gleeson Committee which would report into the structure of the Industrial Relations Commission. On 1 March 1990, the Gleeson Committee report was handed down, adding a vice-president and a senior deputy president. The Gleeson Committee's brief, as I understand it, was to examine the structure of the AIRC and its internal workings. Other issues raised directly or as a necessary consequence of the Committee's terms of reference were the conditions of service and the conditions of status of the AIRC members. The future role of the AIRC and its relationship with other tribunals and the courts was also discussed.
As a preface to the Committee's report, the Committee said that the new structure may:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . also facilitate development of a judicial jurisdiction dealing with industrial matters, for example, a Labour Court or an Industrial Division of the Federal Court, constituted by appropriately qualified AIRC members.
That meant that Senator Cook then had his opportunity to give us his and the ACTU's long awaited, long desired Federal industrial relations court.

PARA.TAB: On 1 March, the Gleeson report made a lot of recommendations. In relation to remuneration, the Committee recommended: first, that there be no legislative nexus with any other group such as Federal judges—so it recommended that we break the Federal judge nexus; second, that there be a salary linkage between the office of the President of the AIRC and the Chief Justice of the Federal Court; third, that there be a salary linkage between the proposed positions of Senior Deputy President and the judges of the Federal Court and that that salary be a benchmark for internal relativities in the new structure; fourth, that the linkage between the Federal Court judges and senior deputy presidents be reviewed at least every five years by the Remuneration Tribunal and also in the case of major changes in judicial remuneration; fifth, that the Government should seek to disallow a Remuneration Tribunal determination only where extraordinary—and I repeat extraordinary—circumstances arise. Today obviously is an extraordinary circumstance because we are here discussing this Bill which is at variance with the Remuneration Tribunal report.

On 20 March 1991, Senator Cook accepted the review. On 28 March, Senator Cook made a submission to the Remuneration Tribunal, and on 16 April the AIRC brought down a national wage case decision with respect to accord mark VI. It substantially rejected mark VI and all holy hell broke loose. The Commission had the audacity to say that the parties, in its view, were not yet mature enough to handle enterprise bargaining. So it brought down its decision with respect to the national wage case at variance with accord mark VI between the ACTU and the Federal Government, represented by the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. From that date literally millions of words have appeared in print, been heard over the airways and been expressed in speeches in this House and elsewhere regarding the appropriateness of the Commission's decision and its role or non-role in the fixing of wages and conditions of employment affecting many millions of employees across the width and breadth of the country.

The issue regarding the role of the Industrial Relations Commission is just one more example of the arrogance of this Government, its lack of response to the will of the people and the denigration of the role of parliament and the judiciary in our democratic society. Last year the Australian Bar Association drew attention to the fact that the independence of the judicial and quasi-judicial bodies in our country was under threat. The Chairman of the Bar Council, Mr D.L. Harper, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . recent action by members of the Federal Government has served to emphasise the immediacy of that threat.

Firstly, the then Treasurer, now our Prime Minister, was reported in the Sunday Age of 5 May 1991 as saying that the Industrial Relations Commission would have to rethink its position or it would not have a position. Secondly, the Minister for Industrial Relations, as reported in the Australian of 6 May 1991 indicated that any determination of the Remuneration Tribunal which sought to pass on benefits of the national wage case to Australia's Federal judiciary would not be implemented. Thirdly, Mr Wally Curran, the Victorian Secretary of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, was reported in the Herald-Sun of 12 May 1991 as having accused the Industrial Relations Commission and the commissioners of lacking ability, obvious bias, hypocrisy, impropriety and incompetence.

PARA.TAB: Fourthly, Mr Bill Kelty, Secretary of the ACTU, was reported in the Australian of 2 May 1991 as having said in relation to the decision of the AIRC:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sickening decision, but there is no reason for the trade union movement to eat the vomit.
Mr Harper, in his statement on behalf of the Victorian Bar Council, went on:

These examples are but the latest in a series. They demonstrate an attempt to downgrade the status and role of the Commonwealth judiciary and of the Industrial Relations Commission. They herald an attack, no doubt unintended, on democracy itself.

PARA.TAB: The issue is not one of benefits for individual members of the judiciary or quasi-judicial bodies. The issue is whether the judiciary can be independent if its pay and conditions are subject to government whim; and whether the Industrial Relations Commission should exercise independence of judgement.

By its actions, the Federal Government has attacked the institutions best positioned to protect democracy against the encroachments of executive power. It has placed the rule of law and the freedoms of a civilised society in jeopardy. It deserves condemnation in the strongest terms.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Harper has rather eloquently stated the major case of concern by all those practising law in Australia. But I remind honourable members that the Industrial Relations Commission is not a court of law; it is in fact a statutory body, a commission, given legitimacy by an Act of Parliament. I have no doubt that the executive members of the Commission, including the President and the Deputy President, consider that the Commission is a court and, as such, is entitled to total independence from both parliament and the executive government.

PARA.TAB: On 8 May 1991 Senator Cook made a supplementary submission with respect to the national wage case. On 15 May 1991 he amended the Industrial Relations Act. It was the second amendment to the Act in 1991. Its purpose was to amend the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to give effect to the recommendations of this Gleeson Committee's review of the structure of the Industrial Relations Commission, including the creation of new positions of Vice-President and Senior Deputy President.
The honourable member for Bennelong, in his speech to that Bill, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I did not lament the breaking of the nexus between the salary and remuneration of presidential members of the Commission and judges of the Federal Court because I do not regard—and nor does the Opposition—the Industrial Relations Commission as being a court.
He went on to say:
It is because Amendment Bill (No. 2) in part anticipates the establishment of a labour court that the Opposition will oppose the Bill in this House and it will be opposed in the other place

And with good cause. This side of the House has always been opposed to a labour court. I return to the history. On 30 November 1991, six months after royal assent, the amendment came into effect. On 24 December 1991 the Remuneration Tribunal reported, and, once again, all holy hell broke loose. That resulted, I might say, in the now famous—or infamous—letter from Mr Ken Turbet, Commissioner of the Industrial Relations Commission. I would like to quote part of that letter for the record. It states:
Dear Minister—
and after an opening paragraph—

PARA.TAB: The reasons for my resignation after 14 years as a commission member, which was preceded by 16 years service to the trade union movement and 20 years membership of the Australian Labor Party, are three-fold.

First, the Government cannot be relied upon to keep its word. A classic and simple example is your about-face on the Gleeson Committee's recommendation in regard to recognition of the Remuneration Tribunal.
Second, actions by you and the Government have damaged the public's perception of the independence and integrity of the AIRC.
Finally, my third and most compelling reason for resigning is your government's total lack of understanding of the respect for the constitutional requirements of Section 51(XXCV) of the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: His final paragraph, which is informative, states:

PARA.TAB: A public institution such as the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, whose decisions either directly, or indirectly through our state counterparts, impact upon every working Australian and their families, can only function effectively when it has the respect of the government which established and maintains it, the organisations which use it, and the employers and workers of our nation who are required to abide by its decisions. Currently, respect from our government is lacking.
Minister, it is for these reasons that I reluctantly leave the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.
Yours faithfully,
Ken Turbet
Commissioner.

SPEECH.PARA: A report in the Herald-Sun by Andrew Bolt, following the Commissioner's resignation, states:

PARA.TAB: Mr Turbet said he didn't have any help from other commission members in drafting his devastating resignation letter, although one senior member later said almost everyone agreed with every word in it.

SPEECH.PARA: That is, I would maintain, another damning indictment by a now resigned member, a highly respected member, of that Commission of this Government, of the Minister, of this Bill and of all the actions that this Government has taken since the April 1991 national wage case, which started this whole round of denigration of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

PARA.TAB: But it has not finished; it goes on. In the Australian of 1 May, we come back to Wally Curran again. Mr Curran sent a letter to the editor of the Australian, which it published on 1 May, and I quote:
Over recent weeks there have been many articles written and comments made about the future of the Industrial Relations Commission, and the commissioners' entitlement to a pay increase.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on:

Since 1989 members of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union have had to endure an antagonistic industrial climate created by the commission which was subsequently corrected by the intervention of the ACTU.

So Wally Curran says, `Well, the ACTU can get it right and the union gets it right. But, boy, this Australian Industrial Relations Commission! It has some problems because it just doesn't understand our industry. We are a very different industry. No matter who it assigns to look at us, it gets it wrong'. He goes on:

PARA.TAB: History will record the fact that the commissioners handling our cases had no knowledge of the industry and accepted without question the arguments put forward by the employers.
In contrast to the commission's incompetency. . .

SPEECH.PARA: And he goes on to define what the union has to offer `in contrast to the commission's incompetency'. It is my view that Mr Curran has done everything possible now to bring into disrepute the Industrial Relations Commission. It is my view that he has been aided and abetted by members of the Government, by other members of the union bureaucracy and by the ACTU itself in all this on the Government's own organisation.

PARA.TAB: It is very difficult for me to understand, to cope with and to condone this continuing attempt to reduce the value of this Commission in the minds of the public, in the minds of the employers and in the minds of the workers, when in fact it is this Government's device to keep the accord alive. I realise that, at the moment, the Secretary of the ACTU is the puppeteer. He has on the strings our newly unelected Prime Minister, who dances to the tune and to the shots that are called by the Secretary of the ACTU.

If they do not like what the umpire says, if they do not like the verdicts from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, they feel entitled to say what they like. They pass that down the line. In this case, they passed it down the line to Mr Curran, who went on to say at the end of his letter to the editor of the Australian:

Unless there is an absolutely honest approach regarding the right of anyone to seek employment in the commission, then the status quo will continue and mainly incompetent and underqualified people will continue to be employed.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter is signed:
WALLY CURRAN
Secretary
Victorian Branch
Australasian Meat
Industry Employees Union
Carlton.

That is an indictment of the Government; it is an indictment of its entire approach; it is an indictment of this Bill, which, unfortunately, had to be brought down in this place to deny the Remuneration Tribunal its day in the sun. Now we do not have the Remuneration Tribunal any more, because the only two surviving members of a three-member tribunal are leaving as well. Everyone is fed up with this Government; fed up with its tie to its union mates; and fed up with the denigration of the umpire. We are all fed up. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the previous speaker, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), in raising these industrial relations matters. I know of his great knowledge on this subject and his concern about the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. Whilst it is quite clear on this side of the House that the Industrial Relations Commission will have a lesser role when we are in government, it is a remarkable feat by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and this Government to chop down the Industrial Relations Commission by stealth and the sort of antics that the previous speaker has alluded to.

PARA.TAB: As the shadow Minister for industrial relations, employment and training, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), has said, we have been quite clear and up-front about what will be the role of the Commission when we are in government. Yet this Government, by the very actions that other speakers have alluded to, is removing the Australian umpire for industrial relations, as the Government sees it.

The Remuneration and Allowances Legislation Amendment Bill allegedly seeks to create a new salary structure for members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission by initiating a different nexus between the salaries of the Commission appointees and the Federal Court judges. In doing so, if the Bill is passed, it will effectively overturn the Remuneration Tribunal's determination No. 21 of 1991. The Bill will also end the necessity for the Chairman of the Remuneration Tribunal to be a judge, either active or retired, or to be qualified to be a judge in a State court. The Bill was introduced under the auspices of the Minister for Industrial Relations, who has been referred to by other speakers.
On 31 March in the Australian, Paddy McGuinness gave what I thought was a rather apt new title to the Minister when he described him as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Minister assisting the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Secretary of the ACTU (Mr Kelty).

Paddy McGuinness sees where the allegiances of the Minister really lie. This is a very serious charge to make, but it is supportable. I suggest that the Minister, a former office bearer with the Building Workers Industrial Union, has produced measures time after time that seek to place a large gap between those who have powers bestowed on them by the industrial relations club and those outside this historical anachronism.

PARA.TAB: According to the Government, those in the IR club are those who are unionised, the militant, those in the public sector, and those who refuse to adapt to the 1990s by sticking with outdated Luddite approaches, such as needing a highly paid umpire to always mediate between employers and employees. Those outside the inner circle include the non-unionised, the subcontractors, the unemployed and those who work for small firms in the private sector.

What ideas does one of the men the Minister is accused of serving, the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty, have for the future of the Australian industrial relations system, the Commission based in Nauru House and the union movement in Australia? In a very revealing piece of evidence in the AIRC hearing on 13 September 1990, Mr Kelty spelt out his view rather succinctly when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: (We must) create a new wages system. . .involving . . . a diminution of the authority of bodies such as the ACTU; bodies such as the conciliation and arbitration commission of Australia, as more and more is done where more and more has to be done, and that is in the workplaces of this country. . .

It is debatable whether more is in fact being achieved in the workplaces of this country, for only about 90 new workplace deals under what the Government laughingly calls a corrupted enterprise bargaining system have been actually concluded. There is no provision for groups of workers, other than the 40 per cent of Australians who are union members, to conclude the agreements. It is very important for members of this House and the electors of Australia to understand that only union members, under the auspices of the so-called enterprise agreements that the Government has drawn up, are entitled to conclude these enterprise agreements. This is a classic case of restrictive trade practices; only unionists can draw up these agreements.

PARA.TAB: I want to concern myself largely with the provisions of the Bill that seek to alter the pay alternatives for Industrial Relations Commission members. The Industrial Relations Commission is a body that has grown in recent years, despite the savage recession that has seen the number in full time employment drop from 4.2 million in December 1990 to just on four million today.

A look at the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's last two annual reports indicates that the number of office bearers, be they commissioners, deputy commissioners or others, has gone from 47 on 1 June 1990 to 53 on 1 June 1991. A similar number of disputes was notified under section 99 of the Act in each year—that is, 3,600 disputes. So we needed more commissioners to handle the same number of disputes. One can only conclude that the complexity of individual disputes has increased, which is logical as the atmosphere of compromise, so valiantly proclaimed by the Hawke-Keating Government since the adoption of the accord, has begun to dissipate.

In the last Industrial Relations Commission annual report, some 98 possible areas of dispute were listed, of which the vast majority had entries during that year. Let me list some of these strange entries. They include leading-hand allowances, allowances for reimbursement of expenses, allowances for tools, travel and clothing, as well as trade union membership. Many of these matters are trivial and should hardly take up the time of a government body. Little wonder that many commentators are suggesting that Australia needs a new broom to sweep through the morass of industrial relations provisions.

The background to this Bill is controversial, very largely because of the recent resignation of Commissioner Ken Turbet, a longstanding member of the industrial relations club and the Labor Party. Other members of the coalition have referred to this. I, like other members on this side of the House, would like to quote from Commissioner Turbet's letter of resignation, because it sets on the public record a remarkable attitude of mind by the commissioner towards the Government and his concern about the role of the Industrial Relations Commission in 1992. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government cannot be relied upon to keep its word. A classic example. . . is your about face on the Gleeson Committee's recommendation in regard to recognition of the Remuneration Tribunal. . . The Government accepts that it should only seek to disallow determinations in exceptional circumstances. . . There are 15 pages (supporting the decision). . . The actions of the Government have damaged the public's perception of the Industrial Relations Commission. . . (It) can only work effectively when it has the respect of the Government.

What an indictment of the Government that is by a man who is almost an ex-commissioner of the Industrial Relations Commission, which the Government is so clearly undermining. That is from a man with 14 years as a commissioner, another 16 years as a trade union official and, to add insult to injury, another 20 years as a member of the ALP. What more authority could we have for the sorts of comments that he makes about the Government and its attitude towards the Industrial Relations Commission?

PARA.TAB: The Remuneration Tribunal has been given a Government mandate to make decisions with regard to the fixing of those salaries at the IRC. One would have thought that the normal procedure would not be varied unless absolutely extraordinary circumstances arose, as Mr Turbet pointed out. The Remuneration Tribunal noted on page 5 of its 1992 review:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government was invited to submit reasons why such a distinction (between fixing the level of remuneration of a presidential member of the Industrial Relations Commission at 95 per cent rather than 100 per cent of that given to a relevant judge of the Federal Court) should be made. . . No acceptable reasons were provided for such a change.

Has there been the necessary extraordinary alteration in circumstances that would warrant government intervention? There has been none, and nothing has been proven to date. Discord has certainly emerged from the Industrial Relations Commission, based in Nauru House. The resignation of Mr Turbet is just the tip of the iceberg, as I understand it, because of the Government's attitude to the Commission and to the commissioners at a personal level. The honourable member for La Trobe demonstrated that by quoting some remarks of Mr Wally Curran, the Secretary of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union.

PARA.TAB: As I say, there has been much disquiet amongst the office-bearers who are left. The lawyers, who have given the Commission a balance and enabled it to determine very complex issues, are leaving and are being replaced by appointees from the ACTU. Previous governments tried very hard to make appointments that kept a balance between the employers and the unions. It is obvious—and it was defended here by the Minister in the House—that the Government is going to `even it up', so-called. When one of the union appointees resigns, the Government will `even up' the numbers by appointing a further union person.

The Bill really conceals a much wider issue of industrial relations. The question of remuneration for these senior personnel in the Industrial Relations Commission has to be looked at as a small part of the overall industrial relations strategy of this Government. In Australia we now have a corporate style of government where big unions, big government and big business seem to act in unison. Anyone outside these groups is hardly listened to. That is exactly what the retired Commissioner suggested: nobody would listen and nobody had respect for the arrangements that the Government was imposing upon the Commission.

Let me remind the House that in the private sector, union coverage is down to 31 per cent, and still falling. The figure is much worse because, typically, 15 per cent of those union members are unfinancial. I repeat: private sector union coverage is down to 31 per cent. People around Australia should be very aware of that fact. The Industrial Relations Commission is based on unions being registered and members of the work force being paid-up members of various unions.

Of the three groups, big business fares worst. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 March headed, `When Kelty speaks, Keating listens', the industrial editor, Brad Norrington, in part, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Shortly before Christmas 1989, Keating and Kelty agreed that a reworking of the accord would see unions bargaining at industry or workplace level according to some vague notion of improved productivity and profitability . . .
Norrington went on:

. . . deals . . . are routinely tied up ahead of official negotiations by Paul Keating and Bill Kelty with little outside input . . . The problem for the political process of the accord is that it no longer has any proper checks and balances.

Most of the award restructuring presently under way is being driven by the needs of the peak union body, the ACTU. Little attention is being paid by this Government to whether alternative models of workplace bargaining are possible or, in fact, what the Industrial Relations Commission might think about it. Why cannot common law contracts be encouraged, as we on this side of the House are advocating? At least, unlike many determinations of a centralised and rather rigid Industrial Relations Commission, these outcomes are market derived. Depending on the profitability of various industries, voluntary contracts could be entered into. Australians have to remember that they cannot live in lotus land any longer, and the one million unemployed would give testimony to that.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Government regards the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and its members as an integral part of the domestic institutional set-up; at least, it did until the recent conflict between the Government and the Commission, which in part created the controversy over this Bill. Mr Kelty has now decided to let the Commission down by any means possible and destroy the role of the Commission in industrial relations arrangements.

The accord is a direct relationship between the ACTU and the Government, rather than individual unions. To give the accord political legitimacy, the Industrial Relations Commission has had to agree to the methods employed by the ACTU to broaden its influence amongst the Ministers of this corporatist government. A very important factor is that inevitably the Industrial Relations Commission had to agree to the provisions of the accord.
How has the ACTU done this? It has adopted a policy of strategic unionism which, as the ACTU explained in Australia Reconstructed, means:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . A high level of (union), resources. . . supplemented by contributions from the general community through government expenditure . . .

Some of these contributions from the Government, such as the funding of artists in residence at the Victorian Trades Hall Council, would be well beyond the imagination of many of the office-bearers of the Industrial Relations Commission or the Remuneration Tribunal.

PARA.TAB: The ACTU, which seems to be determining the payments that will be made to members of the Industrial Relations Commission, often makes strident claims about the success of the so-called accord which commenced in 1983. The Australian community is repeatedly told that the accord has created hundreds of thousands of jobs, led to a stable industrial relations environment and allowed for low inflation.

The evidence, at best, is contradictory. The period from 1979 to 1987 is a good period to consider some facts, as the first mentioned year was midway through the Fraser period and the end year was midway through the accord period of so-called compromise, when the bosses were called names if they even lifted a finger against anyone taking a sickie.

The crucial factor is not whether Australia's performance improved compared with the previous period, but whether Australia could hold its head up against other industrialised nations. Certainly between 1979 and 1987 there was a 71 per cent fall in industrial disputes, measured in strike days lost per 1,000 employees, but the average fall amongst Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, Sweden, the UK and the USA was 78 per cent per thousand employees. Other factors were at work around the world and in Australia.

More alarmingly, Australia's labour productivity has grown more slowly than that of OECD nations. Between 1973 and 1979, prior to the accord, Australia's average increase was 1.6 per cent against an OECD average of 1.8 per cent. After the accord commenced, the figure for Australia was 1.1 per cent and that for the OECD, 1.8 per cent. In other words, Australia's ratio of productivity improvement against that of the OECD declined from 89 points to 61 points—a disastrous performance. No wonder Australia has been slipping down the totem pole of international competitiveness!

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the Remuneration Tribunal, the Keating Government, as well as all its allies in the trade union movement, enter the 1990s with the Kelty-Keating relationship riding high. Why should this Parliament be spending valuable time debating matters such as whether judges of the IRC should have their salaries cut by 5 per cent or 6 per cent when our performance is not keeping pace with that of the rest of the world?

The Opposition has been looking very closely at the changed industrial relations system in New Zealand. Only this morning, the dramatic nature of what those changes could do to the profitability of companies and the country in general was demonstrated. I refer to a press clipping from the Australian newspaper of this morning entitled `Smelter rejoices in labour reform'. In that article Mr Stewart, the Managing Director of the Comalco company, pointed out the dramatic changes that had taken place under the new industrial relations arrangements introduced by that Government. He pointed out some quite remarkable changes in the Comalco works when the industrial relations climate and background was changed by statute. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . labour productivity had improved spectacularly. The number of man-hours required to produce one tonne of aluminium dropped 31 per cent, and is still declining.

PARA.TAB: Equipment refitting was significantly quicker . . .
Electricity use was approaching best practice, having increased by more than 3 per cent.
Inputs were manufactured faster . . .

Product quality had improved because more care was being taken . . . Equipment was not damaged as often and was repaired faster when damaged. For example, downtime for the critical potline cranes had dropped 44 per cent.

Over-manning and overtime abuse had ceased. Since last year the . . . workforce had dropped 210 to nearly 1300. No overtime was worked because no overtime was paid under universal staff . . . contracts.
The crude cost of labour had declined 17 per cent per tonne of aluminium produced.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to compliment the reforms that had taken place in his company. He was amazed at the change of attitude by management and the employees, and at the dramatic increase in the profitability of that company because changes had taken place in the industrial relations approach of those concerned with industry in New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: I conclude with that more positive view of what can be done if the coalition's industrial relations policies are implemented—and they will be implemented—along the lines of the changes that have been brought about in New Zealand. The importance of the Industrial Relations Commission will be somewhat diminished under a coalition government, but at least it will not be attacked in such a stealthy manner as this Government has done on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few remarks on the Remuneration and Allowances Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. I am not sure that there will be anything new in them, as the debate so far has probably canvassed the issues that are involved. However, as previous speakers have said, industrial relations is assuming increasing importance on this side of the House. We see the need for change in the industrial relations system as being absolutely vital if this country is to be turned around. For my part, at least, I take quite an interest in that subject.

PARA.TAB: Last week I participated in a debate on the reform of the construction industry, and in that particular speech I catalogued in some detail the concerns that the Opposition has about the Government's handling of industrial relations. This legislation highlights those concerns. In many respects the Bill is not of itself momentous, but it is the background to this Bill which casts a considerable shadow over it and, indeed, over the Government's handling of industrial relations as a whole.

The unique relationship between the Labor Government and the union movement, particularly the ACTU, is self-evident. The current President of the ACTU, Martin Ferguson, has said that he sees the ACTU as a partner in government with the ALP. There is great concern in the community about this particular relationship. A number of speakers have alluded to the so-called Keating-Kelty relationship which, in many respects, is a very suspicious one indeed, particularly the extent of that relationship evidenced in the overthrow of the former Prime Minister. The whole process of that coup started at Kirribilli House in Sydney. Mr Kelty was present as Mr Keating's ally in the arrangement that was to be made for the supposed orderly hand-over of power. We now know that that did not eventuate in any shape or form. The overthrow did come, but there was much blood on the floor.

Our suspicions about the role of the ACTU in industrial relations in this country have been confirmed consistently. They have been proven to be well and truly on the nose. A number of speakers in this debate, including the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who led for the Opposition, spoke about the fact that it has recently come to a head with the resignations of a number of members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Some of those members, including the President, publicly expressed grave doubts about the independence of the Commission.

I do not believe that the Opposition, in pointing to these circumstances, is in any way grasping at straws. The embarrassment that the Government has suffered over the resignation of Ken Turbet in particular must be extreme. The Government has been able to refute very little of the criticism that Mr Turbet heaped upon it. He comprehensively tipped a bucket on the Government from a great height. In the debate honourable members have spoken of the qualifications Mr Turbet had. They referred to his experience, the background and the context in which he was able to make his remarks. There was no doubt that all of us were astounded by what he had to say from his perspective, in the way that he quit his job and attacked the Government on the way out.

I do not want to cast any aspersions on current serving members of the Commission, but when we pick up one of Ken Turbet's criticisms it is interesting to note the composition of the Commission as it is today. There are 13 deputy presidents who have been appointed since the election of the Labor Government in March 1983. Five of them have union backgrounds, five more practised as industrial lawyers, one is a former Labor politician and one is a leading academic. So there has been a very strong connection. The role of the Commission has in many respects been influenced, and to some extent usurped, by the ACTU. In that sense it is no wonder that Ken Turbet had that parting shot at the Government as evidence of his and, indeed, Deputy President Russell Peterson's growing disenchantment with the Commission.

We have to look back a short time to see how this disenchantment grew. We go back to the April 1991 national wage decision. For Ken Turbet and others that was really a watershed. It exposed the full extent of Government and ACTU interference in, and to an extent, I suspect, intimidation of, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. In that decision the Commission, to its credit, and acting responsibly, refused to endorse the key elements of the accord mark VI, as it was then. It attempted to exercise some independence, as it was bound to do.

We know what the results of that were. The claims for a $12 increase, 3 per cent superannuation improvements and variation of the no extra claims commitment to provide for additional enterprise claims were knocked on the head by the Commission. With some consternation we observed the reaction of the ACTU. The decision had not been rubber-stamped on this occasion. This particular Keating-Kelty deal was not the subject of immediate compliance or acquiescence by the AIRC. We saw some distinctly colourful language flowing from Mr Kelty's mouth as he described the decision as a rotten egg that would not be eaten, and various other abusive terminology was subsequently used. The ACTU wages committee then decided to reject that particular decision. At the time the Confederation of Australian Industry in its newsletter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The ACTU appears to be caught up in its own invective: what the ACTU decides should occur, must occur, or it will take all action open to it to cause damage.

In other words, we saw that, if the ACTU did not like it, it would turn around and lump the AIRC. The Confederation of Australian Industry also described it as extraordinary that the Government was taking the drastic course of encouraging the ACTU in its rejection of that particular decision. It was not only encouraging but aiding and abetting, I would suggest.

PARA.TAB: For its part, the ACTU was committed only to the principle of self-determination. The union movement, in conjunction with the ALP, was determined that it would decide the outcome of the national wage proceedings. The role of the Commission was to be a rubber stamp. If it was not prepared to be a rubber stamp and implement what the ACTU and the Government put to it without too much delay, it would incur the wrath and invective of the ACTU.

This contempt for the processes of the Commission was also associated with a concerted attack on the independence of the Commission. The ACTU apparently induced the Government to introduce legislation which broke the statutory link which had existed between the salaries of deputy presidents of the Commission and Federal Court judges. It replaced that link with a separate process of assessment by the Remuneration Tribunal. That separate assessment process would, of course, be influenced by submissions put to it by the Commonwealth and the ACTU.

We know the history of this also. The outcry from the Commission and employers led the Government to rush off and form a committee to try to extricate itself from the embarrassing situation it found itself in, and the Gleeson inquiry resulted. The AIRC's new structure was adopted consequently in opposition to the AIRC's views. The Federal coalition opposed those changes at that time because of the ACTU's blatant intervention in the Remuneration Tribunal's determination process.

From all of this, and from what other speakers have said, we see that the ACTU continues to be a law unto itself. It holds itself out in so many respects to be above the law that every other Australian individual and entity is subject to. The Australian newspaper in its editorial on 24 April summed up the situation pretty well. It did so after Ken Turbet tipped the bucket on the Government. The heading for that particular editorial was `Cook's industrial mixed relations'. That seems to be pretty descriptive of what industrial relations is all about from the Government's point of view.

The editorial goes on to outline very clearly the duplicity of the Government's and the Minister's approach to industrial relations. The Government is caught in suspended animation in respect of industrial relations. It realises that change is in the wind. In fact, it has become more than a wind; it has almost become a hurricane.

The Government realises belatedly that we as a country have been left behind the rest of the world in respect of wage fixing practices. However, instead of biting the bullet and doing something about it, the Government is paralysed by its relationship with its union mates. It has chosen, as the Australian also points out on this occasion, to subvert the Commission and `bully it into accepting its anomalous form of accordian enterprise bargaining'. No wonder Commissioner Turbet had had a gutful of this hypocrisy. To his great credit—and I have never met the man—

TALK.START.PARA: —A strong man.

—The honourable member for Bennelong tells me he is a strong man. I have never met him but, to his credit, even though he had eight years to go before he was due to retire and he could have seen it out, he was not prepared to sit there and put up with this sort of hypocrisy. He decided to retire. Predictably, some of his former union mates have been very quick to vilify and attempt to discredit him. Once again, we see the true Labor Party coming out. There have been plenty of examples of it. This sort of attempt to vilify a former mate is almost standard operating procedure for the ALP.

PARA.TAB: A former Deputy President of the IRC, Jim Staples, who I suspect knows a bit about the goings on there also, was even more pointed in his comments in the Sydney Morning Herald. His article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Industrial Relations Commission is now dead in the water, gutted by the Hawke-Keating-Kelty Government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Jim doesn't like us much, either.
—The honourable member for Bennelong is anticipating me. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . awaiting only interment by the Hewson Opposition.

Jim Staples goes on to refer to the steady undermining of the IRC's independence since 1980. I am not sure that we are talking about interring the IRC, but—and I am sure the honourable member for Bennelong will agree—we will deal properly and openly with the AIRC when the time comes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get rid of it.

—We will not get rid of it. We see a place for it. But whatever we do with it will contrast markedly with what the Government has done with it. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro wants to enter this debate. His Government has sought to undermine it; it has attempted by stealth to discredit the Commission, to undermine it, to lean on it and to do whatever it can. At least we will deal openly, honestly and properly with the Commission. I think the way we handle that situation will contrast markedly with what the Government has done.

PARA.TAB: We do propose radical change in the field of industrial relations. There is no doubt in most people's minds that radical change is what Australia needs. The Bill that we are dealing with tonight is the end, or least perhaps the end for the time being, of a whole sorry saga in respect of the salary, conditions and qualifications of the IRC commissioners. The end result is a significant downgrading of the IRC. That is the sad result, in many respects, of a long and convoluted process.

When the Remuneration Tribunal recommended substantial increases in salaries in 1990, Kelty subverted the process. He did it with the encouragement, aid and abetment of the person who is Prime Minister today. Of course, the rest is history. The Government stands condemned for its acquiescence in this whole sorry saga. The Opposition will not dirty its hands by supporting this legislation.
