TALK.START.PARA: —I will be making a very short speech to indicate to the House that the Opposition will not be opposing the Commonwealth Employment (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, consistent with the constructive approach that the Opposition always takes to legislation in this House. In other words, we will be taking an approach of agreeing with something that is sensible and along the lines of the path of true reform which is advocated by the Opposition. It is our intention not to oppose this legislation.

PARA.TAB: It is no exaggeration to say that one of the reasons why this piece of legislation has come forward is a consequence of the urging by the coalition, especially in another place, that the Government progressively implement the recommendations of the Brown committee of inquiry into the Comcare system. The House may recall that, at the time of the last debate on amendments to this particular piece of legislation, the Government was somewhat castigated by the Senate for not having implemented the amendments that were recommended—or all of the amendments, or sufficient of the amendments—by the Brown committee of inquiry.

We are very pleased to see that, in this particular situation, the Government has decided to remedy that. We are especially pleased to see that the Government has decided to license Telecom and Australia Post to perform the functions of Comcare. We also support the greater movement towards the adoption of a user-pays principle in relation to the services of Comcare. In our view, that is a very welcome development.
In his news release titled `Comcare Australia Heading for Competition' of 29 April 1992, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) said:

SPEECH.PARA: A new business plan to take the Federal Government's Workers' Compensation Authority . . . from its position as a government monopoly to a more commercially competitive enterprise will be launched at 10am, Thursday April 30, in the Grand Ballroom, National Convention Centre, in Canberra.

I share all of the aspirations contained in those words. We certainly have no argument with attempts to make the Comcare organisation more competitive. Most of the moves that are contained in this legislation are along those lines.

PARA.TAB: The House will be aware that, on many occasions when legislation in my portfolio area comes before this Parliament, I spend all of my allotted time castigating the incredibly inadequate industrial relations policy of the Government and its insensitive attitude towards high levels of unemployment. On this occasion I do not intend to use my allotted 30 minutes, because the amendments proposed by the Government are sensible. There is not much point spending 30 minutes saying that the Government is sensible. In fact, it is almost anti the interests of the Opposition for me to spend 30 minutes saying that the Government is sensible. I am content to say in a few minutes that the Government is sensible on this Bill and leave it to others, who may have a variety of views on whether the Government is sensible, to participate in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too support the Commonwealth Employment (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, which makes a number of important reforms. They are not highly significant, other than in respect of the fact that we need to take some of the directions that have been outlined by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). It is good that there has been a vast improvement in efficiency and in arrangements for workers compensation and its payments through Comcare. There have been a great number of improvements, but there is still a need, for instance, for a system of licensing for self-insurance and in-house claims management.

PARA.TAB: This legislation meets with flexibility and more efficiency some of the needs that have been found in the workers compensation area. Under the Bill Commonwealth authorities can have three types of licences. They can have a class 1 licence, under which they operate as self-insurers and compensate their employees; they can have a class 2 licence, under which they can determine their own claims; or they can have a class 3 licence, under which they can self-insure and also determine the claims of employees.

As the honourable member for Bennelong said, we see here the adoption of the user-pays principle. We also see that guidelines are laid down by the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees. There have been some extremely important changes in safety attitudes within the workplace. I recall that when I became the member for Eden-Monaro nearly 10 years ago, I went to a sawmill and presented a number of safety awards to people at that sawmill. Most of the people who received the safety awards had one or two fingers missing and one had his arm missing from the elbow.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can always tell when you are in a timber town. They've always got fingers missing.
—I remind the honourable member for Throsby that the timber industry is extremely important. I am sure he would not like me to criticise the coal industry. They are both very important industries.

PARA.TAB: Nowadays, when one goes to a sawmill, one sees that the younger people are in much better order. No longer do they have that pride factor that seemed to stop people taking the important safety precautions that they are now taking. When I recently went to the Nimmitabel sawmill, there were men and women observing safety precautions in the proper way. The legislation is an important component as we work towards both safety and rehabilitation, and it implements a number of both minor and fairly important measures. I am pleased to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support the Commonwealth Employment (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and the remarks of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). Comcare, which is another mechanism for workers compensation, is an issue of some importance throughout the Australian community. It is, of course, a very important industrial relations issue. We have used traditionally a number of mechanisms to financially support those workers who, through no fault of their own, have been injured at work.

PARA.TAB: Traditionally, Australian industry has not taken well its obligations to its work force or its responsibilities in training its work force to prevent injuries at work. It seems to me that one of the most important aspects of modern management, in terms of this whole industrial relations debate, is its being able to get the maximum cooperation and the maximum productivity from the individuals who work for an enterprise. So whatever it is that the company produces—whether it is meals for a restaurant, mouse-traps or automobiles—or whatever it might be engaged in in the training sector, the people who work together in the enterprise do so to produce some useful product or service that people in the community want. In producing that product or service, the enterprise is allowed to generate an income in a manner competitive with like enterprises, both here and overseas, and some portion of it is distributed to the people who make up the enterprise itself and have produced the useful work.

Because of the centralisation of our industrial relations system and because of the concept of conciliation and arbitration in a semi-legalistic sort of system, we have set up artificial boundaries. We have tended to create an atmosphere, an ethos, in which management sits on one side, as Labor sits on one side of the table in this chamber, and the work force sits on the other side, as the Opposition sits on the other side of table in this place. That concept of division and divisiveness surely must come to an end. And it must come to an end quickly because our foreign debt, which is now over $145 billion, is not slowing. Our current account is still in deficit.

It is important that we consider the need to create a more productive Australian economy. In order to produce it, we need cooperation from one side of the table to the other. We do not get cooperation with confrontation; we get it by talking together and working together. It seems to me that management's attitude that if management supplied the workplace, it was the workers' responsibility to work safely, and if workers did not, it was their problem if they got hurt, is as archaic as the centralisation of our industrial relations system itself.

In this day and age, it behoves those who own the business or the enterprise to work with the people doing any physical or other work in the enterprise and to come together to arrive at mechanisms for preventing injury at work. The mechanism that we use to pay individuals who cannot work because they have been injured creates great divisiveness across our nation. There is no question about that. Many of the State systems have created tremendous angst in the unions and among employers. In my State of Victoria, there is an ongoing debate over WorkCare. On one side, the system is seen to be full of rorts and, on the other side, it is seen to be not sensitive enough to compensate those individuals who might be hurt.

Safety in the workplace is an attitudinal problem as well as a cooperative problem. We need to work towards a solution. If we attempt to prescribe safety as we are attempting to prescribe training and superannuation, and as we have prescribed compulsory union membership, then we will of course fail. We will not reach new plateaus of safety records because, by prescribing, we will not gain the hearts and minds of those who are doing the work and who need to be protected.

We need to develop a cooperative approach. Any company with modern management knows that its most important asset is its people. If it can protect its people, if it can enthuse its people and if it can bring its people to become involved in the ethos of that enterprise, the enterprise has a much greater chance of success than it ever would with any system of confrontation or prescription.

In relation to the issue of safety, it is my view that we need a training mechanism. We need to address the issue of literacy—which I have spoken about a number of times in this place—with respect to workplace safety. Australians and migrants who, as yet, are without Australian citizenship but who have come to live in Australia and accept the benefits of our society, want work. If they have not accepted the benefits and taken advantage of English as second language programs in order to develop English language skills, they will find themselves severely disadvantaged in the workplace.

Today, of course, their chances of finding a job if they do not have one are probably quite remote. But we need to make sure that our new Australians and our migrants gain the English language skills that they need in order to do their job, to give them a satisfactory understanding of the society in which they live, and to understand the requirements of their workplace.

In regard to the safety issue, it is important that they be able to read safety signs and notices, that they be able to read rule books with respect to safety practices in the workplace, and that these rule books be developed in a cooperative manner in consultative committees by the work force and those who own the enterprise. A number of issues are critical to Australia's gaining a new ethos: one of work in a safe environment to prevent injury and to keep our valuable asset—the work force—employed in a productive manner.

One other issue that I would like to address very briefly before I give way to the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford), who I know has some very important messages in relation to this particular Bill, is the business of Commonwealth Government bureaucratic organisations having preference clauses for union membership and, in some cases, prescribing compulsory union membership. I have spoken in this House on a number of occasions about voluntary membership of organisations.

It seems clear to me that it is only the Government—the public sector in this country—that props up union membership to the level it is at today. Whereas union membership is now 30 per cent or less as a percentage of the private work force, the government sector of the work force is highly unionised. The Government helps to promote that mechanism by automatically deducting union dues from employees' wages. This makes it all so easy for employees to belong to a union, whether or not they receive any benefits from the union or whether or not they wish to be members.

This issue of compulsory union membership concerns one of our most basic freedoms: the freedom of membership of an association. Just as we have freedom of speech, freedom to write, and freedom to breathe the air, we should also have the freedom to associate with those with whom we wish to associate. Compulsory union membership is an abhorrent system which is imposed on many of those in the work force in this country, and nowhere in greater numbers than in the public sector.

In attempting to lift productivity in the public sector while we talk about raising productivity levels in the private sector, in my view it is critical to our approach that we abolish any compulsory union membership, that we abolish preference clauses, and that we abolish automatic deduction of union dues. The Opposition supports this legislation and I thank the House for its indulgence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Employment (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, which will not be opposed by the Opposition, introduces three distinct amendments to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. Even though this Bill will not be opposed, I want to point out some basic problems and offer some basic criticisms.

PARA.TAB: The first amendment will allow the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees to licence other government authorities and other government departments. Here we have what I believe is the ridiculous situation of one bureaucracy actually licensing another bureaucracy.

Commonwealth authority will be granted by the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees. This new bureaucracy will be able to grants three types of licences: firstly, the whole, or part, of Comcare's obligations to compensate employees; secondly, the whole, or part, of Comcare's function in determining its employees' claims; and, thirdly, a combination of the above. The licensing system will allow particular authority to cover all, or part, of Comcare's obligations to compensate its employees. Needless to say, in practical terms, this process is basically another job creation scheme for Labor's new constituency: the new class trendies with their degrees from the Dawkins's universities.

What will the taxpayers have at the end of the day? They will have more bureaucrats and another expensive and unaccountable group of quangos—mostly secure in their Canberra bunker and far removed from the problems of real Australia. The employees of the Commission and all involved in the supervision will, of course, enjoy the perks so essential to oil the wheels of bureaucracy and ensure the nation's continued prosperity: security of tenure, regular salaries, travel, flexitime, training programs, study leave and so on. Yet what expertise will they have had in this type of insurance—surely it is an insurance problem? Does the Commission plan to employ actuaries and others with expertise in the insurance field? If not, why not?

Each existing bureaucracy will, therefore, be expanded to include its own employee compensation department—or what might be called SICOs: sinecures in Commonwealth offices. Once established, these SICOs will take on a life of their own. They will multiply and proliferate and they will cost millions of taxpayers' dollars. Every department will have one, all staffed by highly qualified permanent graduates whose work basically duplicates what is already available in the private marketplace.

Government departments operate with privately built motors cars; why can they not use private insurers? How many SICOs will be established, I ask? If one goes through the Commonwealth Government Directory one finds that there are literally hundreds of departments spread throughout Australia. I question whether each one of these will have its own little Comcare type section. Will these apply to each location? For instance, the Department of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and the Department of Administrative Services operate in each State and offer a wide variety of services in each State. At what level will these licences be issued? If each one of these departments gets a licence to operate, surely there will be hundreds of licences spread throughout Australia.

The second range of amendments proposed by this Bill relates to finance. Comcare will receive premiums to cover its liabilities and administration costs. But this is really what Comcare's role is at the moment. It does have expertise in this area.

I have had several constituents in Dunkley who have needed assistance with various Comcare claims. In my opinion, Comcare has always been an efficient organisation, considering the legislative framework in which it has to work. My constituents have mainly had problems where Comcare has said, `Well, this is all we can do under the Act'. Clearly in certain circumstances its hands are tied. I have made a number of appearances before the Comcare appeals tribunal, endeavouring to have some matters clarified and settled. But in this new utopia of government control and regulation, each department will have its own little SICO unit. No doubt each one will operate under the same rules as Comcare or be licensed under the same rules as Comcare.

People employed before the CERC Act of 1988 commenced work under one set of rules. As one would expect from a government unable to stop meddling in things it should never even be involved in, these rules were changed in 1988 with the consequence that Comcare's ability to perform its task successfully has been limited.

Where a claim is prior to 1988, what would happen? I suppose a Comcare unit would still run the case. But what if the department itself decided on a class 3 licence? A whole new number of staff would have to become familiar with aspects of cases which can be very complicated indeed. But no doubt we will see a massive recruitment of new class legal people who will be employed to administer an unnecessarily complicated set of rules. It is an ideal scenario for the Canberra mandarins and another disaster for the taxpayer.

The third amendment will allow for the recovery of costs from Commonwealth departments and authorities. The Commission will be able to enter into commercial arrangements under which it provides services related to its function on a fee for service basis. Why then as a logical extension cannot a department or authority make its own identical arrangements with private insurance companies? Why must government departments be restricted to using their own or other government bodies for services? At a guess, my answer would be that such a practice would limit employment opportunities here in Canberra—and, as we know, this would constitute the end of civilisation as we know it.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), in his second reading speech, stressed that the licences are to be subject to a system of conditions that one government department imposes upon another, the cost of which will inevitably be passed on to the unfortunate taxpayer. The Minister stated that each department or authority must comply with strict conditions. If these conditions applied to private industry, there would be strict penalties for non-compliance. The concept of bureaucrats subjecting other bureaucrats to penalties is incredible. As we all know, bureaucrats are completely immune from the discipline of the market and market forces. Any penalties they might incur for wrongdoing will simply be passed on to the taxpayer and paid for out of public money. It is, of course, a very different story when the Canberra mandarins are making rules for the private sector.

The Minister also offered departments or authorities the possibility of bank guarantees—no doubt in lieu of early payments—so that the banks could be asked to guarantee tax collections. This surely is a new approach to funding government. However, I cannot see anything in this Bill which makes this insurance scheme fully funded. It appears that costs only have to be recovered. What has become the scandal of WorkCare in Victoria commenced on this basis, without proper calculations. It is virtually inevitable that the largest employer in the nation will soon run up huge debts or unfunded liabilities. If these unfunded liabilities are added to other government unfunded liabilities such as long service leave, termination and redundancies, pension entitlements and superannuation entitlements, the burden on the taxpayer of funding the Public Service cocoon will become even more horrendous than it currently is.

If these liabilities worth billions of dollars are added to the nation's other liabilities such as our overseas loans, the country will be in an even bigger mess. Today at Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) admitted that the country is in a mess. The mess revolves around one million unemployed, a recession that he made us have, an horrendous overseas debt, declining productivity and a prehistoric industrial relations system which continues to disemploy our youth and to pay homage to nineteenth century traditions of class struggle and craft unionism that are singularly inappropriate for Australia in the 1990s.

This Bill will not do anything for the unemployed. It will not lessen the burden of overseas debt by 1c. If anything, it will slow economic growth and impede business while various government departments and authorities become more inward looking. This myopia would not matter so much except for the fact that many major projects and private sector initiatives are held up.

One of the great problems facing Australia in the 1990s is the uncontrolled growth of the government and public sector. As the example of eastern Europe so vividly demonstrates, government is incredibly bad at doing many things. It is very bad at running transport systems, factories, labour market programs, social services, universities, mines, car plants, restaurants, insurance schemes and so on. Government fix-it schemes, subsidies to exporters and the mania for bureaucratic or expert picking of winners are precisely the wrong directions in which this country should go.

The task of government is to have sound finance. A major priority must be to keep down public expenditure and borrowing. Otherwise, government is simply stealing the very resources that industry needs in order to grow and invest. It is scandalous that this country has such a low rate of domestic savings. Americans, and more recently the Japanese, have built their great industries on a high savings ratio. Australians must be encouraged rather than punished—as they currently are—for saving. Prosperity will return to this country only when it is recognised that competition and markets with properly defined property rights are the vehicles for economic success and individual freedom. The absence of legal rights is a crucial factor in explaining the poverty of socialist regimes and the poor performance of corporate states when government and business do deals and when government establishes itself in a monopoly position.

One need look only at the experience of the last 20 years to see that government has virtually never managed to secure a competitive advantage in the production of goods and services. The results of the Commonwealth establishing yet another government authority would simply add weight to my argument. Indeed, the Commonwealth Employment (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1992 is yet another example of what the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) referred to the other day as the scandal that has become government in Canberra and the scandal that has become government in Australia. This is an example of a government out of control and an example of a squandering of taxpayers' resources.

Although we are not opposing this Bill, there are really a number of questions and problems that arise, particularly from the Minister's second reading speech to which I will refer. On page 1 he states:
The main focus of the Bill is to continue the reform of Commonwealth employees' compensation arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, my experience indicates that the problems are with the Act, not with Comcare itself. Further on, he states:
The Commission's role in the prevention of workplace injury and disease through improved occupational health and safety practices and the rehabilitation of injured workers was emphasised.

Comcare is centralised in each State and its influence at the workplaces spread all over the country certainly is limited. I question whether licensing is the answer or just making each location responsible for its safety. On page 2 of the Minister's second reading speech he states:
The Commission was restructured as a regulatory body. . . This includes determining compensation premiums.
Now a licence will allow self-insurance quite freely. On page 3 the Minister states:

In the CERC Act in 1988, provision was made for both Australia Post and Telecom to become self-administrators of the Commonwealth Workers' Compensation Scheme. This was for a two year trial period. Under these arrangements the two organisations were responsible for all aspects of the administration of the CERC Act for their employees.
This new Act appears to cover not just Telecom and Australia Post but other authorities with no commercial application. He states further:

. . . the implementation . . . It does so in a way that is consistent with preserving flexibility and increasing efficiency in the operation of the Commonwealth's Employee Compensation arrangements. But, at the same time, it will ensure that the licensed authorities operate under an appropriate system of regulation by the Commission.
I question whether the Commonwealth or its authorities should be in the employee compensation arrangements anyway. The Minister continues:
Commonwealth authorities will be able to apply to the Commission for licences under the Act.
It would be hard to imagine a situation where a licence would be declined. I think it would be automatic. On page 4 of the Minister's speech he states:
A class 1 licence will allow an authority to operate as a self-insurer.

This may be satisfactory, as I mentioned earlier, for Australia Post or Telecom, but is it satisfactory for a non-commercial type enterprise, of which there are literally hundreds in the Government directory? The Minister continues:

The conditions able to be set by the Commission will include conditions limiting the maximum liability for which a licensed authority may self-insure, or in respect of which it may make a determination . . .
liability . . . will revert to Comcare depending on the class of licence.
Comcare in this instance has been an underwriter and an insurance broker. Is it capable of that particular function, I ask? Page 5 of the Minister's second reading speech states:

Because a licensed authority will be bound, as a condition of its licence, to comply with the Act, a failure to comply with the guidelines or directions of the Commission will involve a breach of that condition. The Commission will be able to suspend a class 2 or class 3 licence or revoke a licence of any class for breach of any condition. It will also be able to direct a licensed authority to comply with the conditions of the licence. The provisions of the Bill also detail the effects of a suspension or revocation.
If this were a Bill applicable to private industry, penalties would be involved. Why not in this particular case? On page 6 the Minister states:

The Bill aims at simplifying the operation of the CERC Act by including a special or standing appropriation. There will be payable to Comcare the moneys necessary to meet undischarged liabilities for claims under the previous compensation arrangements. In addition, Comcare will be paid amounts equal to the administrative costs attributable to these claims.
How is this possible without detailed actuarial calculations and conflicts with the financial impact statement later in the Minister's statement? Page 7 states:

The Minister for Finance may determine the opening balances for the special appropriations and the rate of notional interest to be applied to the balance from time to time in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.
These could be quite large sums of money. I trust this will be clearly shown in the Budget papers. The Minister continues:

DEBATE.TITLE: AVIATION FUEL REVENUES (SPECIAL APPROPRIATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Mr Snowdon:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill 1992 brings on an important debate which has ramifications for the whole aviation industry in Australia. In August 1990 the Government announced its intention to transfer the remaining Commonwealth-owned aerodromes to full local ownership. Those local owners—and most of them are local councils—would then become responsible for the operation and maintenance of these aerodromes.

PARA.TAB: The airport local ownership plan, commonly referred to as the ALOP, was to be phased out by 1994. However, the One Nation statement provided an additional $25m for the phasing out of the ALOP by June 1993. That program has been accelerated and that is causing quite a bit of concern amongst the local councils and local owners under the aerodrome local ownership plan. The ALOP has been funded by a loading of 3.010c per litre on aviation gasoline.

As the handing over of local aerodromes is now well under way, this Bill has been introduced to allow a reduction in the rate of excise to correspond with the reduction of government outlays for the ALOP. Initially the reduction will be just 1c per litre, applicable immediately. A further 1c reduction will apply when the number of Commonwealth airports is reduced to 100—the Government expects that to be later this year—with the full sum being reduced with the termination of the scheme in June 1993. The amendments proposed in this Bill will not result in any net revenue loss to the Civil Aviation Authority or the Commonwealth.

The coalition supports the Bill, but I will highlight a number of issues, particularly the problems that are being experienced by local owners and local councils in the operation and maintenance of these aerodromes under the ALOP. I have a very important aerodrome in my electorate which services a lot of aviation traffic. The management committee of that aerodrome would want an assurance from the Government before the phasing out of the ALOP in June 1993 that the aerodrome is brought up to the standards that are acceptable by the Civil Aviation Authority. It would also want to ensure that all of the navigation directional beacon is relocated from Maiden Gully to the airport, and also that the flight paths for that airport are exactly defined and are appropriate to the operation and the continued efficient operation of the Bendigo airport.

There have been a number of reasons why that airport needs to be kept open, and one of the most important is the emergency services including air ambulance, the regional fire services and the State Emergency Service as well as a number of commercial operators who use the Bendigo airport on regular occasions and who provide a very valuable service. That airport is quite capable of handling some quite large aeroplanes. In fact, Prince Charles and Princess Diana visited Bendigo in an RAAF aircraft, which was equivalent to about a 707 size aircraft. It was quite capable of landing on that strip and taking off from that strip. So it is an important part of the aviation world. It also forms a link with other local ownership aerodromes throughout Australia and forms a very important part of the transport network in Australia.

The coalition has given a commitment to maintenance support for rural, remote and regional aerodromes under its Fightback package. It has made a commitment to the local councils and local owners of those strips. We believe there is a community service obligation which entails the maintenance and ongoing support for those airstrips throughout rural, remote and regional areas. We have heard a lot of talk from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about improving transport infrastructure in this country. He made some attempt at it in the One Nation statement, but most of what was talked about included rail and not much was mentioned of this particular plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nearly $26m extra.

—Yes, $26m but that is revenue neutral. The Government is going to rip it off them from avgas anyway. That is what this Bill is all about. The Government is not putting any more money into it. It should not try to kid the local ownership and the councils that it is. The Government is just taking some of the money which it already collects from avgas and putting it back into that $25m; that is all. The Government knows that.

PARA.TAB: To bring all of those airports up to standard and to keep the maintenance up, the coalition has made a commitment based on the community service obligation to ensure that those airports keep up to standard and meet the requirements of the Civil Aviation Authority. We believe that is very important for the total transport network throughout Australia. As well as the need to maintain and upgrade rail services, we need to get our shipping in place as well as our aviation. That is an issue that the Government is not addressing. But I will not continue that line.

There are benefits also in the general area of Fightback which help the aviation industry. Bearing in mind that the Government collects a lot of excise revenue from aviation fuel, we believe that it should be putting more back into the aviation industry and also into the promotion of tourism. Tourism, in particular, is an area where the coalition has given a commitment to introduce a number of taxation policy initiatives, including reducing the overall tax burden and increasing disposable income by the lowering of personal income tax. That means that people will have more money in their pockets to go on holidays—to use our aviation industry to go to the wonderful tourist resorts that we have throughout Australia. Everyone in this chamber would recognise the impact that the airline pilots dispute had on the tourism industry, particularly with the reduced flights and the drop in tourist numbers flying throughout Australia.

The Fightback package also makes some major concessions to the tourism industry and the aviation industry by way of the abolition of the wholesale sales tax and the proposed abolition of the petrol excise and payroll tax. The aviation industry is subjected to all of those taxes. That is an added cost to the industry and it increases the fares.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the GST? Wait until the tourists cop that.

—The honourable member for Burke just interjected. What he does not recognise is the massive amount of wholesale sales tax that is involved in the aviation industry. All of its spare parts and all of its servicing attract wholesale sales tax. That will all be abolished under the Fightback package—the petrol excise and the payroll tax. All those companies in the aviation industry have huge payroll tax bills. That payroll tax will be abolished, and that will be reflected in lower fares for tourists.

PARA.TAB: There will be a faster phasing down of import duties on spare parts that might come in for airlines and the aviation industry. Under the Fightback package, there will also be an abolition of the training guarantee levy—which is an imposition of cost on the whole industry. There will be no further increases in the superannuation guarantee levy. There will be reduced capital gains tax, especially for small business and tourism operators who are dependent on the aviation industry to bring their clients to some of our better known tourist facilities throughout Australia. What an important role the aviation industry plays in that service! There will also be a review of depreciation allowances, and we will abolish the automatic indexation of excise.

In the area of infrastructure initiatives, under Fightback we are going to accelerate and facilitate airport construction and improvements. We know that this Government has shied away from the third runway for what seems to be years. It is like Blue Hills on the ABC: it just goes on and on. Every week there is another episode. I note that the honourable member for Burke is not interjecting on that one.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Nor should he be invited to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your guidance. The coalition is prepared to have a go at these things, and we will right the aviation industry. As a very important adjunct of aviation, we will reorganise the Australian railways to increase their efficiency. I am pleased to see that at long last the Government has recognised that the national railways are a very important link in the transport system. I see the honourable member for Burke nodding his head to show that he agrees with that comment. It is important that we maintain the rail service, because of its links with the aviation industry and its ability to carry tourists to their destinations after having arrived in this country from overseas, and also for domestic travel.

PARA.TAB: Telecommunications, a very important part of the aviation industry as well, will be opened up to full market competition. That is important in this country, because our aviation industry is dependent upon improved communications. We will also be pursuing an open skies aviation policy. We will ensure that terminal space is available on a competitive basis. I reflect on the demise of Compass Airlines and its resurrection under another name, and on the sad state of our country's aviation industry.

The coalition has made a particular commitment to the full privatisation of Qantas. We would encourage the participation of the new airline which has taken over the running of Compass to provide some competition in that area, because the main benefit of the introduction of Compass into the aviation world in Australia was the substantial lowering of fares throughout Australia. More people than ever in this country decided to use air travel as their main source of transport during the introduction of Compass, with its competitive prices in the fare structure. The other two airlines, Ansett and Australian Airlines, were able to compete and meet those prices, and to provide, for the first time in many years in Australia, some competition in domestic air travel in this country.

The other benefit of the Fightback package that I want to mention is the benefit that would go to general aviation, especially the abolition of excise on avgas, which is a commitment which will allow a redirection of 27c per litre on business and 19c per litre on private aviation gasoline. We have had a very good response from pilots and operators of private airlines, and private owners of aeroplanes, who are thrilled that the coalition has given a commitment to that, because they believe that will be of substantial assistance to them.

As I said, the coalition does not oppose the Bill, but we do have a number of concerns about it, which I have spelt out, particularly in the changeover, the phasing out completely of the ALOP and the bringing up of local aerodromes to the standard required by the Civil Aviation Authority, before those aerodromes are transferred from government ownership to local councils and local owners.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 12 centres on that list in fact have smaller regional populations than Gippsland. The submission goes on to say that the travelling time from Gippsland to an ATO office is 4 1/2 hours, whereas the maximum travelling time from any other Victorian centre to an existing office is three hours. On the grounds of equity and efficiency, a very simple but eloquent submission was put to the Taxation Office. But, surprise, surprise, the reply we got back on 21 April this year states:

PARA.TAB: As you may be aware, the ATO is currently undertaking a major program of decentralisation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is to be congratulated for that. The letter continues:
This program, which is now well advanced, involves establishing new "branch offices" in suburban locations in capital cities or in major regional centres.
I have no argument so far. The letter goes on:
The current round of new decentralised offices has been in the planning stages since 1988 or earlier and some of the new offices will not be established for three or four years yet.
It is fine so far. The letter continues:
In the last six months the ATO has established a presence at Box Hill, Moonee Ponds and Geelong . . .

It also states that soon it will establish another one in Moorabbin. Is that not terrific? It is decentralisation to place three new offices in Melbourne, all in the 03 area code. What sort of nonsense is it when the ATO calls that decentralisation? The letter then goes on further to give the justification for this:

One of the reasons for the establishment of the new Moorabbin Office is to allow the ATO at Dandenong, which currently services your region, to redirect its activities and responsibilities. This will provide a wider range of taxpayer services to the residents of Gippsland.

How silly can one get? The ATO office is there. That report quite clearly states that it is not servicing the people. Yet the ATO goes on and puts one down at Moorabbin. That is not decentralisation; that is total bureaucratic nonsense.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who signed this letter, ought to be ashamed of himself for accepting such nonsense. I put it to him quite simply: we have a population of over 200,000 people; in the interests of decentralisation and fairness, I ask him to look once again at the situation and put a tax office in Gippsland. This would obviously create employment in regional areas, which is so important for women, who are quite often disadvantaged in these areas. I implore the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Parliamentary Secretary to disregard the gobbledegook that was placed before them and get on to genuine decentralisation and equity for my region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I give the House the benefit of my intended discourse, I want to say a few words about the contribution made by the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus). She raised an issue which I think is very important to the quality of life for very many people; that is, how we treat the disabled, and particularly the intellectually disabled, in the community. The answer to the problem is not, as suggested, just through the taxation system; it is a philosophical problem.

PARA.TAB: The problem arises because many of the people in the welfare industry, the social workers, have decided—arbitrarily, I might add—that we should do away with institutionalisation and people should be returned to their homes. This is a very nice, tidy arrangement for governments, I have no doubt. But the reality is that there are some people for whom institutionalisation is the only solution. It is the only sane solution other than simply murdering them.

I believe that we need to have a complete rethink in this area and that we need to re-fund some of the institutions which used to cater for these people. I have come across people who were previously institutionalised. These people are not particularly dangerous to the community but they are dangerous to themselves; they are incapable of looking after themselves properly. They now live fairly tortured lives in all sorts of cheap accommodation.

In the cases that the honourable member for Hawker brought forward, clearly the quality of life for the parents who are looking after these children is abysmal. They are very often in a situation of terror and certainly one in which they could have no expectations of what we would normally accept as reasonable conditions in life. I believe we need to have a complete rethink of this welfare industry.

As a government we have to stand up to the nonsense that is preached by many of these social workers and opt for re-funding some of the institutions which took these pressures off the community. In some cases, there is simply no humane or compassionate alternative to institutionalisation. Institutional facilities should be in the community.

I also want to talk about seriously head-injured people because here we have another case where I think governments act without a full understanding and knowledge of the situation. Many people who have suffered head injuries, mainly as a result of motor car accidents, are intellectually quite sound, but, in a sense, they are prisoners in their own bodies. They are locked in; they often have no motor functions; and we treat them as vegetables.

We have them in C-class hospitals, which are fairly expensive, with no attempt made at rehabilitation. The rehabilitation is often handled by doctors who simply have no neurosurgical experience. They may ask a patient a question and if they get no apparent response, they then conclude that the patient is a vegetable. The patient is then put into an institution and virtually forgotten.

People are entombed in their bodies for the rest of their lives. This is a tremendous cost to society, apart from the humanitarian angle. We ought to be looking at much more serious attempts at rehabilitation. Dr Newman, who has written a book on the subject, is one of the world's leading experts. His work has been recognised overseas but it is not recognised in Australia to anything like the same degree. I know that he approached the Government some time ago for a grant of $50,000 to codify the systems of treating these people and the rehabilitation processes.

People have come to me asking what they are to do when they cannot afford to keep their child, relation, son, father or whoever at a facility where that person has made tremendous progress. We must look at this area from pure compassion. We must be prepared to look at giving these people a chance to lead some sort of normal life. In doing so, we will have a very big effect on the cost that is incurred by the state. If we can rehabilitate half of these people, we will save a lot of money, although I do not think it is the money that we should be looking at. I urge the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) to quickly assess the work of Dr Newman and fund the work on these brain-injured people. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) made reference in his contribution to the adjournment debate tonight to a study which had been published and released by WEL, the Women's Electoral Lobby. Given that the honourable member made reference to that study, one ought to point out the inadequacies of the study itself. Whilst most members would generally find that work which has been published by WEL over the years is of a reasonable standard, there are certainly gross inaccuracies and inconsistencies in the way in which this particular study was put together by WEL.

PARA.TAB: What it has done is take the price of a range of goods, deducted from that price the wholesale sales tax and then added on a 15 per cent GST. If that were the end of the story, it may well be correct, but it is not the end of the story. In Fightback, what we propose is the reduction, removal and abolition of a whole range of taxes—taxes such as the fuel excise, which is the $10 or $11 a tank that every person who shops will have in their pocket at the end of the week simply by saving that from filling up on their tank of petrol and the payroll tax which flows through the system and which is a huge tax on employment itself.

In addition to that, we have the Government now saying that it is going to tax business further by adding a superannuation guarantee levy on top of the costs that business is already paying; as if we have somehow got the golden pear that somehow produces these items which can be passed on to workers. That is a major problem. It is proper that the inaccuracies of that report be pointed out.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 5 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: Did Commonwealth Government departments enter into arrangements which gave preference to travel by their employees on particular airlines to the exclusion of Compass; if so, (a) what were the arrangements, (b) which departments entered into them and (c) did the arrangements prevent the departments from benefiting from lower air fares offered by Compass while it was operating.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Commonwealth departments did not enter into arrangements which gave preference to travel by their employees on particular airlines to the exclusion of Compass.

The Government's 1987 Travel Reforms restructured Australian Public Service travel services. As a result, from 1 January 1988 until 31 December 1991 Commonwealth Government departments and agencies organised their travel under what were then called `Block' arrangements. Three year travel contracts were arranged for nine groups, or 'Blocks', of Commonwealth departments and agencies with five travel agents. Travel contracts for each of the nine `Blocks' were negotiated by the APS Travel Review Team through the Department of Administrative Services. Under the `Block' arrangements all contracts were for the provision of travel services as a travel agent and not as a carrier. That is, all departments and agencies were free to nominate carriage on any airline and to pursue discount fares wherever available. The arrangements continued to apply to all but one of the `Blocks' until 31 December 1991.

These arrangements did not involve a preference to any airline and did not prevent departments and agencies from utilising discounted fares that were offered by Compass when it was operating on relevant routes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister able to say how many persons have been retrenched in the (a) automotive, (b) footwear, (c) clothing and (d) textiles industries since 1989.

(2) How many retrenchments referred to in part (1) are attributable to (a) changes in tariff and quota policies, (b) the failure of major company structures, (c) the illegal use or misappropriation of funds and (d) high interest on operating capital.
(3) How has the ratio between imports and Australian sourced goods changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Taking the automotive sector to include Australian car makers, component producers and the import sector of the passenger motor vehicle industry, the Automotive Industry Authority estimates that total employment fell from 62,395 in 1989 to 52,281 in 1991.

(1)(b)-(d) The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not collect data on the number of retrenchments from the Textile, Clothing and Footwear (TCF) industries. However, as part of the overall TCF Plan introduced in 1988, the Department of Employment, Education and Training provides special assistance to displaced TCF employees. Part of this program involves the notification of retrenchments to the CES. The Office of Labour Market adjustment has provided the following information on notified retrenchments for the period 1989 to 1991. Footwear had a total of 2,296, clothing 7,697 and textiles industries 3,909.
(2) Information is not available to the Government that would allow data on the cause of retrenchments to be disaggregated in the manner proposed.
(3) I have addressed this question with particular reference to the automotive and TCF sectors.
In 1989 imported cars held 24.3% of the Australian new car sales. The market share of imports rose to 31% in 1991. In the first quarter of 1992, imports took 39% of the new car market.

For the TCF industries the appropriate Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for 1990/91 are not yet available. Nevertheless, imports as a percentage of the total Australian TCF market went from 33.0% in 1988/89 to 34.2% in 1989/90. In the individual industries, textile imports decreased their share from 52.1% in 1988/89 to 48.8% in 1989/90 while clothing and footwear imports increased from 18.2% to 22.7% over the same period.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What productivity improvements, in percentages, in (a) fuel consumption, (b) locomotive maintenance, (c) signalling and communications, (d) terminal operations, (e) train crewing, (f) track maintenance and (g) wagon maintenance by the National Rail Corporation (NRC) are necessary for the success of its five year plan.

(2) Does each of the improvements referred to in part (1) vary in relation to (a) the State Rail Authority of New South Wales, (b) the Public Transport Corporation, Victoria, (c) Australian National operating on the mainland and (d) Westrail; if so, in what way.
(3) Will staff of the Public Transport Corporation, Victoria, with the necessary skills and qualifications be given preference for employment in the NRC's Victorian operations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The NRC is currently developing its first Corporate Plan, which will address, among other things, productivity improvements. However, the

ANSWER.PARA: productivity improvement benchmarks used in financial modelling to test the commercial viability of the National Rail Corporation (NRC) are set out in the National Rail Freight Initiative Task Force Report of 21 March 1991. They are:

PARA.TAB: (a) fuel consumption—20 per cent
(b) locomotive maintenance—30 per cent
(c) signalling and communications—50 per cent
(d) terminal operations—33 per cent
(e) train crewing—40 per cent
(f) track maintenance—20 per cent, and
(g) wagon maintenance—42 per cent.

A definite answer to this question can only be made by each of the systems which have the detailed information on current, and prospective, performance. However, it would seem reasonable to expect that productivity improvements would vary between systems. As indicated by the Industry Commission in its recent report on the Rail Industry, not all systems are currently performing to the same efficiency standard. (This is referred to in Chapter 2 of the Industry Commission Report, and in Appendices C, D and E.) Furthermore, State systems may not be able to achieve the same degree of productivity gains available to a national system operator because they are artificially constrained in their operations by State borders. To illustrate by one example, this factor may prevent full advantage to be taken of crew rostering improvements.

(3) The NRC is presently discussing an enterprise agreement with the ACTU and the rail unions. These discussions are not yet finalised. However, I am advised by the NRC that its selection and employment will be on the basis of requirement, suitability and merit and, all other things being equal, preference will be given to the employment of existing rail system employees. The implementation of the enterprise agreement remains entirely a matter for the NRC.
